TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, by letter dated 21 October 1997, has raised a matter of privilege under standing order 81 and asked that precedence be given under that standing order to a motion relating to the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The question he raises is whether two documents of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund have been dealt with by the Attorney‐General, Mr Daryl Williams MP, the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin, or Mr Warren Entsch MP, in a manner not authorised by the joint committee.
I am required by the standing order to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence, having regard to the following criteria:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.
Past presidential rulings have explained that a matter is given precedence if it is capable of being held by the Senate to meet criterion (a) and if there is no other readily available remedy.

Unauthorised disclosure of committee documents is declared by the Senate's privilege resolutions to be a matter which may constitute a contempt of the Senate, and, in past precedents, allegations of such unauthor ised disclosure have been regarded as meeting the criteria for giving precedence to a motion.

There is a difficulty with the matter raised by Senator Bolkus, however. One of the persons named in Senator Bolkus's letter, Mr Entsch, is a member of the House of Representatives, and past presidential rulings have made it clear that the Senate cannot inquire into the conduct of a member of the House of Representatives, other than a minister acting in the capacity of a minister. Only the House of Representatives can inquire into the conduct of its members other than ministers acting in that capacity. Rulings to this effect were given by President Sibraa on 17 May 1988 and by President Beahan on 19 September 1994.

Although Mr Williams is a minister and may be taken to have been acting in that capacity in dealing with the documents in question, the evidence of his dealing with the documents is his disclosure of them in the course of proceedings in the House of Representatives. The Senate cannot inquire into proceedings in the House of Representatives.

I therefore determine that precedence may be given to a motion relating to the matter raised by Senator Bolkus only in so far as it relates to unauthorised dealings with committee documents other than by members of the House of Representatives who are not ministers and other than in the course of proceedings in the House of Representatives.

On 20 June 1996 the Senate adopted a recommendation of the Privileges Committee that, in cases of unauthorised disclosure of committee documents, the committee concerned should in the first instance inquire into the disclosure and determine whether it had a tendency substantially to interfere with the work of the committee or of the Senate. The resolution adopting this procedure, however, explicitly does not prevent a Senator raising a matter of privilege under standing order 81 in the absence of such an inquiry and determination by the committee concerned.

If Senator Bolkus decides to exercise his right to give a notice of motion, the notice must be framed so as to make it clear that any inquiry by the Privileges Committee does not extend to the conduct of members of the House of Representatives other than ministers acting in the capacity of ministers or to proceedings in the House of Representatives. I table Senator Bolkus's letter and attachments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. The Senate votes its will to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
2. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—At the moment in the chamber, one‐sixth or perhaps even one‐seventh of senators are present. When we deal with notices of motion—essentially they are notices of motion from the opposition, the Democrats or the Greens—quite frequently we get a situation where the government opposes the notices of motion. The numbers in the Senate being as they are, if notices of motion are supported by the opposition, the Greens and the Democrats, it inevitably comes to my vote.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that I am the only senator who has to spend such an inordinate amount of time physically present in this chamber listening to other persons' motions. I am not complaining about that; that is my job. There are other matters which require substantial amounts of my time. Unfortunately, as I understand the divisions which are taking place, the Wik matter is one of those matters. Hopefully that time will not be broken by other activities. I am raising this point so that honourable senators might give some thought to whether contentious issues could be dealt with in one group at a particular time on a particular day of the week. That would certainly assist me.

I do apologise for that. I understand the situation and I ask honourable senators to understand that everybody else seems to be able to either get a pair or have somebody else cover for them in this chamber. That might change, of course, after the next election. Really, this is an appeal to honourable senators to give consideration to perhaps having one day—say a Thursday—when we can have a look at these matters. I have not done it before, but I appeal on this occasion because in the next few weeks I will have to spend a considerable amount of time on the Wik measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it is a matter which I will draw to the attention of the Chairman of the Procedures Committee where it can be discussed. Thank you for proposing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This matter is being considered at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting which is taking place at the moment. We are also aware that the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group will be meeting today, Scotland time, to discuss these issues. Australia will continue to work with the international community to support efforts to improve human rights in Nigeria and Kenya. This we will do in a constructive and positive way. As you will be aware, Commonwealth heads of government are meeting this week and will give these issues serious consideration. Other international measures are also being taken.

SPEECH.PARA: We continue to be concerned by the human rights situation in Nigeria. We wish to play a positive role in conjunction with other countries in urging Nigeria to observe internationally recognised human rights standards. At the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting we will be working with other heads of government to consider Nigerian participation in the Commonwealth. If CHOGM considers that Nigeria has not made enough progress towards compliance with the Harare declaration to warrant lifting its suspension, Australia would support Nigeria's continued suspension from the Commonwealth. It will be important to monitor closely progress with Nigeria's transition program. If the Nigerian timetable for return to democracy stalls, we would support consideration of a sanctions package by heads of governments. The Commonwealth looks to the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group for recommendations. Decisions on these recommendations are matters for determination by Commonwealth heads of government.

BREAK.PARA: The international community is watching political developments in Kenya closely in the lead‐up to the Kenyan national elections. The international community attaches considerable importance to free and fair elections in Kenya as a prime indicator of political stability. Western donor countries, including Australia, have made several group demarches to the Kenyan government in recent months advocating free and fair elections. Representatives from the Australian High Commission in Nairobi will participate as part of an international election monitoring group.

In summary, the Australian government is being actively and constructively involved through the Commonwealth heads of government process and the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group, and we believe that is the appropriate action to take.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any objection to the motion, as amended, being taken as formal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.STATE: (Victoria ‐ Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I seek leave to make a statement on the matter in anticipation of it being taken as formal.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is committed to improving waterfront reliability and productivity to enhance job prospects, exports and economic growth for the benefit of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: In May last year, just a few months after the election, expressions of interest were invited from a number of relevant consultants to provide advice `regarding an industrial relations strategy for the implementation of waterfront reform'.

ACIL Economics and Policy Pty Ltd was selected because of their extensive experience in waterfront reform, including having conducted two reviews in New Zealand, and their involvement with a range of export industries. ACIL had also subcontracted with First IR Pty Ltd, a firm with an intimate knowledge of the new industrial relations landscape encompassed in the Workplace Relations Bill that was introduced into parliament late last year.

The consultants submitted a report finalising the consultancy on 18 September 1996. The report was commissioned to assist the government's consideration of waterfront reform. The awarding of this contract was listed in the government Gazette in 1996, and in supplementary information to the 1995‐96 annual report of the Department of Transport and Regional Development, also published in 1996.

ACIL have also recently been engaged to provide advice on options to improve the reliability and productivity of the services provided by the waterfront industries. ACIL were engaged for this project at the direction of the former Minister for Transport and Reg ional Development, based on official advice that a tendering process can be forgone where there is a need for a particular consultant to further develop or enhance a task previously carried out by that consultant and which requires special knowledge and familiarity with the previous task. This advice was drawn from that department's supply manual, which was issued on 11 July 1995 under the previous Labor government when Mr Brereton was the minister for transport.

The contract with ACIL provides for expenditures of up to $600,000, which allows for the potential use of subcontractors. Again, the consultancy was listed in the government Gazette and the information was provided to Senator O'Brien in a response to a question on notice. The opposition has already asked questions about these consultancies in the estimates committee hearings in August 1997 and has been provided with relevant information.

There are five categories of documents included in Senator O'Brien's motion. Part (a) seeks all documents relating to the tender and awarding of the consultancy contract to ACIL economics on or about 15 May 1996 relating to waterfront reform. These tender documents were provided to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee in response to a question taken on notice at its hearings on 20 August 1997. A further copy of these documents will be provided if required.

Other documents relating to the awarding of the consultancy contract involve a comparative assessment of bidders as well as the tender proposals of the bidders. These were provided in confidence. If these are to be released, either publicly or on a restricted basis, to Senator O'Brien, privacy considerations would require prior contact with the affected organisations to obtain approval. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) is prepared to contact the relevant parties to seek their permission to release all or part of the documents relating to them.

Part (b) of the motion seeks the report arising from the contract awarded to ACIL Economics on or about 15 May 1996. This report is classified commercial‐in‐confidence and cabinet‐in‐confidence and contains advice to assist the government's contribution to waterfront reform. The report is part of the deliberative processes involved in the functions of the government, and disclosure would be contrary to the public interest.

The cabinet has discussed the development of the government's policy on waterfront reform. The development of policies relating to waterfront and shipping reform is of national economic importance. Disclosure of the report could damage relations with the states, as some information contained in the report was provided in confidence by state governments. There is also the potential that disclosure could endanger the physical safety of a person or persons. Accordingly, the government will be claiming public interest immunity in relation to the disclosure of this document.

Part (c) of the motion seeks the terms of reference for the contract awarded to ACIL Economics on or about 20 June 1997 relating to the waterfront reform and all related documents. The minister is prepared to table the terms of reference for the contract, and I table that document now.

Part (d) of the motion seeks a list of all organisations contacted by ACIL Economics pursuant to the contracts let to it on or about 15 May 1996 and 20 June 1997. The list of organisations contacted for the 1996 ACIL project is part of the ACIL report. Knowledge of specific persons or entities visited could adversely affect the commercial interests of those named, and may also endanger the physical safety of persons. Full details of contacts under the 1997 ACIL project will form part of the report that has not yet been received. However, when the report is received, it can be expected to be treated in the same manner as the 1996 report. Accordingly, the government will claim public interest immunity in relation to these documents.

The final part of the motion seeks a list of all sites visited and travel undertaken by ACIL Economics pursuant to the contracts let to it on or about 15 May 1996 and 20 June 1997. The list of sites visited for the 1996 project is part of the ACIL report. Knowledge of specific persons or entities visited could adversely affect the commercial interests of those named and may also endanger the physical safety of persons.

The full extent of visits under the 1997 project will be part of the report, which has not been received as yet. However, when the report is received, it can be expected to be treated in the same manner as the 1996 report. Accordingly, the government will claim public interest immunity in relation to these documents. Information on interstate travel undertaken is provided for the purposes of reimbursement of costs and is recorded only at the level of the city visited. It would not be an effective use of departmental resources to collate this information and, to the extent that it has any relevance, it could identify specific persons or entities visited and adversely affect their privacy or commercial interests.

The ACIL projects are part of the advice to government on maritime issues. The former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, commissioned a number of consultancies to provide research and advice on maritime matters. In addition to ACIL he, through the department, engaged Dr Stephen Webster to prepare a report with the assistance of six other contractors. Five of these contracts were notified in the Gazette on 19 September 1997, and one will be notified in the normal course of events later this month.

Dr Webster's report was presented on 3 October 1997. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), as the minister now responsible for maritime matters, is currently considering the report. As with the ACIL documents, this report will be a valuable input into the government's development of policies in the maritime sector and will likewise be subject to public interest immunity.

Reform on the waterfront must be realised for the benefit of all Australians. We will not allow this objective to be placed in jeopardy by the premature release of documents which are inputs to our deliberative processes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank Senator Alston for his comments and the material that he has tabled today. Unfortunately, this matter has been outstanding for some time, and those matters were not drawn to our attention before this morning's revelation.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the other comments that the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business made, it is important that it be on the record, prior to a determination of this motion, that until the demise of the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, there was within the department a well‐resourced division—the Maritime Division.

This reform program has been under way for some time, so it has to be said that there is not only expertise within that division but also experience. Despite this, the government chose to pay a consultant nearly $700,000 over the last year and this year to develop a strategy for reform on the waterfront—or that is what we are told.

Information on that matter has properly been sought at the Senate estimates process, but the government has, to date, denied the information available and, only this morning, has advised the availability of certain of that information. But the government continues to indicate it does not wish to produce all the information.

The Maritime Division—this properly resourced division; a part of the Department of Transport and Regional Development—has now been moved from its natural home into the Department of Industrial Relations. It is, in the opposition's view, a bizarre process which, as I said yesterday, indicates that the only transport policy this government has is to attack the Maritime Union. But, rather than get into that process, what we in the Estimates process are entitled to observe is the relevance of the advice sought, given the resourcing of this government, of a division which has, as I understand it, an annual budget of $62 million to conduct the necessary process of advising government. Yet we are advised that a further $700,000 in consultancy fees are being or have been paid to ACIL Economics to assist the government to prepare policy.

It is the opposition's view that we are entitled to scrutinise the expenditure of this $700,000 and to judge its worth, as are the people of Australia. We indicate that we are opposing the government's view on retaining the secrecy of these documents. The waterfront is a key area, but it is important that the Senate not be refused information to which it is legitimately entitled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I listened carefully to the statements of the minister. I have made statements on frequent occasions in this chamber in relation to the actual reasons for commercial in confidence retention of documents and information. Listening to the minister, I thought that many of his arguments were, to say the least, tenuous. This government said that every element of the previous government ought to be available for scrutiny, and we have been assured that we ought to be totally confident in the outsourcing and privatisation of functions of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have the government digging even further into a trench. Those elements of government expenditure which end up going out to private resources will be used as an excuse for not providing full and frank disclosure of what is going on. It is not good enough. This government has only been in power since last year. It is a dreadful sign for future government accountability, because we are going more and more into privatisation and competition policy in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is important, as has been said, that the Senate does protect its rights to information from the executive government. The current government, when in opposition, frequently used the forms of the parliament to obtain documentation from the previous government. It has always been my view that, no matter which government is in power, when the Senate or a senator makes a legitimate request of the executive government for legitimate information, that should be supported, irrespective of what the issue is.

SPEECH.PARA: A very serious situation is facing us. The statement that has been read by Senator Alston, and which was presumably prepared by the industrial relations minister, could be developing a line of argument which could be used against the provision of information on a whole range of issues. Nevertheless, a serious question has been raised.

As Senator O'Brien said, it was the first time that he had heard these matters and these questions raised against the provision of information. It is certainly the first time that I have heard of that. It concerns me that the government says that supply of this information to the Senate may endanger presumably the life and safety of certain individuals. That is a matter which we must all be interested in and concerned about.

However, I think that ought to be tested in some way. I am not sure that we ought not look at whether the matters raised in the minister's statement are of such a nature as should prevent us from proceeding with a demand that these be tabled. That could be done in the upcoming estimates committee meetings and in the consideration of the matter afterwards or, alternatively, it could be referred to another committee, whereby the chair and deputy chair of that committee would be able to assess whether or not the statements that have been made by the minister were of such importance that the information and, in particular, the report should not be provided to the Senate.

I do not think we should let go of the request that has been made. I note that Senator O'Brien indicated that it was the first time he had heard of those sorts of protections, and I presume it is the first time anybody around here has heard of them as well. At present, I suggest that perhaps we should defer the motion to another day, and then perhaps senators can consider a way of dealing with this matter so that we are not prevented by executive government action from obtaining information and documentation from the executive government, as we have done time and time again over the many years that this demand for presentation of documents has been made in the Senate—and that has been for the 21 or 22 years that I have been here.
Motion (by Senator O'Brien) agreed to:
That notice of motion No.752, as amended, be postponed till the next day of sitting.

TITLE.XREF: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT AMENDMENT (RESTART AND EXCEPTIONAL CIRCUMSTANCES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
This bill establishes the new Farm Family Restart Scheme and the exceptional circumstances relief payment for farm families.

This bill introduces an important element of the government's integrated rural policy, "Agriculture—Advancing Australia" which will help to build a competitive, sustainable and profitable rural sector. The measures introduced in this bill will ensure farm families experiencing financial hardship have equitable access to welfare support. The rural sector accounts for a major share of Australia's exports and provides the basis for much of the nation's value adding food and fibre processing industries. Its economic health and profitability is vital to the future prosperity of this nation.

The rural sector has faced unprecedented challenges in recent years. While the top 20 per cent of farm businesses are performing well, data collated by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics show the sector as a whole has endured a long period of negative profitability. Severe drought, low commodity prices and cost pressures, particularly in the farm finance market, have created a very difficult operating environment for farm businesses.

Madam President, my intention is not to talk down the sector and paint too gloomy a picture; it is simply to acknowledge the circumstances our farmers have and in many cases continue to endure. Their resilience in the face of adversity is indeed admirable.

There is, however, another side to the coin, for while there are challenges to be overcome, there is no poverty of opportunity for our farmers. They are efficient, competitive producers of high quality, clean food and fibre. They are ideally positioned to capture the significant opportunities presented by the rapid growth of Asian food markets and international trade reform.

Much has already been done by the government to position rural Australia to succeed in the years ahead. Our preparedness to reign in government expenditure and put the Commonwealth budget on track for surplus, together with broader micro‐economic reforms in areas such as the labour market, are good news for agriculture. The maintenance of low inflation and continuing reductions in real interest rates have allowed real progress to be made in reducing business input costs and provided a boost to Australia's international competitiveness through the resulting devaluation of the Australian dollar.

While much has been done to get the big picture right, there is more still this government can do to help secure the foundations of Australian agriculture. This bill is about investing substantial resources where it matters, just as the government has done through the Natural Heritage Trust and in areas such as quarantine and meat inspection reform. Agriculture—Advancing Australia is a comprehensive package with four key objectives; firstly, to help farm businesses profit from change; secondly, to provide positive incentives for ongoing farm adjustment; thirdly, to encourage social and economic development in rural areas and fourthly, and very importantly, to ensure the farm sector has access to an adequate welfare safety net.

"Agriculture—Advancing Australia" is the direct result of many government initiated reviews of rural policy which have been conducted over the past 18 months. These reviews have drawn on the expertise and experiences of many involved in the rural industry. Extensive consultation with state and territory governments, farmer groups and the public has contributed significantly in shaping the measures introduced today. The initiatives in this bill the farm family restart scheme and the exceptional circumstances relief payment, have received widespread endorsement from key farming bodies such as the National Farmers' Federation.

In the past, the interrelationship between rural welfare and business policy objectives has not been fully appreciated. In a sense, the integration of family life and welfare with the management of the farm business has been taken for granted. This interrelationship needs to be recognised in addressing the welfare needs of farming families. It is imperative that we do if we are to ensure the current transition in outlook from the family farm to the family farm business runs to a successful conclusion. This means also that welfare measures need to be distinct from measures targeted at improving the profitability of farming businesses.

This bill has been carefully designed to meet the coalition's long standing commitment to address these important welfare issues, while, at the same time, taking account of the uniqueness of family farm business structures, and the vulnerability of farming families to natural events.

Just as importantly, the measures contained in this bill offer carefully targeted assistance to those who wish to adjust out of farming. Additionally, it provides income support for those farm families who find themselves suffering financial hardship as a result exceptional circumstances which are beyond their capacity to manage.

Madam President, the new Farm Family Restart Scheme is the government's key program for delivering income support to the farm sector. It also provides adjustment assistance to farmers who wish to leave the industry.

The proposed amendments offer an innovative approach to assisting farm families. This legislation provides farmers with the opportunity to give serious consideration to the future of the farm and family without having to rush decisions. It recognises that it takes time to come to grips with the possibility of a future that does not entail farm ownership. It allows them to keep working the farm while they review their situation. It relieves the tremendous pressure than can arise from literally not being able to put food on the table.

The Farm Family Restart Scheme will provide a decision support system for farmers considering exiting the industry as well as those who need the breathing space to re‐focus their farm enterprise. This scheme provides access to professional advice to farmers to help them assess the future viability of their business.
The Farm Family Restart Scheme will begin on 1 December 1997. I will now provide the house with details of the features of the new scheme.

Income support will be provided to low income farmers who cannot borrow further against their assets. This support will be equivalent to the Newstart Allowance, plus Partner Allowance where appropriate. Very importantly, it does not require the farm family to put the farm on the market or undergo an activity test as would be the case if they were seeking support through the social security system. This support will be available to eligible farmers for up to one year;

Recipients will face an obligation to obtain professional advice on the future viability of the farm business, as well as ongoing professional advice to assist the family focus on either re‐building the business where this is possible, or leaving the industry. The government will provide financial support to the farm family to access this professional advice, which may include career counselling.

A re‐establishment grant of up to $45,000 will be available to eligible farmers. This grant will provide positive incentives for farmers to leave farming before their assets are severely depleted. I emphasise that eligible farmers will be able to apply for the re‐establishment grant only during the first two years of the operation of the Farm Family Restart Scheme. To receive the grant, those who apply and meet the eligibility criteria will need to sell their farm within twelve months of ceasing income support, or from the date of their application if income support is not sought.

The re‐establishment grant will be subject to a more generous assets test than past re‐establishment grants, but any income support provided under the Farm Family Restart Scheme will be deducted from the grant. The new assets test will allow farmers to have up to $90,000 in assets to qualify for the maximum grant. The grant will phase down by $2 for every $3 in assets above this threshold.

Farmers who have accessed the scheme for less than six months and withdraw will be eligible to apply to rejoin the scheme, to complete the twelve months. Farmers who withdraw from the scheme after six months will not be able to rejoin. Support paid under this scheme will be provided as a grant—not as a loan scheme, which was proven ineffective under the former government's farm household support scheme. It resulted in low income farmers incurring debts to the government which they simply did not have the capacity to repay. This government has, of course, decided to wipe the slate clean in this regard and write off these debts.
Madam President, the Farm Household Support Act 1992 is also being amended to introduce the exceptional circumstances relief payment.

The exceptional circumstances relief payment will be an income support payment available to farmers in areas declared to be in exceptional circumstances. Its rate of payment will also be equivalent to the newstart allowance, plus partner allowance where appropriate. It will be subject to the same income and off‐farm assets tests that apply to drought relief payment to ensure it is targeted to farm families who are experiencing financial hardship as a result of the exceptional circumstance. The exceptional circumstances relief payment will be equivalent to and replace the current drought relief payment.

The exceptional circumstances relief payment gives recognition to the fact that there are exceptional circumstances which are beyond the scope of normal farm risk management strategies. It will be available to farmers suffering financial hardship as a result of rare and severe events including, but not restricted to, extreme drought. It will allow farming families to focus on the task of managing their businesses in circumstances which are challenging enough without the added burden of worrying about how they will meet their day to day living costs.

The duration of this payment will be determined on a case by case basis according to the nature of the declared exceptional circumstance. A 12 months recovery period will continue to apply for exceptional drought.

Farmers currently in drought exceptional circumstances areas, and receiving the drought relief payment, will progressively move to the exceptional circumstances relief payment. As their drought exceptional circumstances certificates expire, they will be issued with exceptional circumstances certificates. Farmers completing their recovery period for the drought relief payment or reaching the end of exceptional circumstances relief payment support will be eligible to apply for the Farm Family Restart Scheme if they wish to do so.

The government will honour its commitments under the rural adjustment scheme. Farmers will still be able to apply for re‐establishment assistance under the rural adjustment scheme, until 30 November 1997. This will provide a smooth transition to the new Farm Family Restart Scheme when it commences on 1 December 1997.

Madam President, this bill is an essential element in the government's rural policy platform. It is closely linked to other measures in the Agriculture—Advancing Australia package which will help to maximise the sector's contribution to the economic, social and environmental well‐being of the nation, especially rural and regional communities.
I commend the bill to honourable senators.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first sitting day in 1998, in accordance with standing order 111.

TITLE.XREF: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 22 October.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. This memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 23 October 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 4), before item 1, insert:
Insert:
(1F) Where, as a result of a notification of a dispute, an organisation or an associated body is affected by action under a State law which results in the loss of:

TAB.TAB: (a) respondency to existing State awards or agreements to which the organisation or an associated body was a party; and/or
(b) the right to cover members under the eligibility rules of that organisation or an associated body;

then notwithstanding section 111AAA, the Commission must proceed to deal with the application as quickly as it can, and if the Commission considers it appropriate, make an interim award for an interim period.

SPEECH.PARA: (1G) For the purposes of this section, associated body has the same meaning as in Schedule 4.

The amendments we will have before us throughout this debate are primarily technical. As I outlined in my speech on the second reading, I have adopted the approach of accepting, by and large, a technical approach, unless issues have emerged subsequent to the passage of the act which attempt to put the act into some difficulty in any area or unless issues are fundamental to the nature of industrial relations as it is at present. My view, as the Senate well knows, is that we should seek to ensure that the new act has time to be bedded down and not succumb to the drive, particularly from the right, to advance the cause of major reduction in the provisions available to both workers and employers through the act.

However, my amendment No. 1 refers to a situation which has arisen in Western Australia which goes against the fundamental principles and purpose of the act. The act says that workers and employers and their respective organisations should be free to choose the jurisdiction under which they seek to operate either at the state or the federal level. It also implies that anyone doing so should be free to do so; in other words, they should not be constrained by pursuing their legal and legitimate activities.

Minister Graham Kierath, a Liberal member of the coalition government in Western Australia, introduced a law in Western Australia which was known as the second wave of reforms. He shovelled it through the upper house—and that is probably a polite term—before the members of that upper house changed on 22 May this year consequent to the Western Australian election on 16 December 1996. The change in the upper house would have meant that he would have been unable to get through some of the more hairy‐chested and draconian measures he put forward.

One of the measures Minister Kierath put forward which has in fact passed into law in Western Australia is that, in the event of a workers' or an employers' organisation making an application to move into the federal system through a process—and the process has a number of steps—that ends with the minister, it is possible for that organisation's ability to operate under the state system to be ended whilst the application is being considered; in other words, the organisation cannot continue to maintain its state awards or respond to the nature of the agreement or negotiate improvements to the state awards. Frankly, we think that is wrong. We think that goes against the morality of the act and against freedom of choice and the ability to go about ones business in industrial relations, which should be the right of every worker, every employer and every organisation that relates to them.

BREAK.PARA: The Senate and those who are experienced in the issues of union operations would be aware that it can take many years to move from a state to a federal jurisdiction. I have been told that it can take as long as four years. So you hardly want to have no ability to care for your workers under the state system in the meantime. This amendment seeks to fast‐track the ability of the Industrial Relations Commission to consider an application to move from the state to the federal system where respondency to existing state awards or agreements has been impaired as a result of state law. To do that the commission would have to evade somewhat the restrictive nature of section 111AAA.

We would never dream of proposing that except in circumstances where people's rights have been unfairly and unnecessarily constrained, as they have in the Western Australian situation. Of course, that disease could spread to other governments and therefore we have not particularised this amendment to Western Australia. But we do think it is appropriate. We do not think it is an ideological issue or a philosophical issue. We think it is an issue of fairness and morality. In fact it is an attempt to make sure that the provisions we have within the bill about freedom of choice are respected by state governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the opposition agrees with the amendment proposed by Senator Murray and we will not be opposing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pass a few comments in respect of this amendment proposed by Senator Murray and to indicate my thoughts that it is a most worthwhile amendment on his part. In a former life I was involved with a major trade union in Western Australia which was in the process of engaging in a range of negotiations on behalf of its members with a range of firms, some national, some medium sized and some local. A range of those firms, for reasons relating to business practice, indicated that they wished to switch their method of operation from regulation under the Western Australian state system and the Western Australian common rule awards that applied in that state, to the federal system, either under federal awards or, as it was in those days, federal certified agreements. We did not have a particular concern whether an award agreement or enterprise bargain was regulated either in the federal system or the state system.

SPEECH.PARA: The more recent amendments passed by the Court government in Western Australia have had the effect that, where trade unions negotiate enterprise bargaining agreements or certified agreements, whatever they are currently called, with employers and seek to have them regulated under the law in the federal system, the union that does that, and that shifts its members by consent or through the arbitral process out of the state system to the federal system, can be penalised for doing so.

Senator Murray indicated he thought it was an issue of correctness or right or wrong, and not so much an ideological or philosophical issue. I would disagree with him on that point. The effect was that trade unions and employers who negotiated agreements that suited their mutual and joint interests to change the system of regulation from either federal to state or from state to federal, as was the case from time to time, were punished, notwithstanding the fact that they operated within their rules with the interests of their members as a priority and consistent with the interests of the particular firm or firms involved in that process.

Then, having achieved that purpose by agreement, the state system was changed to deny that union coverage of a former group of workers when they had consented to go into the federal system for their own purposes. This strikes me as being an ideological pursuit carried to the extreme. On occasion, that shift from federal to state or state to federal was pursued via arbitral process before an independent tribunal. All of the evidence was placed before the tribunal and it made a decision on merit, having regard to the sense or otherwise of the argument put forward by the respective organisations.

Again in that case, when that arbitral process was pursued, the government in that state passed laws that restricted the rights of that organisation to protect those members and other members under the state system. To the extent that Senator Murray's amendment seeks to overcome that evil, it is a most worthwhile endeavour as far as I am concerned and, as far as the opposition is concerned, it is worthy of support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is opposed to this amendment. We are quite sure, and I am sure Senator Murray would not deny this, that it is designed purely to punish one state and to discriminate against one state's industrial laws, and that is the state of Western Australia where Senator Murray, Senator Bishop and I come from. We believe, firstly, it is inappropriate to include this sort of amendment in a technical bill. In any event, the Workplace Relations Act already requires the commission to deal with matters as quickly as practicable, and provision is made for the commission to make interim awards.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Bishop said that it was indeed a philosophical issue. I think Senator Murray tried to say it was not philosophically or ideologically driven but just a technical thing. If that is the case, Senator Murray, well technically, the commission is required to deal with matters as quickly as possible anyway. I think Senator Bishop is being more frank about this. It is an ideological and philosophical attack on the Western Australian government's industrial laws.

I am sure that Senator Bishop and Senator Murray share an ideological opposition to those industrial laws, but they are a matter for the state parliament of Western Australia. To seek to interfere, in what is, I think, a fairly obvious if not blatant attack on that state parliament's decision to pass those laws with what is clearly, as is even agreed by the ACTU, a technically amending bill—a tidying up bill; a bit of housekeeping—is entirely inappropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, I am attempting to draw the attention of the chamber to the moral issue here. For me, the moral issue is you should not punish someone for attempting to operate in one jurisdiction rather than another, and that is what the Western Australian government has done. Let us assume it was not an issue of industrial relations; let us assume you are punished for going to the Federal Court instead of the state Supreme Court, or you are punished for abiding by federal copyright laws instead of state business names laws. It is just wrong in principle; it is wrong morally. It is for that reason that I regard it as an issue of morality and not an issue of ideology.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Murray's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Ellison did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Kernot.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 2, page 4 (after line 4), before item 1, insert:
Add:
(4) Notwithstanding any other section in this Act, other than section 170ML, the Commission may make any orders it deems necessary to further the object of this Part.
(5) A person or organisation to whom an order under subsection (4) is expressed to apply must comply with the order.

This is a technical amendment. It has arisen as a result of a problem of interpretation and understanding which has emerged within the Industrial Relations Commission between the Department of Industrial Relations and the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. I say it is technical but, of course, I am aware of how important it is. It goes to an issue which is fairly fundamental. Accordingly, I will need to return to the message which I put across in my speech in the second reading debate which concerns this amendment. I referred to it as a material technical amendment, which is probably the best way I could describe it. It deals with the issue of collective bargaining.

We have always said that collective bargaining protects the weak and vulnerable in our society from those with strength. A key issue has always been the protection afforded to Australian workers and, I happen to believe, Australian employers as a result of Australia's long commitment and adherence to its international obligations under ILO conventions. Those ILO conventions—as Labor senators would know better than anyone—prefer collective bargaining over individual bargaining in areas where those who do the individual bargaining are in an inferior or a weakened bargaining situation. We all fought very hard over that last year and we did get as much of our international obligations back into that act as we felt we could.

We had several meetings with the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business on this particular issue last year. We were persuaded by the minister and his staff that the bill did indeed prefer collective bargaining over individual bargaining. In particular, the minister's office pointed to the fact that under section 170LA the Industrial Relations Commission has a positive duty to facilitate the making of collective certified agreements.

I received advice that it is important to appreciate that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will have extensive conciliation powers to facilitate the negation of certified agreements which may include, for example, ordering the parties to attend compulsory conferences. Indeed, under section 170LA, the AIRC is required, as far as practicable, to perform its function in such a way as to facilitate the making of certified agreements.

In dealing with a situation where employers want to bargain individually and workers want to bargain collectively—in other words, where there is a difference in opinion as to how they want to be dealt with—I was further advised that such employees would have a number of options open to them. In particular, they could initiate a bargaining period for a certified agreement and they could also appoint their union as their bargaining agent. If the employer still wished to negotiate an agreement he would have to deal with the union. The union and the employer would then have to negotiate whether any agreement was to be in the form of a collective AWA or a certified agreement. The employees would be able to act collectively and would be able to take protective action. They would also seek the assistance of the Industrial Relations Commission to facilitate a certified agreement if they wished.

I would have thought that we in the Senate were absolutely in support of employees and employers pursuing individual agreements where both are willing and both feel that this is the best course. I am not supportive of a situation where workers in an inferior bargaining position who wish to bargain collectively would be obliged or forced to take up individual agreements. It is plainly their right to be able to negotiate collectively, and it is a right that has been recognised throughout the civilised world. That is how we understood the bill would operate. We understood that workers could not be forced—and I use the word `forced' so you understand my meaning—by their employers to bargain individually.

What happened in the Hunter region is that the Industrial Relations Commission essentially said to us all, `We know that you have 170LA. We think we know what that says, but we are uncertain as to the intention of government.' The government took, in our view, a harder line than that which we had understood to be the case.

It is our intention, through this material technical amendment, to make it clear that where a third party is required—throughout our law it is consistent that a third party is frequently required; we take it as axiomatic that if there is a problem you can refer to an arbitrator, a court or a conciliator and that is throughout the basis of our contractual dealings—it should be axiomatic that the Industrial Relations Commission, with the constitutional imperative that it enjoys, feel obliged and able, in terms of the act and particularly in terms of 170LA, to enter a dispute where the issue is incapable of resolution in any other way. The government may not agree with that interpretation, but it was certainly the interpretation that we believed, and I have been at pains to be very particular with the wording that I have used.

We propose a technical amendment to give the commission the power to make any orders that it deems necessary to fulfil its statutory obligations to facilitate the making of certified agreements and collective bargaining where the workers or the employers need that device activated. Such orders would not extend to stopping protected action, as the act clearly intended such action to be protected, but such orders could extend to prevent the predatory offering or approval of AWAs, for example, or other punitive action by employers against unions and workers wanting and needing to bargain collectively. That is the nub of our case. I hope the Senate will recognise that it is a material technical amendment designed to give a message to the AIRC that, when other means are not before it, it does have the powers it should.

(aa) any person first employed less than 14 days before approval is given either has, or has ready access to, the agreement, in writing, at least 7 days before the approval is given, unless the Commission determines a lesser period; and
(2) Schedule 2, item 2, page 4, (lines 21 to 23), omit paragraph (b), substitute:

(b) 7 days' notice, in writing, of intention to make the agreement is given to every person first employed after the first notice is given under paragraph (a), unless the Commission determines a lesser period; and
(3) Schedule 2, item 3, page 4, (lines 31 to 33), omit paragraph (aa), substitute:

(aa) any person first employed less than 14 days before approval is given either has, or has ready access to, the agreement, in writing, at least 7 days before the approval is given, unless the Commission determines a lesser period; and

We believe the government's amendment will affect the rights of new employees in the workplace who are considering whether or not they will sign up to a certified agreement. We believe the government's amendment will effectively reduce the period for those employees who commence work after the 14 days begins. It is aimed at ensuring that the 14-day time period does not have to recommence if a new employee begins work during that time.

Our concern with regard to this first amendment is that a lesser period should occur as a right; for example, at least seven days, unless the commission determines otherwise. We believe that a new employee coming on does need to have a reasonable amount of time to consider a certified agreement, which has the potential to affect them for years with regard to their working environment and the wages and conditions that they work under. However, we are sympathetic to the position that we do not want the timeline pushed out too far, but there is the capacity for the commission to approve a lesser period with regard to this.

To sum up, whilst we do have some sympathy with the government's position, we do see that in extreme circumstances workers may, in fact, have very short periods to determine whether or not they are prepared to sign up to a certified agreement. We think seven days is reasonable. As I said, if there is any suggestion of vexatious or frivolous activity, then the AIRC does have the capacity to come in and say, `No, this is not appropriate.' However, we do not believe that the government's amendment is fair in terms of new workers coming on during that period. So, again, it is an attempt on our part to ensure that people are given adequate time to determine the effect of a certified agreement on them and to give their concurrence or otherwise to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Greens (WA) will be supporting opposition amendments Nos 1 to 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 5 (after line 19), at the end of Schedule 2, add:

TAB.TAB: Omit "order the employer", substitute "make the following orders".

PARA.TAB: Add:
; and (c) any other order that the Court thinks necessary to remedy the effect of the contravention; and

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment deals with the matter of protected industrial action. Section 170NH provides the orders a court can make when an employer terminates an employee for engag ing in protected industrial action. The orders that can be made are more limited than those that the court can make when employees are terminated for any other unlawful reasons and these are provided by section 170CR.

Our concern is that the current situation is unfair. It is anomalous in that we have different provisions for workers engaged in action which is protected and for workers engaged in other more general circumstances. So there is an inherent anomaly with regard to this. This amendment attempts to address that inherent anomaly and ensures that the available remedies apply equally in both cases. In particular, this amendment will provide that, in the case of an employee terminated for engaging in protected industrial action, the court will be able to make any other order it thinks appropriate and any other consequential order.
So we believe that situation is anomalous. We do not believe workers engaged in protected industrial action should be treated any differently. This amendment goes to addressing that anomaly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the chamber that we accept opposition amendment No. 4 as a technical amendment. We think these dismissals are in the nature of unlawful, rather than unfair, dismissals. —I rise to indicate that the Greens (WA) will be supporting opposition amendment No. 4.

We say that section 170NH provides for the Federal Court to order reinstatement and compensation where an employee is dismissed or injured in his or her employment for taking protected industrial action. We, therefore, say that there is no need for any other remedies to be provided for. The court already has inherent powers to make orders to give effect to its decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

We regard this attempt by the government particularly seriously. From our perspective, it is very important that a federal award system be used. Secondly, in the very few instances where there are no federal awards, there are similar awards which could apply.

We have serious difficulties and differences across the various states in relation to state awards. We believe it is appropriate to provide the federal benchmark. At this point, I indicate that the opposition believes there is already a situation where the no disadvantage test breaches the government's pre‐election commitment that no worker would be worse off. That situation is occurring where the Employment Advocate is ignoring, in terms of the application of the no disadvantage test, areas where there are agreements, and areas where workers are operating under minimum awards rather than paid rates awards.

From our perspective, there is already a serious divide with regard to what workers were getting under the old industrial relations system and the way that the no disadvantage test is being applied by the Employment Advocate. There is already a gap emerging with regard to wage differentials, and we are concerned that that not be exacerbated by bringing another variable into the equation—that is, state awards.

As I have said, there is a large variation across the states in relation to state awards and we believe that it is important that the same benchmark be applied, which is the relevant federal award. Obviously, where that does not exist, there are umpteen federal awards which, in those rare circumstances where there is not one, can be applied and the equity principle maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mackay has made a very lucid point. We are supposed to be running a federal system. If you go back to the founding fathers—there being no founding mothers in those days—
—They didn't make the history books anyway.

—No, they did not make the history books as they would have done these days. That shows, at least, that we have come a long way in 100 years. But I am not too sure that we have come a long way on this particular point, because the idea was that the federal system would work just as the words suggest—as a federal system. Here, where we have state awards forming the standard, we really are going back by using a federal constitution to entrench, as it were, the state system, because the states individually are now able to set the standards for how a person in that particular state will operate.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Mackay says, different rates of remuneration and different conditions will apply. That certainly is against the idea of there having to be an interstate dispute to found an arbitration system. Of course, we rely on international conventions, corporations powers and things like that—I understand that. But the general spirit of how industrial relations was conducted in the founding fathers' era has passed. Is that a good thing? I do not think it is a good thing because states can bid against each other to reduce wages and conditions in an attempt to attract businesses to them. I think there is a real danger in this, and I think Senator Mackay is absolutely right in her approach to this.

This is just a minor amendment to the government's amendment to count the number of days from when the employee is given notice of a decision by management to mass retrench workers. We have added the words `the employee is given notice of'. In other words, we want to prevent managers keeping the decision secret from workers for three weeks to prevent relief under the act. They must be given notice; that is obviously the need. Accordingly, it is a technical amendment, but it is important.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Schedule 5, item 1, page 11 (lines 5 to 11), TO BE OPPOSED .
(14) Schedule 5, items 2 and 3, page 11 (lines 12 to 18), TO BE OPPOSED .

(16) Schedule 5, item 7, page 12 (lines 13 and 14), TO BE OPPOSED .
(17) Schedule 5, item 8, page 12 (lines 15 to 21), TO BE OPPOSED .

The effect of the government amendments is that employees under federal awards, certified agreements and AWAs will not be able to access state provisions in laws or awards, such as severance pay or redundancy . We oppose the time limit imposition of 21 days on a union applying to the AIRC on behalf of an employee over an employer's decision to sack a worker.

While accepting government items 4 and 5, we are opposing the rest for the following reasons. Firstly, from our perspective, the government is keeping workers' rights as confined as possible. The government is concerned that workers may be able to access beneficial state legislation awards on termination, and obviously that is something that the government would not support. We believe it is important that workers have access to either jurisdiction, and that their access not be restricted.

Secondly, with regard to the time limit imposed on a union, we believe, as I indicated before, that the amendment's effect is too restrictive. Currently, there is no time limit imposed on unions. I would like to indicate that there are a number of reasons why we believe that 21 days is too restrictive. You may have a situation where a large number of employees are terminated at once, which is quite possible; it has happened many times in Australia's current industrial climate. In fact, quite recently 1,000 workers were terminated. Twenty‐one days is simply not adequate for the preparation of a case as to whether the termination was unjust, harsh and unlawful. Also, you may have a situation wherein a worker who is a member of a union is sacked, but may not be aware of his or her rights in that respect. It may take some time for that person to say, `Well, look, I believe in retrospect, having thought about this, that I was terminated unjustly. I'd better get down to the union to see whether I've got a case.' This can often take in excess of 21 days. I think Arco is probably the best recent example of the situation with mass sackings. Given the industrial relations climate, we are likely to see more en masse sackings occurring.

Each unfair dismissal has to be filed individually, and there is currently no capacity for what could be termed `class actions'. Here again, we believe that 21 days is too limiting because of the procedural aspects surrounding applications.

BREAK.PARA: I reiterate the difficulties that arise when workers are sacked en masse, quite often for different reasons—it may not be for reasons such as inadequate productivity or a diminution in the bottom line in terms of profit, but it could be for different reasons. Quite often—as Senator Cooney would be aware—these are very complex cases in terms of establishing whether it is harsh, unjust and unlawful. We believe that the current provisions should apply with regard to no time limit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mackay has convinced me yet again. In a sense, this is not an issue of industrial law but an issue of common law. The basis for employment is contracts between the employer and the employee—workplace contracts. Normally, the time limit that applies to a breach of contract is six years. Why 21 days has been chosen in what really is a common law action is a very interesting question. I do not know where the 21 days comes from.

SPEECH.PARA: This provision is aimed, I think, at getting more summonses or writs issued. If you are a lawyer, what you ought to do as soon as anybody is sacked is simply issue a writ to make sure that you are not sued for negligence. Why there would be a provision like this seems extraordinary, as Senator Mackay said.

If you are a worker, you would have firstly to recover from the shock, and then get proper advice and proceedings taken. You would probably be better off if you were in a union because you would go straight to the union and it would get in touch with its solicitors. Even though workers in a union would be disadvantaged, they would not be as disadvantaged as workers who did not have a union to look to and who were trying to recover from the very nasty shock of being sacked. Anybody who has lost preselection or lost an election would certainly know that that does not do much for the morale.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes you don't get 21 days.

—True! I have no doubt that the government is determined to do this and, as Senator Campbell has often said, the government has a different philosophy from ours. We understand that, but this does not seem to fit in with the philosophy that the government has adopted that an agreement ought to be reached between employer and employee, that they should be able to arrange their own terms, and that it should be done according to common law. On this issue, there is a complete setting aside of what would normally operate as a statute of limitations.
—I rise to indicate that the Greens (WA) will be supporting the opposition on these amendments.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I have vacillated a little on these amendments, I am afraid, because I wanted to hear the arguments of the opposition. I have struggled with it a bit because I thought the original government technical amendments were in order. However, I have listened to the debate. I still have some real nagging doubts that you have identified, but because I cannot put my finger on a particular clause or phrase, I think I will stay with the government on this one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to Senator Mackay, I cannot understand why the bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: An application under subsection (2) or (4) must be lodged within 21 days after the decision to terminate the employee's employment is made.

As a matter of reality—if not as a matter of philosophy—that is a very harsh provision. A person who has had his position terminated will at times be in a state of shock. It is a terrible thing to lose your job and be put in a position where you have to go home to your family and say, `Look, no income is going to be coming in for a while. We have to apply for social security and all that that amounts to.'

Within the 21 days, when you are going through that shock, for a person to be expected to act rationally is absolutely incredible. When you are put at a disadvantage, when you are put onto the street, in effect, you are not in any condition to think about things. Yet, in that condition, you are expected to make an informed decision to see a solicitor and put in an application.

BREAK.PARA: Why is it that, if there is a breach of contract between a bank and a big business house, that breach of contract is alive, in terms of taking action upon it, for six years? People who have legal advice and accounting advice—all the expert advice they need—have still got six years within which to make a decision on whether or not to take proceedings. However, a worker, usually someone on reasonably low wages, who has no legal advice, no accountant and no experience must get that application in within 21 days, and if the person does not, that is the end of him.

This measure seems to me to be quite extraordinary. It is against the very common law that we are supposed to be operating under and against this new business of bargaining where the marketplace decides. If the marketplace decides, why shouldn't the time limitations that generally operate in the marketplace—that is, six years—operate for the worker? The biggest business house in Australia has six years to vindicate what it thinks is a breach of contract but a person who is vulnerable, like a sacked worker, will be confined to 21 days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Cooney's arguments would be fine if they actually applied to what is a very narrow set of matters to which this amendment applies in relation to the 21‐day time limit. It is a technical amendment that seeks to bring the provisions in line with all the other provisions on the termination of employment. The provision is also made for an extension of time to be granted in appropriate cases.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that the technical amendment we have moved in relation to the 21‐day time limit goes to a very narrow set of matters. For example, it relates to section 170CL in relation an employer notifying the Commonwealth Employment Service of terminations. The matters that Senator Cooney raised are not even addressed by this amendment or by Senator Mackay's opposition to the amendment. To achieve what Senator Cooney wants to achieve you would have to go back and basically amend all of the provisions which relate to termination of employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what Senator Campbell is saying and it has force in the context in which he is saying it. When you go on to say that there are provisions right throughout this act that do that sort of thing I think that is absolutely right. It is only when you start arguing and listening to somebody like Senator Mackay that you suddenly realise how flawed all these provisions in the legislation are that will confine working people in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to put what we have been talking about into context, the minister indicates that this is a narrow category but the average person does not know what category they are in. They have no idea, and generally they have no access to legal advice. People are telling us on a day-to-day basis that people have to voluntarily provide advice to people in these situations because they are left without knowing where to go. That is more and more the case with what the government is doing, trying to isolate people in the workplace.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Cooney has been indicating as a principle is quite right. We have to put it in the context of people knowing or not knowing what category they are in or who on earth they can go to. As Senator Cooney indicated, if you asked the average person when they are in that situation and in a state of shock, they would not know. If they are in a work force that is hostile to unions—that is, the employer does not much like unions—there will not be much access to a support base. For the protection of workers you have to think of potential medium or worst case scenarios. Believe me, in Western Australia there are quite a few of those.
