Our amendment removes the first requirement and ensures that a union can gain right of entry to see any union member or potential union member. Our concerns there are obvious. We believe that the right of entry should prevail in those circumstances. We believe that this is an appropriate place to make that point. We seek support for this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Mackay for her clarification. The government does not regard this as a technical amendment. It really goes to one of the core issues of the Workplace Relations Act. It tries to re-open that issue. It seeks to expand a union's right of entry to workplaces where they have no award coverage. The government will oppose this amendment.

—I am advised that under the Labor Party's Industrial Relations Act right of entry was regulated by awards. In other words, the right was based on award coverage. I think the parliamentary secretary is right. This is like our very first amendment. This is not technical. This amendment would extend the intention beyond the scope that Labor's law originally provided. Accordingly, we will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the question of the right of entry, I think that one of the problems is the concept that is behind it—that is, that the union and the union official is going into the workplace to cause trouble or at least to provide a focus for friction. I think that the issue that Senator Mackay has raised is a central one. Senator Murray says that it is not a technical issue, which is true, and therefore it should not be discussed—that is probably putting it too strongly—and allowed to go through. Senator Mackay has raised an issue which needs to be looked at by this parliament at this stage. The nature of the union and its relationship with employees ought to be looked at.

SPEECH.PARA: The conduct of the union and its officials is underpinned by the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and the various acts which came before it. The union is an organisation elected by its members. Its officials are subject to the ballot box every four years. I think that has to be taken into account when you look at this particular problem.

It would seem to me that—where the idea is for the work force and management to bring flexibility and choice into the workplace—an organisation which is freely and democratically elected every four years by a group of workers ought to be taken into account. It is only right and proper that any organisation which goes about its functions in a lawful, reasonable and measured way ought to be able to recruit and to see how workplaces are operating. If they try to cause disturbances or break the law then, certainly, they should not be allowed into the workplace.

In the great British traditions that underpin this nation—and the concept of the union, the concept of the free association of people who work, is a very English concept—why shouldn't a freely elected body be able to take its proper place in society and go in at an appropriate time and in an appropriate way and speak to people who are in the workplace? The unions can put forward to workers the proposition that they might find it useful to be part of an organisation that tries to get fairness in wages and conditions—not only in wages and conditions but in the way the system operates. I think more and more the position is clear that the union movement wants to see a productive and a forward thinking industry in Australia. It is a matter of cooperation. Their function is also to see that those people are properly protected by a system that they elect.

I think it is a real tragedy that the perception in industrial relations is that the union is there to simply aggravate the situation. I think it is the same sort of false concept we would have if we thought that employer organisations were simply there to grind down workers and to make difficulties. We would not have that concept at all. We would be saying that these organisations are there to see that industry is not only run profitably and that production is at its highest level but also that the workplace is a socially just, culturally enriching place. That deserves cooperation. I have great respect for Senator Murray, but this provision that Senator Mackay wants to remove is one that really poisons the climate in which industrial relations should be properly carried out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to follow up on a matter that was mentioned by Senator Murray in relation to this amendment moved by the opposition. Senator Murray indicated that he thought it was an extension of what the previous Labor government industrial relations legislation allowed. He mentioned that it used to be in awards. It is not in the 20 allowable matters, so there is no right of entry under awards, and there will be no right of entry under awards with what got pushed through under the workplace relations bill. So, no, it is not something in addition to what existed before; it is basically saying it is fair enough to say that somehow or other this right ought to exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Time and time again we have heard the government come in and use membership levels of unions to bash workers over the head. For instance, they say, `Look, if there are fewer people joining unions, there is something wrong with the union movement.' The government are actually helping to create the situation where people do not have access to information about what their entitlements are, what unions there are and how easily they can join a union. They are actually creating that situation by not allowing union representatives into the workplace without a very difficult process. We have already heard that, in Western Australia at least, there are a lot of issues about workers' health and safety. That lack of access to information puts workers at risk. It puts their lives at risk. People have died in Western Australia because of the inability of unions to have guaranteed access to the workplace.

So it is not a situation where the opposition are asking for something over and above what was in the Labor government legislation. They are trying to provide that right for workers to have access to that information that they otherwise would not get. Remember, we just heard the opposition say, in relation to withdrawals from amalgamated organisations, that they believe workers have a right to information. Yes, they do. On issues to do with their workplace, one of the best ways to make sure they have access to their rights is if the unions are able to go into the workplace and tell them what they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to acknowledge the contributions by Senator Cooney and Senator Margetts because I think they are absolutely relevant. Perhaps I could put it in this way to the government and to the Democrats: if you join a union, surely you have the right for that union to provide a service to you. That is really what we are on about. To use an example that the government may be able to relate to, it is a bit like subscribing to a magazine and the government coming in and saying, `You can't have that magazine.' In fact, it is a type of market intervention, dare I say it, by the government in terms of the capacity of those workers who choose to belong to a union. Workers should be able to access that service and have a union representative come in when they wish—to put it in parlance that the government may be able to understand.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important to say to Senator Murray that I endorse the comments made by Senator Cooney and Senator Margetts but, if somebody chooses to belong to a union, why shouldn't they have the right to have that union come and see them to provide the sort of service that they require? Senator Margetts, quite correctly, gave examples in terms of occupational health and safety. Under this government's provision, if a union member has difficulty with an occupational health and safety matter at work, unless the appropriate award coverage is there, that union would not be able to come in, see that union member, examine the site and determine whether or not there was an occupational health and safety difficulty there.

As I said, to use parlance that the government can relate to, we do not believe this government should be seeking to intervene in the union market. We believe there should be free access between a union and the people who wish to join that union. We encourage the Democrats to rethink their position. As indicated, we will be dividing on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

Item 4, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will oppose item 1 of schedule 9 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (26) Schedule 9, item 1, page 23 (lines 5 and 6), TO BE OPPOSED .
We are concerned about this from the perspective of a state enterprise agreement being able to override a federal award only if the agreement does not disadvantage the worker relevant to the award.

The other matters are tidying up of the act. Our position is that the status quo should remain. Our principal position is similar to arguments we have advanced in other amendments—that is, we are concerned about the diminution of the no disadvantage test in terms of state awards, particularly in states like Western Australia, which has an appalling IR track record which Senator Murray and Senator Bishop spoke about earlier.

We are already concerned about the diminution of the application of the no disadvantage test in that, as I articulated previously, we have a situation whereby the Employment Advocate, in terms of applying the no disadvantage test on AWAs, is taking minimum rates awards and not recognising pre‐existing enterprise agreements or pre‐existing agreements on the work site. Obviously with paid rates awards there is a bit of a difference, although that will decrease over time in terms of the government's action on paid rates awards.

We are already concerned that the no disadvantage test is being compromised. We do not want it further compromised by going to the lowest industrial relations common denominator like the Western Australian industrial jurisdiction, which we believe is appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will join the Labor Party in opposing this amendment. In our agreement with the government last year, the wording agreed was that state employment agreements would be compared with the relevant award. If workers were operating under a federal award, the agreement would not rule out using the federal award as a benchmark. I think that what the government is proposing stretches `technical' a little further than we expect, so we will support the opposition at this stage.

—I have to say that this whole bill is wide ranging, although the government has pushed it as a series of technical amendments. Their arguments that they are just little weeny technical amendments in the bill itself do not necessarily hold water. I am prepared to support the opposition in relation to this issue. Certainly, as a senator from Western Australia I believe that the workers, the ordinary people, in Western Australia do need this support from the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not said that these are teensy weensy sort of minor technical amendments. They really are technical in nature but they do have an important effect. I think Senator Cooney quoted earlier from the second reading speech saying that they will obviously add to the Workplace Relations Act and the new industrial relations culture that this government is trying to create through this legislation and particularly the amendments we are debating today.

SPEECH.PARA: So although they are ostensibly technical amendments, they do seek to make a workplace relations scheme work more effectively and therefore deliver the policy benefits that flow from that. You can have a debate about Western Australia if you want, but one of the things that are indisputable about Western Australia is that it has one of the best employment generation records of any of the states of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —No thanks to Graham Kierath.
—Maybe thanks to Richard Court and a few other people, Senator Murray. I acknowledge that you are nodding there. I am sure the Premier will be happy to have your support in that regard—and surprised.

BREAK.PARA: The amendment is indeed, though, a technical amendment. It is designed to clarify the existing provision. The omission of the government's amendment, which now seems likely with the support for the Labor Party by the Democrats, will simply make the existing provision more confusing for the parties concerned.

Under the provision as it now stands, the reference to `relevant award' can only mean a relevant state award. The provision is about the criteria applied by state tribunals in relation to the approval of state agreements. For the approval of state agreements by state tribunals, the relevant award benchmark will necessarily be a state award. So, in summary, the government regards this as an important provision and believes that the opposition amendment will make a significantly negative impact on the scheme which the government supports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the committee, I will be supporting the opposition's amendment which in effect removes schedule 9.

SPEECH.PARA: Item 1 not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 9, page 23 (after line 12), after item 2, insert:

PARA.TAB: Add:

(4) For the purposes of this section, an employee is not deemed to be engaged in industrial action where the employee is fully engaged during his or her ordinary hours of work in performing work directed by the employer, notwithstanding that the employee may refuse to perform some other aspect of work required by the employer.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two amendments that honourable senators will see that deal with aspects of the issue dealt with in my amendment (1) on page 719. This revisits an area which was debated in the consideration of the 1996 industrial relations legislation, when I pointed out to the Senate that `industrial action', as written in the bill, may mean almost anything. At the time, initially, we were prepared to give the government the benefit of the doubt and believe that they did not mean that employers would be forced to dock the pay of workers for any possible sort of action, including work‐to‐rule.

Sometimes, if something is dangerous, employees try to indicate there is a problem. Sometimes something additional to employees' paid duties may be required to be undertaken—for instance, teachers may choose not to agree to take on excursions which are in effect in their own time. Ironically, those instances can be regarded as industrial action. And there are all sorts of other issues.

Pretty soon the government found that they had a monstrous, unenforceable situation. Most of us have received letters saying, `If your staff ever attend meetings you must tell us so that we can dock their pay.' What a monstrous assertion! What a dreadful thing to happen in 1997!

At the time of that debate I pointed out this consequence to the Senate, and in particular I pointed it out to Senator Murray who represented the Australian Democrats, as he is here today in this debate. Like most people in the Senate, he did not realise that that was what the government had in mind. As I said, initially I gave the government the benefit of the doubt. I thought that maybe it was an unintended consequence, but, during the course of the debate, it became clear that it was an intended consequence on the part of the government—they meant any form of industrial action.

During the debate it was explained that the reason for that very broad definition of industrial action being put into industrial relations legislation in the first place was not to try to beat workers over the head, that it was actually there to make sure that there could be early and relevant intervention so that issues could be taken to a tribunal before they became full‐scale industrial action. That was said to be the reason for the broad definition. But the government took that broad definition and used it as a means of beating workers over the head, and I believe that was a very draconian step.

The government—as have we—have found this to be an unworkable situation. At one stage we know that the entire public sector was stopping for one or two minutes at a time to see how on earth the government could enforce this situation. I guess Senator Murray has tried to redeem himself with his amendment (10), but I do not believe it goes far enough. Basically, it says:
For the purpose of this Part, industrial action does not include action by employees that is authorised, agreed to or accepted by the employer of the employees.

That is a good point inasmuch as it was noted in the debate that there could be a ridiculous situation where an employer could be quite happy with the industrial action that was being taken, or quite at ease with the industrial action that was being taken for various reasons, therefore they should not be forced to dock the pay of their workers for action with which they either agreed or did not object to.

However, according to basic human rights principles, if you start defining industrial action according to whether or not an employer likes it, you have a very silly situation. So, whilst I will certainly agree to support Senator Murray's amendment, I will also add those aspects which in effect are included in work‐to‐rule—that is to say:

. . . an employee is not deemed to be engaged in industrial action where the employee is fully engaged during his or her ordinary hours of work in performing work directed by the employer, notwithstanding that the employee may refuse to perform some other aspect of work required by the employer.

This will cover minor work‐to‐rule disputes involving people such as nurses and teachers and people who believe they have a social responsibility to the people they serve. They are often people who work under very straitened conditions, who have had their pay and conditions kept down in many instances, but who want to make sure that their message is getting across without creating a problem for the people to whom they are dedicated. To start requiring that people's pay be docked in those kinds of situations I think is a very dangerous thing.

It is very unlikely that, say, the Western Australian education department will authorise a work‐to‐rule situation—in fact, it is ridicu lous to suggest that they will. So I argue that work‐to‐rule situations and those kinds of non‐strike actions should not be included in the section regarding the compulsory docking of pay because, in the end, I think it will become unworkable. Perhaps we will end up with more industrial action rather than less.

TITLE.XREF: NATIONAL ROAD TRANSPORT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 October, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill 1997 and commends it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill 1997 basically brings about an extension of the National Road Transport Commission, or NRTC, for another year to allow a new agreement between the states and the Commonwealth to be finalised. The Greens (WA) have no objection to this bill, but I wish to speak about the shape of the final agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Road transport is an issue which has major implications for greenhouse gas emissions. Roughly one‐third of our anthropogenic or person‐made CO2 emissions come from road transport. The approach to transport policy in this country will have major implications for our ability to effectively address the greenhouse problem, without imposing other unnecessary costs. The failure to have adequately addressed this issue in the last decade will already impose substantial costs. The NRTC has the job of road transport reform. It seeks to provide a coordinated national approach to road transport. It is the natural organisation to address the reform of road transport to take account of the environ mental implications of such transport. I would think the world would be looking to Australia to address some of these situations, as road transport is such a major issue.

Fuel supply is also an important question in the context of road transport planning. We have an acknowledged decline in oil supplies—even acknowledged by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer). We are reaching the halfway point of known world oil supplies. We are already at the point where production exceeds the rate of discovery. We know that from here on in we are reaching the more expensive range of oil sources. That means that within the next 10 years the price of oil will increase exceedingly. Even for purely selfish economic reasons we should be planning to deal with these issues.

We will see an increase in the marginal cost of oil and need to start planning for the reality now. That marginal cost of producing the next barrel of oil is going to increase quite substantially. I trust the National Road Transport Commission will consider these two important issues in the context of their current review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contribution and commend the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Minister, what is the government's reaction to President Clinton's announcement of the United States greenhouse gas emission target? Does Australia support the United States announcement, and does Australia share the United States view of the role of the developing countries in the climate change negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The United States has added a further position to the negotiating table overnight. I think that is a helpful contribution to the debate in the lead‐up to Kyoto. What the United States has done is to suggest an appropriate target for the United States. It is interesting that what it has done is to select a target that reflects the particular national circumstances of the United States. In other words, it has nominated a figure that it believes can be achieved, consistent with what might be described as adopting sensible domestic practices providing a certain amount of incentive, providing a certain opportunity for domestic reform and providing a certain amount of encouragement for domestic industry in particular.

ANSWER.PARA: That is very much along the same lines as the Australian approach to this debate. Australia has always said that we as a country should make a reasonable contribution, one that can contribute to a better global outcome, but that it also should be consistent with our national circumstances.

It is interesting that we now have from the majors three different positions on the table: the position of Europe, the position of Japan, and now that of the United States. They all substantially differ, but they all in some ways reflect what can be achieved by the economies that they represent. Australia's position, of course, will be different again, and we hope to be able to release that figure as soon as possible.

There is no doubt that, if we were to apply the United States' suggested figure to our country, the consequence would be very significant economic sacrifice and the loss of a large number of jobs. That is why that figure would not be a sensible figure for Australia to accept. Obviously, this government has made it clear from the start that we want to be part of a good global outcome, we want Australia to accept its fair share of the burden, but we are not going to sacrifice Australian jobs to achieve that outcome.

There were a lot of things in the Clinton speech which were helpful to the debate and were certainly not inconsistent with the points that we have been making. The issues of the science, the importance of the issue, the need for a global response are all things that we have been saying. The need for flexibility in implementation is something that we agree with. The need to engage developing countries within the solution is obviously essential if you are going to achieve an effective global outcome. The language of President Clinton was that it required `meaningful participation by developing countries', which is very much in accordance with our own views.

His preference for market solutions over regulatory solutions to maximise the potential outcome is along the lines of our position. He said that this was a challenge for the whole of the community and not just for governments. In fact, he adopted something, Senator Parer, very close to our own greenhouse challenge program in relation to domestic industry in the United States, and it is good to see that that is being taken up.

President Clinton called for reform of the electricity market in the United States; and we are well advanced on that in our own country. He called for more effective energy usage by the US government; and we are going down the same lines in that regard. Madam President, when you look at the speech as a whole, there is a lot in there that is very similar to the direction that we have taken, and I think it is a helpful contribution to what is a very complex but vitally important negotiation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we are going beyond the pale. This whole disinformation campaign that has been going on in the Labor Party for some time now has reached the stage where they are scraping the bottom of the barrel. —Yes, as my colleague says, it speaks for itself, because if he understood, he wouldn't ask such a fatuous question. If a person is incapable of conducting anything for themselves, there is a legal friend in each state who does it for them. There is negotiation between the legal friend and the person who suffers from that incapacity on their admission, which is assessed by the aged care assessment team.

ANSWER.PARA: If, as Senator Forshaw says, I am not answering the question, I think my answer needed that preamble so that even he might understand that there is a legal friend, and an aged care assessment team makes the decision to approach the nursing home so that that person may be admitted. Any negotiation from then on goes between the nursing home proprietor and the legal friend or the relatives. If the person designated somebody to be their agent before they became incapacitated, then that agent negotiates. I think even Senator Forshaw should have been aware of that before he asked that fatuous question. Otherwise, he is wasting the time of the Senate during question time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Is there substantial public support for the government's one-third privatisation of Telstra? Is this level of support in line with worldwide trends in relation to privatisation? Are there any groups or individuals who remain out of step with these trends?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chapman is absolutely right. In fact, the response has been overwhelming. Something like 2.3 million Australians have already voted on this issue by registering an interest in the prospectus. If you look around the world you will find the same awareness on the part of governments that privatisation makes sense in all sorts of ways.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to draw particular attention to what has been happening in the UK where son of Thatcher has once again shown the way for the Labor Party in Australia, if they are interested. They are interested only in the style, not the substance. If you look at the substance you will see that the Deputy Prime Minister in the UK, who just happens to be in the left wing faction, has announced his confidence in a partial privatisation of the London Underground, which was announced by the tories during the election campaign. He said, `The public would expect us to look at a wide range of public‐private partnerships.'

If you surfed the Times net today you would have found the words `Blair to announce Labour's first sell off. The Prime Minister is to announce that the government is to sell its majority holding in the $1.5 billion Commonwealth Development Corporation'. He is also reported as saying that, although it is a change of approach for Labour, he is more interested in whether something works than in whether it is private or public. I can tell you that if he keeps this up we will be inviting him out here for the next election because he will be in a perfect position to tell you lot what privatisation is all about.

The biggest policy challenge of all faces the want to be member for Dickson, who has been swanning around, tripping over television cables, not facing up to the policy issues. Here is a very good one for her to face up to. The agreed draft policy for the Labor Party's 1998 national conference contains the following words—and, Senator Schacht, I would be interested if you would pay attention because I want to know whether you drafted it:
An ALP government would maintain majority public ownership of Telstra.

There you are. This lot who are out there kicking us to death are all of a sudden prepared to countenance the sale of another 16½ per cent; in other words, they no longer have this ideological prejudice. But where does former Senator Kernot stand? She was out there dying in a ditch on these issues. She hated the privatisation of Qantas. She bagged Labor on the Commonwealth Bank. She would not have a bar of Telstra. What is she going to do now?

Now that Labor has decided to take the money, is she going to simply roll over, junk her principles, sign on to this long overdue ideological sell‐out or is she going to tell Labor that that is not what she had in mind in switching over? She wanted to keep them honest, so called—honest right in the pockets of your preselectors, of course your clients who will not have a bar of it, who do not believe in privatisation at any cost because it will affect the public sector ownership and therefore the union membership.

Let us face up to the issue. Senator Schacht, did you or did you not draft this provision that an ALP government would maintain majority public ownership of Telstra? If you did, I congratulate you on seeing the light. If you do not know anything about it, which is much more likely, then you had better scurry out there and find out who is putting this forward without your knowledge. Let us see where your customers stand. Let us see if they have really rolled over, whether Mrs Kernot is going to come on board or whether this is simply a kite that you are flying.

Saying that it is only a majority does not mean anything anyway because that is what you said about the Commonwealth Bank. Remember, Ralph Willis even put out the prospectus saying that they would not go beyond selling off a majority interest in the Commonwealth Bank. Of course, once Labor was re‐elected in 1993 it did precisely the opposite. So do not believe for a moment, because we do not and the public does not, that a form of words like that will get you off the hook.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, the time for answering the question has terminated.
—That is an acknowledgment that we have been right all along, and I would like you and Mrs Kernot to face up to it straightaway.

—Madam President, on a point of order: this is about the 20th time this year that Senator Alston has defied you and continued talking when you called him to order. He is the only minister over there who does it. At least once this week you have had to stand to get him to finish his answer. If he cannot time his little prepared diatribes within four minutes, you have to sit him down, Madam President.
—Thank you, Senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, you told us very aggressively yesterday of your personal familiarity with the policy area of nursing homes. You would then be aware of the 47‐page model agreement that has just been drawn up for elderly Australians entering nursing homes. Given the obvious trouble that you have reading and comprehending a one‐page question time brief, don't you agree that frail elderly people, indeed anyone, will have a great deal of difficulty in understanding that 47 pages of legal gobbledygook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Thank you, Minister. I agree that they will. Minister, yesterday you spoke about all the options that people have in regard to not having to sell their houses—being able to do things like making periodic payments. Under the area of periodic payments, the agreement prescribes that the provider of the service—that is, Mr Moran and others—will be able to apply security to periodic payments and the provider will determine what that security has to be. Minister, don't you agree that, considering the number of people who will own only their own homes, the obvious security that will be demanded for these other options you talked about yesterday will be the homes they own?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—My question is to Senator Hill, Minister for the Environment. Minister, when I began this series of questions last year on the government's greenhouse policy I predicted that, if you did not change course, Australia risked becoming an international pariah on this issue. Since then we have seen nation after nation decry Australia's bloody‐mindedness, and today you lost your last major card when President Bill Clinton made it clear that the US will not endorse your position and, in fact, wants binding targets. Firstly, will you reconsider now that we are an international pariah? Secondly, will you throw out the useless ABARE report and encourage the new jobs that are there waiting to be done? Finally, do you agree that we must quickly recognise the potential for renewable technologies and that international market opportunities will flow on if we develop a strong domestic market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a strange question but I will have a go at answering it. In fact, I would suggest, Senator, that the principles that underlie our position are being more widely recognised and respected by our negotiating partners each day. On that basis, you will understand why I think your question is oddly out of order with the direction of these negotiations.

ANSWER.PARA: The point that I made in answer to an earlier question was that President Clinton has put down a formula today that suits the national circumstances of the United States. It does not call for no action. In fact, he puts forward a number of domestic changes in terms of incentives and other ways that would encourage a better domestic greenhouse performance, but basically it fits their national circumstance. It is what he believes can be achieved by the United States without economic loss. That is basically the position that Australia is advocating. We have argued that Australia should make a worthwhile contribution but it should be one that does not undermine our economy, does not sacrifice Australian jobs and does not provide an extra burden to the regions of Australia that would suffer under a uniform proposal.

What I said earlier was that, in fact, we now have a number of different formulas and targets on the table. Japan put down its a couple of weeks ago. It talked about 1990 levels less five per cent plus an allowance for various elements of differentiation. One of those areas of differentiation was within our formula. It added another two that suited its national circumstances. It called for some pain for Japan. For example, it called, in their interpretation, for them to build another 20 nuclear power stations, which might be something that Senator Lees is suggesting for Australia as an alternative. I do not know.

The Europeans have done likewise. They have allowed differentiation within the European community. They have allowed Portugal to go 40 per cent above 1990 levels. As I recall, they allowed Spain to go 30 per cent above 1990 levels. Out of that differentiated model, they have an overall picture that they believe they can deliver as a community, a community target that will not cost them unduly in terms of jobs.

All Australia wants is to be put in the same boat. By the time you give differentiation for the European states, differentiation for the east European states and differentiation for the developing world, as was acknowledged by President Clinton today, so I presume you endorse that, there are only eight countries left in the world that you are not giving the right to differentiate. Why should we be one of those eight countries and sacrifice thousands of jobs just to please the Europeans? Why should we do that? This government is not going to do it.

As I said, this government is prepared to take tough domestic decisions, and the Prime Minister will be making further announcements in due course. This government is prepared to further encourage industry, as we have been doing through the greenhouse challenge program. I commend industry that has come on board and done a good job in that regard. This government is prepared to ensure Australia does its fair share and does its bit to achieve a better global outcome, but we are not going to take an unfair burden and we are not going to throw Australian jobs on the trash heap.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his interesting answer. Minister, you must have read a different version of what President Clinton said to what I did because he made it very clear that he supported binding targets. We are the only nation now left in the OECD that is going to be at Kyoto that does not support binding international targets. Minister, do you agree that, as far as differentiation is concerned, if we keep pushing this line we could end up having to do more than the rest of the world because of our current position, and that we have the flexibility within Australia to differentiate between industries, depending on where they are now at? Did you note that most of Europe, specifically the English Guardian today, believes that we are totally out of step and that `Oz is up a gum tree and out on a limb'? Minister, you seem to be the only one who is convinced that we are not out of step with the rest of the world. We have to acknowledge that there are many new jobs there waiting to be done, to get in step with it and, if we can develop those industries here, then export that technology, particularly to Asia. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have said on binding targets is that, until we know the obligation that is going to be sought of us, it would be inappropriate, foolish and bad public policy for us to agree to sign on. In other words, what you are suggesting we should do is sign a blank cheque on Australian jobs, and we are not going to do that. We believe we have a responsibility to contribute to a better global greenhouse outcome, but we have also got a responsibility to grow the Australian economy and provide jobs. We want to achieve both, and we believe you can achieve both.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lees is just starting to understand differentiation. An industry, for example, that has already made the sacrifice and spent the money to put in new energy efficiency plant may be able to do less than one that has not done it. But that is what differentiation is all about. It is about putting enough pressure on each industry and each state to contribute what they can consistent with preserving jobs and economic opportunity. So, Senator Lees, you are starting to get on track, but if you take that example one step further you will better understand the debate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Is it true that Mr Doug Moran of the Moran Health Group heavily lobbied coalition frontbenchers to introduce a user pays system for nursing homes? Is it true that Mr Moran had Mr Costello and Mr Ruddock to dinner for this purpose just before the 1996 election? Is it true that he increased his nursing investments in the expectation that your Liberal government would introduce a user pays system and that he had a lot to do with the nursing home legislation you subsequently introduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that many people from many parts of the industry approached us because they would have known that we were going to win the last election. Blind Freddy would have known that we were going to win the last election. It would have been very prudent for the whole of the nursing industry as the health care industry to approach our party and the coalition because Captain Whacky was leading them down the plughole, as those nursing home people and the hospital industry, the whole lot, would have been aware. The only people who were not aware of it were Senator Faulkner and his cohorts over there.

ANSWER.PARA: You have only to read that book about what happened during that campaign to know that many people consulted with us. It was absolutely marvellous. The last time I can remember that happening was in 1975. I am sure that Mr Moran probably approached people. I would not know whether he had dinner. I am sure he had dinner every night, just as all of us did. Who he had as his companions, I have not the faintest idea. But, if he was prudent, just as Francis Sullivan, the Director of the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, he would have also seen our people—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you read what he said in the paper?
—No, you do not want to blame Francis Sullivan because he comes and meets with you daily, just as he does with us. In fact, I met with him last night.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Forshaw interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You go back into your box over there. You have done enough damage. I would not know who Mr Moran had dinner with nor who Mr Costello had dinner with. Who else was it Senator Schacht spoke about? Somebody else—I am sure they are quite decent people—
—So you didn't get a free lunch?

—Senator Schacht asked me whether I got a free lunch. I did not get a free lunch. I did not get a free dinner. I did not get anything. But I did go to Mr Moran's art prize, which is the best art prize in Australia—a portrait prize. He donates that every year. He is a philanthropist, I know. If his philanthropy includes the Liberal Party, good on him. I think that is great. We on our side never have any strings attached to donations, not like the—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise is far too high. A reasonable level of intervention can be tolerated, but not the level which is going on at the present time.
—There is one thing I am certain about, that there are no strings attached to donations to the Liberal Party. You cannot say that about the other side.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They laugh and scoff, but what do the unions expect of them? Nothing? Mr Moran spoke about bludgers the other day. The only people who bludge off the unions are those who are here in the Senate. That is what they are doing. They are not working for their unions. This is where they come when they are superannuated out from the unions.

ANSWER.PARA: There are no strings attached to donations that are given to the coalition. They are all declared. There is nothing under the covers. So to imply that anything has occurred is the pot calling the kettle black. That is what they are doing. They are implying that there is undue motive, that there was lobbying. Of course there is lobbying. Everybody lobbies politicians. If they are not lobbying, they are not doing their job.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't go near that lot.

—Senator Alston interjects that they do not go near that lot. Why would they? They even have to clutch at the leader of another party to be their acolyte, to join the rest of them, to come in. I am sure that will come back and bite them one day too.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you see a potential conflict of interest in nursing home proprietors such as the Moran group also operating a real estate agency? Is your government comfortable with a situation whereby a company collects bonds of up to $250,000 from new entrants to nursing homes and, at the same time, sells their homes or rents them out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, those huge bonds are exempt. Senator Schacht is probably not aware of that, but there is an exemption over a certain area. For example, the accommodation bonds of up to $250,000 that Senator Schacht referred to apply to Mr Moran's Rose Bay Gardens nursing home. This home operates under the exempt home arrangements, introduced by the previous Labor government.

ANSWER.PARA: They introduced the exemption. He does not even know his own policy when he was in government. The Labor government introduced those exemptions to enable those who can afford to and wish to do so to pay for more luxury level accommodation and hotel type services. If they wish to pay that, they are exempt from the bond, Senator Schacht, and less than three per cent of nursing homes are in this category. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill as the Minister for the Environment, as the Minister representing the Prime Minister and as the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the front page report in the Financial Review yesterday that the government will roll out a strategy document on greenhouse in an effort to counter increasing internal and global criticism of their approach. I ask: will the government be introducing enforceable standards in areas such as building insulation and motor vehicle fuel efficiency? Will these standards be at least as stringent as those in other nations such as the US and Germany? On what basis will national standards be developed? Just how much of this reported $150 million package will consist of a subsidy to petroleum companies to reduce lead in petrol, a worthy aim but nothing whatsoever to do with greenhouse gas reductions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not remember seeing that last idea, even in the Financial Review , I have to say. That is presumably an invention of the Greens. I would dismiss that, Senator Margetts. Obviously, I can neither deny nor confirm other aspects of that article.

ANSWER.PARA: What I can say to you is that there are opportunities for us across all sectors to do better in relation to greenhouse gas emissions. We think that it is reasonable that best international standard is expected of Australia. If we look at the domestic sector, for example, there is the potential for better insulation standards and the like that would help make a positive contribution. If we look at the transport sector, there is the potential for better emission standards.

I should mention to Senator Lees that the second area of domestic reform that Japan is looking at after building 20 new nuclear power stations is even more stringent emission requirements for motor vehicles. There is that potential for Australia. Similarly, in relation to the fixed production of energy, industry use of energy and, dare I say it, land use policy there is the opportunity in this country for better performance and therefore a greater contribution to reducing global greenhouse gases.

The government is working its way through all of those sectors. We will be putting to the people a program that calls for a stronger domestic response than that which we now have. It is interesting that, under the current domestic response, our performance has been better than that of many of the countries that criticise us.

Our increase, as Senator Margetts will know, from 1990 to 1995 was about six per cent. That was a considerably better result than many other countries within annex 1. It demonstrates that the voluntary no regrets approach that the government has adopted is making a useful contribution. Nevertheless, we accept that Australia can do more, can do better and it is our intention to ask that of Australians.

I have made the point that it is not just a challenge for governments; it is also a challenge for industry. It is a challenge for the community at large. If we as a nation are going to produce a better greenhouse outcome then we all have to make a contribution. It cannot all be under federal legislation because, as you are no doubt aware Senator Margetts, some of these matters are within the constitutional province of the states.

I believe it can be argued, in any event, that your approach, the regulatory approach—and it is interesting to see the way that President Clinton developed his argument today—is not as effective as a non‐regulatory regime, a market orientated regime, which will encourage a better outcome than a regulatory outcome which tends to become a lowest common denominator outcome. There is room for us to do better. We want to do better because it is important that Australia does play its full role within the international greenhouse challenge. That is the way in which we are approaching this vitally important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am glad that the minister mentioned the United States. It appears that US President Bill Clinton has proposed more than $6 billion in tax incentives for industry to encourage research and energy efficient practices. Will the government be reversing its decision to withdraw money from energy conservation research through the ERDC, the Energy Research and Development Corporation, and the cooperative research centres? Given that the United States has quite a lot of enforceable standards, will the government be working with the states to actually bring about the first enforceable environmental standards on energy efficiency that Australian has had?

—We have started the process of putting propositions to the states. We obviously would like to see them endorse our proposals. When those negotiations are concluded and the COAG meeting comes up in a few weeks time, further announcements can be expected. I think the honourable senator is also somewhat confused in that this government does invest very large sums of public money in greenhouse science and in renewable energy. I draw Senator Margetts' attention to the CRC on renewable energy which is based in her home state.
—You just cut it.

—You have probably never been there. I invite you to visit and to talk to the academics and to look at the very worthwhile work that they are doing with public support. This government is investing in the universities. It is investing in the CRC. It is investing in renewable technologies. It is investing in sustainable energy. (Time expired)

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, Senator Herron. Can you confirm that, in order to appease the coalition backbench, the government is contemplating allocating $4 million for an advertising campaign to sell its introduction of entry bonds and daily charges for nursing homes? Will the Department of Health and Family Services consult the Office of Government Information and Advertising in relation to that decision? Will you guarantee that that contract for the campaign will be decided through a competitive tendering process without any political interference—novel though this concept may be to some of your government colleagues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I cannot confirm any of that because I am unaware of that. Holding Senator Ray in high regard, I will put that question to the minister and get back to him with an answer. As I have high regard for Senator Ray's abilities and as he has advocated all those things, I will take that on board. I am sure that suggestion from you, Senator Ray, will be very useful to us. I would have thought, considering the level of ignorance on the other side, the amount of disinformation that is around and the scare campaign that has been mounted against this issue by the opposition, that $4 million would not be enough.
—What scare campaign.

—There has been enormous publicity about this disinformation campaign—the scaring and the frightening of elderly people. All this week we have been trying to spell out to the opposition what is occurring. I thank Senator Ray for his suggestion. I think it is a marvellous idea that that should occur. The only thing I would differ with is the amount of funding that should be spent on this campaign, because there has been an enormous amount of publicity and media generated by this disinformation campaign. One should consider, Senator Faulkner, that the actual principle was introduced by the Labor Party in the first place in relation to hostels.

BREAK.PARA: So I do not think that amount of funding will be enough, because it will take a monstrous campaign to overcome the disinformation and the mistruths that have been developed in the media. I think the media actually has a responsibility now to clarify all the points in this particular policy.

I also agree with Senator Ray that any contracts put out should be all above board, as they are under us. There should be open tendering. I think it was Senator Ray's suggestion that there should be open tendering. I would agree that, if any contract is let for an advertising campaign, there should be open tendering and it should be all above board so that there can be no outside influences. I am sure that a particular agency favoured by the opposition will not be the one that will be—

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot go the four minutes.
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—The tenders will be open. If that should be Senator Ray's suggestion, I think it is a very good suggestion. There are other points that Senator Ray has suggested with regard to detail. As I said, I am not aware of those points in relation to those details, but certainly they fit in with the parameters that I would think would be reasonable by any government. We will follow those through, as has been suggested by Senator Ray.

BREAK.PARA: There may be some item that I have not covered. I apologise to Senator Ray for that. Senator Ray could raise by way of supplementary question anything that I have not covered in my answer. I would be happy to follow it through. If he has a supplementary question in that regard, I will complete that part of the answer I have not given him. It will be necessary to refer this to the minister so that I can get a full answer for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, isn't Senator Herron aware that government advertising does not go to open tender, which he has committed the government to, but a restricted tender run by OGIA? Secondly, if he is not satisfied with the $4 million as being sufficient, will he, in fact, nominate a figure? Thirdly, will he tell us how many nursing home entries per million dollars the government could have effected without wasting it on advertising? Finally, will he make sure that some of this money is spent in resolving disinformation that Mr Smith has just put down in the other place, which totally contradicts him today? Obviously ignorance starts over there.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to inform the Senate that I was asked a question earlier today by Senator Bob Collins. The same question about the inability to cover a brief in one page was asked in the other chamber, word for word, about 10 minutes later. Senator Ray, I would hope that you will follow the same format in relation to the supplementary question that you have just asked so that you will get a similar sort of answer on the other side to the one that—
—You are not allowed supplementaries over here.

—Senator Ray interjected that they are not allowed supplementaries. You certainly are allowed supplementaries on the other side, Senator Ray. You are totally ignorant of the procedure on the other side, just as former Senator Gareth Evans is. Wasn't he the one who called for a quorum during question time, or was that Senator Faulkner? I think it was former Senator Evans. So I would suggest that Senator Ray check the procedure on the other side—(Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice. Minister, the issue of violence and personal safety is an increasing concern to many Australians, especially to women and to older Australians. Will you inform the Senate of the government's initiatives to prevent violence in our community, including the Australian Violence Prevention Awards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Macdonald for the question. He rightly identifies that fear of violence in the community, especially in the rural community and amongst the elderly, is a problem. Today I had the opportunity to announce the four national winners in the Australian Violence Prevention Awards. These are jointly sponsored by the heads of Australian governments; that is, Commonwealth, state and territory. It is a combined initiative and includes a total prize pool of some $100,000. The whole system is designed to reward the most outstanding projects for the prevention or the reduction of violence. Projects can focus on specific groups, such as women or children or youth or the family, or they may take the other tack and focus on specific problems, such as excessive alcohol consumption, violence in the media or violence in sport.

ANSWER.PARA: Recent figures on the cost of crime suggest that for every man, woman and child in Australia, the cost of crime is some $100,000 a year, and that gives us a $20 billion a year cost across Australia. It is clear, therefore, that in tackling the causes of violence in crime we cannot rely on the justice system alone, which picks up the crime after it has been committed. We absolutely have to give a much greater focus to crime prevention strategies which will reduce the opportunities and the motivation for criminal activity.

The Prime Minister recently announced some $13 million in a national campaign against violence in crime, which will support a very wide range of crime prevention initiatives. The awards play a very important role in the fight against violent crime. This year there were over 100 entries from across Australia. The projects have to have been up and running for a year. They are assessed on a range of criteria, including whether the project can be copied elsewhere, whether it will be useful to other communities to follow the example, whether it actually does reduce or prevent violence, and the degree to which it is innovative and raises community awareness.

The winners of the violence prevention awards this year cover a range of interesting aspects. The lead winner of the $20,000 prize is the positive parenting program, or the triple P program, from Queensland. In this program, parents are taught strategies for building positive relationships with their children and to develop appropriate discipline strategies. There has been significant publicity given to this program—most recently by the 60 Minutes program. It is a most effective program and one that can be transmitted around Australia.

Three other programs received awards of $10,000 each. In Queensland, the family care program received $10,000. That program involves a trial of home based nursing services which are provided to families that are identified as being vulnerable—that is, instead of waiting until a problem occurs, vulnerable families are identified and assistance is provided so that the problem does not occur. Preventing workplace violence in Victoria, a scheme initiated by Jobwatch, helps employees who experience violence at work, giving them a capacity for reporting and redress. Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Interjections that relate to the answer are one thing; sledging is another, and it is totally disorderly.

—Feelsafe in Western Australia is a very useful program for adults and older adolescents who have impaired cognitive abilities. It helps them develop the skills to deal with situations that are unsafe, potentially abusive or dangerous. Forty other projects around Australia on a state basis were awarded either prizes or certificates of merit. Each of these projects in their way contributes across Australia, whether they involve Commonwealth, state or local government or community groups, into making Australia a safer place.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, given that you avoided addressing the issue of conflict of interest in Senator Schacht's supplementary question just a moment ago, I would like to ask you very clearly again: do you see a potential conflict of interest in nursing home proprietors, such as the Moran group, also operating a real estate agency? Minister, doesn't this place such a company in a position where it can take unfair advantage of elderly people who have no other option than to sell or rent their house in order to get into a nursing home? Does the government accept this situation or will the government take some action to change it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. It was reported in the West Australian of 2 October that the WA Minister for Resource Development, Mr Colin Barnett, had held talks with Treasurer Peter Costello and industry minister John Moore on the subject of Commonwealth financial assistance for the controversial proposed Oakajee port and industrial development near Geraldton. Firstly, is the minister aware of the widespread community concern about the economic and environmental risks and costs of the proposed new industrial site and port at Oakajee? Secondly, what sum of money was the WA government seeking from the Commonwealth? Thirdly, was any commitment given at that meeting or subsequently by the Commonwealth for funding assistance for this project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Murray for the opportunity to comment on what is a very important resources development. It is not often recognised that out of resources development and downstream processing comes enormous infrastructure development and the spin-off effects from those additional infrastructure developments.

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that the government of Western Australia is close to completing assessments and approvals for the proposed Oakajee deepwater port and associated industrial estate near Geraldton. I understand the Western Australian government has spent some $2½ million on external consultancy fees, including on environmental and economic issues. I also understand that the Western Australian government is confident that the port can be constructed within reasonable financial parameters and is negotiating to bring the proposal to fruition. I also understand that financial details remain to be settled.

The port is crucial to the development of important resources proposals in the mid‐west region of Western Australia, including the $1.2 billion An Feng Kingstream iron and steel project, a project, I might say, that I discussed when I was recently in Taipei with the An Feng people. There is also the $900 million Mt Gibson integrated iron project as well as $1 billion in associated infrastructure.

These projects, provided they proceed, will result in the creation of 1,500 permanent jobs and 5,000 indirect jobs, with 2,400 jobs during the construction phase. The port would give a significant boost to regional development and resources and energy exploration as well as, of course, the downstream processing that most of us in this country have sought for so many years. The proposal is strongly supported by the local community.

TALK.START.PARA: —No it is not.
—There is the lone voice. Any development in this country you can guarantee the Greens will oppose. To hell with the jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: It will be the only major port between Perth and the Pilbara, a distance of some 1,200 kilometres. The port project is commercially driven and is being strongly supported by the private sector. I understand that consideration of the financial studies that will be the basis of a Western Australian government contribution to the project remains to be finalised.

I am advised that the Western Australian government's preferred approach is to proceed to tender for a finance-build-own‐operate and transfer process facility—in other words, build, own, operate, transfer across back to the state; it is an old trick—that will cost significantly less than reported in the press.
A substantial amount of funding for the port will come from the private sector. There has been considerable interest in participating in the port development from credible private consortia.

As regards the other part of the question asked by Senator Murray as to whether there had been some approach made to the federal government, no approach has been made to me personally or to my department. Prior to coming into question time I heard that some approach had been made to, I think, the Treasurer. But I will find out for you and let you know.

Would you give us the assurance that you would consult with that community?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 October 1997 Senator Woodley asked Senator Chris Ellison, the then Minister Assisting the Attorney-General, a question without notice. The question asked by Senator Woodley was in relation to the accuracy of testing by AQIS of cooked chicken meat imports for Newcastle disease and other bird viruses and the role of the Attorney‐General and his department in assessing the risk of legal liability arising from that test.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ellison took that question on notice and undertook to provide the information at a later date. Since then, of course, I have been appointed as Minister for Justice. The Attorney-General has provided me with the following information in answer to Senator Woodley's question. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The answer read as follows—

(1) I am informed that no record has been able to be found in the Attorney-General's Department that any officer of his Department has checked AQIS reports on testing of cooked chicken imports to ensure that they are accurate;

(2) Generally, such a task would not be done within the Attorney-General' s Department unless the Commonwealth agency concerned asked the AttorneyGeneral's Department (including the Australian Government Solicitor) to give legal advice on issues to which the question of the accuracy of such tests was relevant;

(3) While the Attorney-General is concerned to minimise any exposure of the Commonwealth and its agencies to any legal liability sounding in damages or other relief, it is not part of the normal functions of his Department to check, without request, processes and procedures for which other Departments and agencies are responsible, in an endeavour to minimise legal liability. It needs to be borne in mind, in that connection, that since 1 July 1992 the provision of legal services by the Attorney-Gener al's Department Legal Practice has operated on a user pays basis and, accordingly, it is properly a matter for the responsible agency to determine whether legal services are required;

(4) Should there be a request from the responsible Minister or agency, the Australian Government Solicitor is available to provide advice concerning potential liability that may be related to the testing of chicken meat imports.
I trust that this answers Senator Woodley's question and I thank him for his question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that Senator Schacht's little speech exemplifies the approach the Labor Party has taken to this whole issue. It completely ignores the real issue, the state of Australia's nursing homes. We have heard nothing about the real issue, the appalling state of Australia's nursing homes, or the fact that the policy of the government is designed to improve conditions in those nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: I know it has already been said to the Senate at least four times in taking note of answers over the last couple of months, but the fact is that nursing homes around Australia on the whole are of very poor quality. For example, 40 per cent of nursing home residents share their bedrooms with four or more people; 13 per cent of nursing homes do not meet fire regulations, and another 11 per cent do not meet health regulations. These are pretty appalling statistics. There has been a real need to improve the standard of nursing homes, and that is what the government has set out do to with this policy to introduce a bond system. The idea of the bond system is that money will become available for capital improvements.

We have to remember that Australia faces an ever‐increasing proportion of its population falling into the aged group. In fact, something like a 48 per cent increase will occur in the number of people aged over 65 in the next 20 years. We have to do something to prepare to meet their needs. That is why the government has introduced this very sensible policy to enable nursing homes to have access to capital to improve facilities.

I know it has been said many times before, but this policy which the government is introducing is just an extension of a policy and a program to charge accommodation bonds for hostels which the Labor government introduced in 1988. That policy worked very well. In fact, people in hostels today have benefited greatly from that policy because the standards of the facilities in which they are living have greatly improved.

I think it is very curious that the opposition is so critical of this policy when in fact it is really, I suppose, a credit to them that the government has been so impressed with the success of the policy they introduced that they have extended it to nursing homes. Very largely, what has been said has been scaremongering; they have been trying to frighten people about accommodation bonds.

The fact of the matter is that the accommodation bond system in hostels has meant that people have had to pay a fairly modest bond of around $26,000. There is no reason at all to believe that accommodation bonds in nursing homes will be any different. They will not be anything like the horrendous amounts which the opposition is claiming they will be.

I was a member of the Senate Community Affairs Reference Committee inquiry which looked into the question of nursing homes. One of the witness was a Dr Norman Marinovic, who is the head of the geriatric service at Fremantle Hospital. He said in evidence to the committee that he did not see any problem with accommodation bonds for nursing homes and that he believed the system would work just as well as it had in the case of hostels. In other words, he be lieved that the standard of nursing homes would be improved under the government's policy, just as the standard of hostels has improved under the government's policies.

Also, I would like to quote an endorsement which came from Maureen Lister of Aged Care Australia, which represents the church and charity community group sector and provides most of the hostels and about 45 per cent of all nursing homes in Australia. On the World Today on ABC Radio on 11 February Ms Lister said:
We've had entry contributions to the hostel system for some 10 years and I don't believe that residents of hostels would ever say that that system has not worked.
(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take note of the responses by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) during question time today on the nursing homes issue because I am sick and tired of the minister's non‐stop response to every concern raised with him in this chamber that it is some sort of Labor plot. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak on this particular issue to bring some balance to the debate. I accept there is fear out in the community but that fear has been generated by the campaign run from the other side, particularly in the House of Representatives. There is so much misrepresentation around in terms of what is occurring that it really is quite a sad day for Australia, I believe, that we should see this happening.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to place on record a couple of points. In a lot of ways, the need to deal with the issue of aged people and the necessity for nursing homes and what they require in their later years is not dissimilar, in a sense, to what we were confronted with when we had to deal with the $10 billion deficit when we came into government. It was the Labor government which left nursing homes in such a mess. We should never forget that when dealing with this issue.

We have heard many quotes but one worth commenting on is that of Maureen Lister of Aged Care Australia, who said, `We'll be able to see quite significant improvements in the building of nursing homes, and everyone knows that is gravely needed.' As I understand it, she is involved with 45 per cent of nursing homes in this country.

I will endeavour to put to bed a few of the furphies that we have heard. With regard to better access for concessional residents, we have just heard Senator Bob Collins's comments with regard to the financially disadvantaged. I want to put on the record the fact that financial disadvantage will not affect a person's ability to get the care they need. That is a very important point. Every facility will be required to set aside a minimum number of places for those who cannot pay an accommodation bond. In the hostel sector now, the average national target for places for financially disadvantaged persons is 23 per cent. The concessional resident target under the new scheme will be 27 per cent of places nationally—in each region, according to local need.

This will ensure that all older people, whether concessional residents or not, have an equal chance of getting a place. I want to emphasise that point: they will have an equal chance of getting a place. It is a very important point in the context of this debate and the necessity to get the facts on the table.

Also, concessional residents will not wait any longer to get a place. There will be equal access. Experience with hostels shows that people who are financially disadvantaged wait no longer for a place. Let us remember that the hostel policy is almost identical to the policy adopted by the previous government.

Providers will receive an extra subsidy of $7 a day for each concessional resident and $12 if their number of concessional residents totals more than 40 per cent. This is a big improvement on Labor's $3.50 a day extra for financially disadvantaged residents. In fact, according to my sums, it is double. We are confident that, with higher government subsidies and better protections, the new arrangements will provide greater assurance that older people will have access to the care they need.

I would like to deal with one other aspect in the time remaining to me—that is, the sale of a resident's home. Under these arrangements, residents do not have to sell their home to pay for a bond. From everything we heard during the campaign that was run a week or 10 days ago, we would have believed that that was the case. Let me assure everybody that it is a concern that is shared not only by elderly people but by people who accept responsibility for their mothers, fathers or members of their families—in some instances it could be their aunts and uncles or their friends. People need to understand that they do not have to sell their home to pay for a bond. They may prefer to pay from other assets or income, from borrowing against the home or other assets, or from rental income.

One of the big furphies is this scaremongering campaign—I cannot describe it as anything else—that aged people will have to sell their home. You can understand why they would get upset about that. (Time expired)
