—Or perhaps, Senator McKiernan, you do want to hear the government's policy. He really does want to hear it. He is genuine after all. Senator McKiernan, there are three reasons that we have introduced this policy. Firstly, because of the estimated sheer growth in the number of older Australians in the next 20 years; secondly, because of how run down nursing homes have become over the past decade; and, thirdly, because of how ill‐prepared we are for the estimated future growth in the number of older Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the future growth in the numbers entering nursing homes, it is no exaggeration to say that one of the great tasks facing the coalition when it achieved government was to plan for this future wave. The statistics are compelling. The number of aged Australians over 65 will grow to some 48 per cent over the next 20 years. To put that in number terms, in 1991 the number of Australians over the age of 65 was two million. Within the next 20 or so years there will be as many as five million. This government, because of these compelling statistics, is planning for the future. In fact, this planning should have been done some 10 years ago.

BREAK.PARA: Closely linked to this is the state of the nursing homes. The previous government was warned as far back as 1993, in the Gregory report, that the nursing home industry needed a capital injection of some $130 million per year over at least the next decade. This government found that nursing homes across Australia needed capital upgrading. They did not meet the fire regulations or the health regulations. There were narrow corridors, there was dingy lighting and there were unhygienic kitchens. More than 40 per cent of nursing home residents were forced to share a bedroom with four or more people. That is the foundation stone on which we have built our policy.

In the short time I have left, I would like to allay the concerns of my Victorian residents—as Senator McKiernan invited me to do—in regard to the safety net. Those who cannot financially meet the bond will be catered for and will have direct access to nursing homes. If people do not meet the financial criteria, if people are under the threshold, we will put aside 27 per cent for nursing homes for what are called `concessional rates'. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

As I said by way of a point of order—which was, indeed, not a point of order, and you correctly ruled on that—it is not my habit to interject across the chamber, not even to slag across the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not do it. I have had the experience of sitting in the chair that you are now sitting in and so I know how difficult it is for the chair to seek to control the debate. I do not seek to add to the disorder in the chamber when I am sitting in my place here. The assertion and allegation that Senator McGauran made is not founded on truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a personal explanation in response to Senator McKiernan.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, most definitely.

If someone calls you a liar, which Senator McKiernan did—and he was forced to withdraw that statement by you—that is an abuse across the chamber.

I got a withdrawal, but if that is not abuse across the chamber and a misrepresentation, then I do not know what is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked earlier that people improve their language and actually address the chair. If you address the chair you will find that you will get into a lot less trouble because you are actually talking to the chair and not to the other people.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 23 October, from Senator Lees:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
"That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The absolute contempt shown by the Hawke, Keating and Howard Governments for the 800,000 unemployed persons in Australia, and for the loss of 3.3 million jobs over the last decade by their failure to fully explore creative but practical solutions to the unemployment crisis currently gripping this nation.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: "That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The absolute contempt shown by the Hawke, Keating and Howard Governments for the 800,000 unemployed persons in Australia, and for the loss of 3.3 million jobs over the last decade by their failure to fully explore creative but practical solutions to the unemployment crisis currently gripping this nation.

I begin by looking at the answer given to a question of mine by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator Ellison, earlier this week. Unfortunately, he is not able to be with us for this debate today, but in his answer he fell immediately into the inevitable government rhetoric that the answer to the jobs crisis lies, first and foremost, in the work for the dole scheme and, failing that, in economic growth.

While I am certain that Senator Ellison has been very carefully and eagerly studying the obligatory rhetoric on jobs since assuming his present role, he obviously has a lot of work to do, because none of his colleagues—not one minister, not even Dr Kemp—has at any stage dared to go so far as to suggest that the work for the dole scheme will have any impact whatsoever on unemployment levels.

BREAK.PARA: In fact the minister's own department has stressed over and over, in the context of the merits of the work for the dole bill, that job outcomes and training do not even factor in the formal objectives of this scheme. As we have seen, it has never been enough to simply refer to economic growth as a solution. It was not good enough under the previous governments, and it certainly is not good enough now. It does not automatically bring down unemployment levels.

Despite years of economic growth, growth which was supposed to generate jobs, hundreds of thousands of Australians remain unemployed and many others who want full-time work are stuck in part-time and casual positions barely able to make ends meet. At the same time as working conditions are declining stress levels are increasing. Those in full-time work are being expected, as we have seen from the latest statistics, to work longer and longer hours.

If this pattern continues the result will be a divided and unequal society, a society where a privileged minority have access to well‐paid and very satisfying work with probably some promotional opportunities, but the vast majority of Australian workers will be left to fight for fewer and fewer jobs—jobs which will be of poor quality, jobs which will have little, if any, security and satisfaction, jobs which will be highly stressed, jobs which will have no prospects for advancement, few fringe benefits and low wages.

So who is responsible for this pattern? Senator Ellison would have us believe that this government is nothing like the former government but, frankly, in my view, looking at the evidence they are as bad as each other. Australians have endured more than a decade of both federal and state governments seeing themselves solely as economic managers, pulling out of providing services, selling off public assets and consistently refusing to place social and environmental goals on at least an equal footing with economic ones.

When the economic bottom line becomes the only criterion governments really care about, other important national objectives tend to go out the window. But what about the important national and economic objective of ensuring business and consumer confidence by concentrating on securing Australian jobs? How can you justify attempts to explain away the loss of 3.3 million full‐time jobs to redundancies over the past 12 years? How do you even begin to explain the loss on average, year in and year out since 1986, of 275,000 full-time jobs?

The fact is that neither the Labor Party nor the Howard‐led coalition have any policies in place to reverse this loss of full-time positions. Let us just go through this government's list. These are jobs directly lost thanks to the actions of this government. This government is responsible for the shedding of 180,000 jobs since March 1996—27,000 are directly from the Public Service due to the government's cuts; 22,000 are from Telstra as part of the preparations for privatisation; 20,000 are from state and local governments as a result of grant cuts to those bodies; 25,000 are from public works due to a $1 billion cut in spending; 39,000 are from the manufacturing sector due largely to a collapse in confidence; and 46,000 are due to a cut in labour market program places.

So there is little doubt that if the rampant job shedding encouraged under the policy settings of both the Labor Party and the coalition had been reduced by just one‐quarter many of today's unemployed would probably have jobs right now. The simple fact is that Labor and the coalition have not only failed to create new jobs—and I particularly emphasise new jobs for young Australians—but also failed to protect existing jobs.

There have certainly been some distractions in the last couple of weeks. But the Democrats refuse to allow the furore over travel rorts and the actions of former Senator Kernot to distract us from the main game. There needs to be a new approach, some creative solutions, to the jobs dilemma in this country, and we should be investigating those right now. My colleague Senator Stott Despoja, the Democrats employment spokesperson, will rise in a few minutes to introduce to the Senate the Australian Democrats most recent initiatives on jobs.

We have been getting down to the job on jobs—consulting the Australian public on the question of how they think unemployment should be addressed. In March of this year we commenced a public consultation project in search of viable solutions to the jobs crisis. We approached forward looking and creative business and community leaders and academics to contribute to a discussion on the Internet on jobs. We asked them to put up a challenge to the existing paradigms and we are pleased and, in some instances, quite surprised at the results. We have shown, and Senator Stott Despoja will demonstrate, that there are a range of alternatives to the economic rationalist approach so readily embraced by the two mainstream parties.

This book is a testament to Australians in all walks of life who care deeply about the employment crisis—those who we approached for essays, those in the general public who public contributed via the Internet and the Australian Democrats staff and members who have contributed endless ideas and innovations. High unemployment is not an inevitable by‐product of technological advancement as the essays in this publication show. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment really is, I suppose, the worst problem that is facing this country, and we all know that its social consequences are quite horrendous.
—Why don't you do something about it? We all know that your budget was aimed at increasing unemployment.
—Senator Cook, who is interjecting, was a senior cabinet minister when unemployment topped the one million mark and there are one million Australians who will never forgive Labor for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion before us is both pejorative and unbecoming. Even if one trawls over the Labor Party's poor performance in this area I do not think you could argue that it was on the basis of absolute contempt for the unemployed. I have to say that with the unemployment problem facing the Howard government there is nobody I know on the Liberal side or indeed the Labor side of politics who says, `Ha, ha! There are 800,000 people unemployed.' We genuinely try to seek solutions and the argument between the two sides of this place and the nation is about how you overcome the problem.

The fact that we have arguments as to how to overcome the problem indicates that we acknowledge it is a problem, Senator Lees, and we are trying to do something about it. But to suggest that they are treated with absolute contempt is unbecoming, Senator Lees, and I have to say to you that it does nothing for your prospects for leadership of the Australian Democrats and your standing and your party's standing within the community.

Sure, let us have a fight, a debate and an argument about our policy thrusts and directions where you think ours may be wrong and yours may be right. But I would never descend to the suggestion that the Democrats treat the unemployed with absolute contempt, although I might be forgiven for saying so when one reads today's Daily Telegraph where we are told:
Hairdresser Vicki McFarlane was ready to take on two new staff members at her Parramatta Salon in time for Christmas.
But when opposition MPs—
including the Democrats—
in Canberra scuppered changes to unfair dismissal laws on Tuesday, Ms McFarlane decided it just was not worth the risk.
"We feel betrayed by what the Senate has done," she said yesterday.

Do you know what? There are two people in Parramatta that also feel betrayed. Because of the policies of the Democrats and the Labor Party, there are going to be two people in Parramatta that face Christmas 1997 without a job—a direct result of the way the Democrats and the Labor Party cast their vote in this place only a few days ago.

The motion that has been put before us suggests that there are 800,000 unemployed persons in Australia. Unfortunately, that is correct, and the government is dealing with that issue. If time permits, I will go through some of our initiatives in that regard. But we are then told `and for the loss of 3.3 million jobs over the last decade'. If there were 3.3 million jobs actually lost out of the economy, wouldn't it stand to reason that you might have an unemployment rate of 3.3 million? What has happened is that a lot of people have lost their jobs but they do not tell you the other side of the equation, that a lot of those people that have lost their jobs have in fact gained new jobs, and that is where this motion is so very deceptive and very misleading.

One wonders: have Senator Lees and the Democrats given some thought to these figures? Where would they have trawled these figures up from? It is quite obvious. They are from the Sydney Morning Herald headline. A cheap journalistic headline becomes the substance of the Australian Democrats policy on unemployment. That is how devoid they are of policy consideration. That is how devoid they are of actually thinking about the issues that are confronting this nation.

The motion goes on to tell us that the Howard government and others have failed `to fully explore creative but practical solutions to the unemployment crisis currently gripping this nation.' I would have thought that if the Australian Democrats were fair dinkum they would have said `explore creative but practical solutions to the unemployment crisis such as—' and then given us definite examples. There is not a single example in the motion. Why? Because they do not have any solutions.

What makes me so wild in this debate is that there are people who seek to portray themselves as the champions of the oppressed who come in here accusing this government of having absolute contempt for the unemployed, but you yourselves cannot come up with one single policy statement on the issue, other than if we go surfing on the net. What do we find about the Australian Democrats issues sheet on unemployment? It states:
Redefining Work . With dramatic changes in our society and our economy, a goal of every Australian having work is an impossibility.

That is the Democrat policy. If you believe that every Australian cannot have a job, you tell us, Senator Lees, what is the acceptable rate of unemployment for this nation? I tell the Senate that the only acceptable rate for unemployment is zero, and that is what we are working towards.

BREAK.PARA: We may not achieve that goal, and I accept that, but we will work day and night to get the unemployment level right down. We will not accept that soft cop‐out of saying, `It's impossible to give every Australian a job, so let's forget about it. Let's just condemn Labor and Liberal but not come up with any policy solutions.' If you had definite policy solutions, you would have got up in your introductory speech, Senator Lees, and told the Senate what the acceptable rate of unemployment was, how your policies would in fact reduce the numbers and what the numbers would be at the end of the implementation of your policies. But we know what your policy is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz, can I just ask for a bit less bashing on the desk please.
—Oh, excuse me, Madam Deputy President.
—I think you might be causing some problems for the ears of the people who are trying to monitor this, and if it were broadcast—it is not broadcast today but it is—

—It is not broadcast, Madam Deputy President. If you wish to interrupt my speeches on the basis of how I conduct myself when I am not outside standing orders, I might give you some kind reminders as well.
—Your speech is very good, Senator, but—
—Oh, I don't need that school teacher sort of comment.
—I am concerned about the thumping on the desk and the effect that that can have on people's ears in the monitoring booth.
—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that Senator Abetz has made a reflection on the chair which he should withdraw.
—What is the reflection?
—I did not hear that, Senator Cook. I am quite happy for Senator Abetz to continue. I am just trying to be kind to everybody and I am trying not stop your flow either, Senator Abetz.

—Madam Deputy President, if I become somewhat passionate about this issue, I am sure that at least the unemployed in this country will forgive me, even if you don't. We were told by the former leader of the Australian Democrats in the Australian on Thursday, 10 October 1996 that the Democrats are developing a niche role as the nation's intellectual opposition whose solution for unemployment is that you cannot have a job for everybody in Australia, so why bother.

BREAK.PARA: Unlike the Australian Democrats, we are trying and we do have some very good policies in place. One of the important strategies, of course, is deficit reduction, and we have handled that very well and very successfully. You know it. You are embarrassed about it, but the Australian people are thanking us for it.

The government is working to create real jobs, and this strategy has already contributed to strong economic growth in Australia. An aggressive deficit reduction program has significantly contributed to the lowest interest rate and inflation rate environment seen in Australia for many years. Indeed, I think it was only yesterday that other figures came out which were excellent in that regard. We are getting the policies in place.

The new workplace relations framework has given employers greater operational flexibility and is improving productivity in the workplace. This will encourage employers to recruit as the economy grows. We are expanding vocational education and training programs in schools. This will provide senior secondary students with structured on‐ and off‐the‐job training which is recognised by industry. But, when we work in concert with McDonald's, you belittle our activities and you belittle the activities of McDonald's.

Further assistance to enter the work force is available through the jobs pathway program with the assistance of employment brokers. New apprenticeships will provide expanded training opportunities, including for those disadvantaged in their access to vocational education and training. The government is spending $550 million over the next two years to support more than 220,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships.

The list goes on of the initiatives that we as a government have taken over the past 18 months. We reject the Democrat proposition that we cannot get a job for every Australian. We are determined to achieve that task. We will work tirelessly to achieve it. I reject the Democrat motion. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move an amendment to the urgency motion as circulated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice and at the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Faulkner moving an amendment to the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept this suggestion that the urgency motion be amended. The provisions are, of course, that this has to be done by leave. There is a very good reason why the provisions are that it has to be done by leave—for the very simple reason that this is a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are of the belief that this is a matter of urgency. They have brought the motion to the chamber today, and the Labor Party had ample opportunity to bring their own urgency motion should they have so wished. They chose not to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —We circulated an amendment.

—The Labor Party seeks to amend this motion to delete any reference to its own culpability. We have had 13 years of Labor government in this country and 13 years of high unemployment—higher unemployment than exists now. In fact, the unemployment rate at the last election was higher than it is now. This government is trying to do something about rectifying the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my understanding that even the Democrats agree this motion should not be amend ed. We in the government will disagree with the Democrats on the original motion, but what we in this government will not do is give the opposition leave to amend this urgency motion so that they can just delete any reference to their own culpability.

This is a stunning indictment of the attitude of the Labor Party—a stunning indictment which saw the people opposite thrown off the treasury bench at the last election. Why, I ask honourable senators, were the Labor Party thrown out of office at the last election? Because they were arrogant. Why at the last election did the people of Australia throw the Labor Party out of government? Because the Labor Party refused to accept the fact that they were responsible for the economic malaise in this country.

The Labor Party refused to accept the fact that they were responsible for unemployment. The Labor Party refused to accept the fact that they were responsible for high interest rates. The Labor Party refused to accept the fact that they were responsible for record bankruptcies. Now what do we see? We see an urgency motion brought by the Democrats, and the Labor Party seeks to continue their old ways. This is not the new Labor Party. This is not even the reconstructed Labor Party. This is the old, unreconstructable Labor Party.

No matter whom they get to defect to them, they are still the same old `head in the sand, we're not responsible for the economic malaise in this country, even though we were in government for 13 years' Labor Party. That is why the Australian people, with a stunning blow, threw the Labor Party off the treasury benches at the last election. This debate today is proof to the Australian electorate that the Labor Party do not wish to be a responsible political party in this country. They are a party of political opportunists.

I understand that the Democrats do not wish to have this motion amended. I think I have made the point for the government. Senator Lees may wish to speak to the suspension of standing orders, but it will be very clear that the government will be voting against the suspension of standing orders. We are here. We are happy to debate this motion that Senator Lees has brought on. This government has some very positive things it wants to do. This government has very positive plans. This government, as Senator Abetz has shown, will not accept anything other than our best efforts to reduce unemployment.

We can have a sensible debate here about what is the best way to reduce unemployment, and I think that is what Senator Lees wants to do, but we will not allow the ALP to run away. In the words of former President Reagan, `You can run, but you can't hide.' There is no hiding place for the Labor Party in this chamber today. Senator Cook may want to smirk. He is smirking because he is feeling embarrassed. Senator Cook has been caught out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hiding his own Easter eggs.
—Senator Quirke, we may actually excuse you because you were not part of the Labor government that got thrown out of office.
—He was part of the one that wrecked a bank!

—He was part of the Labor Party that wrecked the State Bank of South Australia. We know what the Labor Party are up to. They do not want to face up to the facts and, until the Labor Party face up to the fact that they are responsible for the economic destruction of this nation, the people will never trust the Labor Party. It does not matter whom they get to defect to them, the people will never trust them, will never vote for them and they will never sit on the treasury benches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the motion that has been moved by Senator Mackay. Senator Mackay wants to amend the motion that is before the chamber. The two speakers we have heard thus far in the debate on the urgency motion are the proponents of the motion—the Democrats—and the government. Senator Mackay, in my view rightly, believes that the motion is deficient and ought to be changed to reflect the reality of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are to be congratulated for bringing on a debate in this chamber about unemployment. There is no doubt that it is the most important question in Australia today. I am somewhat surprised that in raising the issue of unemployment—the most important debate we could have—they are intolerant of any proposed change to the motion. They then put that proposed change as a question to this chamber to ascertain the support for the change but simply want to cleave to their own motion. If we are going to have a serious debate about unemployment then all points of view should be heard.

All Senator Mackay wants to do is put a point of view which varies a little from the view which the Democrats wish to put. It would be reasonable for that motion to be accepted and for the chamber to have the opportunity to hear the argument on it and then vote accordingly. Anything less than allowing that procedure to unfold would be to inhibit the ability to properly discuss this issue. If we truly believe that unemployment is the most serious question—and I do and my party does—and if other people in this chamber believe this to be the case then they will be prepared to listen to points of view other than their own.

We have had the pyrotechnics of the schoolboy debating champion from the other side and it is a desperation call if ever I have heard one. All Senator O'Chee has to do is look at the polls to understand why people have drifted away from the government—and its response to unemployment—and are in increasing numbers favouring Labor and our attitude to managing what is a serious and concerning problem for this nation.

I am not going to engage in the same histrionics as Senator O'Chee. The fire, brimstone and bluster which he employed were necessary to cover his embarrassment. You are embarrassed, Senator O'Chee, because you know that people do not believe you and in the most recent polling have been prepared to indicate that by indicating support for the Australian Labor Party or the minor parties in this chamber. So bluster away but do not think that there is anything credible in what you have to say.

I want to conclude before my time is up in order to enable this debate to roll on, as I think that it is a serious debate. I implore the government and the minor parties here to allow what ordinary Australians would regard as a fundamental democratic opportunity—that is, allow Senator Mackay to put an amendment which is at variance to the principal motion so that this chamber can vote on it. Let us do that and get on with the substance of this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I do want to get on with the substance of this debate. I take issue with Senator Cook's idea that to have a serious debate we need to effectively gut the motion. The motion is written as it is because we are concerned about the 3.3 million jobs that have been lost over the last 10 years. We cannot just look in isolation at the last 18 months. We are looking at the bigger picture, the longer term reasons for the steady loss of jobs in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it most interesting that this side of the chamber seem to believe that to have a real debate they have to be left out of it—that we should only debate the current government's policies. I suggest to Senator Cook that, if it is his wish to just look at the policies of this government, we move another motion next week dealing with just that. This motion is written as it is because we believe we have to go back in time and look right through the growth of this idea that the economic rationalist ideal will somehow solve the jobs and unemployment problem. Obviously, I will be voting against this motion. If that is unsuccessful, we will not be supporting any changes to the motion that we have already moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak for very long. I support Senator O'Chee in refusing Senator Mackay leave to move her amendment. In relation to Senator Cook's contribution, I indicate that I have not heard such platitudinous self‐serving rubbish in this place for a long time. His comments about wanting to talk about employment really amounted simply to removing from the motion Labor's culpability for the unemployment problem that we have.

BREAK.PARA: I cannot say that I feel that warmly about the wording of the motion proposed by the Democrats. It seems to me to be a motion that seeks to apportion blame rather than find solutions. It is purely political on that basis. In that sense, I have some contempt for the motion itself. If you are going to apportion blame then it is platitudinous rubbish for Senator Cook to come in here and suggest that somehow Labor ought to be taken out of that debate. He would have done better to offer some sensible contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I think quite often a lot of debates that go on in this place and a few other places around Australia could be described as a waste of time. I do not think this one is really a waste of time, but we could say that time could probably be better spent on other things. As I understand it, this refusal by the government to accept what is a reasonable amendment to the motion will mean that the debate will be cut short.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to respond to Senator Abetz. I am not going to respond to Senator O'Chee. I am not going to respond to the advice given by the junior minister in the chamber, the Minister for Justice (Senator Vanstone), who started to give some gratuitous advice about events in South Australia. Instead, I say that this motion is, in my view, fundamentally flawed.

One of the reasons I am making some remarks now is that I think this will be one of the few opportunities I will have here today to make a few of these remarks. In the first place, I do agree with one thing that the minister said. The minister said a moment ago that this is full of negative stuff about two governments who, in their own way—albeit, I suspect, this government's incompetent way—dealt with a very important issue in Australia. At the end of the day, I can understand why the Democrats want to get some product differentiation at work in respect of this question. I can understand that because, after the South Australian election, they were having a pretty good time until Wednesday last week. In fact, I think the Democrats—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where's that—South Australia? What happened?

—For four days in South Australia the sun was shining on them but, unfortunately, on Wednesday afternoon last week, if you had not been watching TV or listening to the radio, you would have seen a strange thing happening on every electric pole in South Australia. All of the Democrat election signs came down in unison very quickly because they actually had someone on it who they wanted to make sure was not going to get any more publicity.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. What we are meant to be discussing today is why we should suspend standing orders. Senator Quirke is not mounting any case when he discusses the South Australian election. I would ask you to bring the speaker to order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes, with concern, the continuing failure of the Australian Government to develop a comprehensive industry policy, as demonstrated by:

PARA.TAB: (i) its failure to respond effectively to key reports, such as the Mortimer report, the Goldsworthy report and the Metal Trades Industry Association report, Make or Break ,

(ii) its failure to come up with any initiatives on industry policy apart from those elements of the Australian Labor Party's policy which it has been forced to accept, including the responses on the automotive and textile, clothing and footwear industries and on ship and book bounties,
(iii) its inability to respond decisively to the BHP announcement on Newcastle in order to ensure that Australia continues to have a viable steelmaking capacity,
(iv) its gross mishandling of the anti-dumping issue and its failure to keep its election promise to cut the maximum time for an anti-dumping case to 155 days,
(v) its mishandling of the pharmaceutical industry issue, which has put at risk millions of dollars of investment and hundreds of new jobs, and

(vi) its failure to act upon the recommendations relating to strategies to develop an Australian information industry contained in the Information Industries Taskforce (Goldsworthy) and the Industrial Property Advisory Committee (Cutler) reports, including its failure to recognise the critical role government procurement plays in this sector in terms of establishing export credentials amongst small-to medium-sized enterprises;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) condemns the Government's $4 billion cuts to industry programs, noting that overall budget cuts have:

PARA.TAB: (i) taken approximately half a percentage point off gross domestic product,
(ii) slashed industrial research and development from $820 million in the 1995-96 financial year to a projected $286 million in the 1997-98 financial year, and
(iii) reduced the attractiveness of Australia as a destination for major new industrial investment;

SPEECH.PARA: (c) deplores the Government's failure to respond to growing job insecurity, particularly amongst workers in the manufacturing sector, and its failure to take any steps to deliver on its election commitment to create 200 000 new manufacturing jobs by the year 2000; and
(d) calls on the Government, as a matter of urgency, to:

PARA.TAB: (i) respond positively and comprehensively to the Mortimer blueprint on industry policy, including the approach to growth targets, strategic action plans for key industries, and the 5-year funding model,
(ii) reverse its cuts to industry programs, and
(iii) recommit to the 200 000 manufacturing jobs target.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important notice of motion. It deals with the essential question that Australians want an answer to—where will the jobs come from to provide employment for the unemployed and for those who will be leaving school in about six weeks and facing the jobs market? What can be done to allay the concerns of those parents who are worried about the employment future of their children?

This is a motion that deals with industry policy—an unfashionable area of economic debate in this country but one absolutely essential to get the engines of industry grinding into growth so that employment opportunities open up. The motion states:
That the Senate—
(a) notes, with concern, the continuing failure of the Australian Government to develop a comprehensive industry policy—
It then goes to a number of subpoints, which I will address in my remarks later. It also states that the Senate:
condemns the Government's $4 billion cuts to industry programs, noting that overall budget cuts have—

The motion then goes through the effect on economic growth, the slash to industrial research and development funding and the reduction in Australia's attractiveness as a destination for investment. It also states that the Senate:

deplores the Government's failure to respond to growing job insecurity, particularly amongst workers in the manufacturing sector, and its failure to take any steps to deliver on its election commitment to create 200 000 new manufacturing jobs by the year 2000—

That is something that, in office, the government has not been prepared to re‐endorse. The motion then sets out a program of at least three steps the government can take in order to do something about this important front of national policy development. I will be joined in this debate by my colleagues Senators Lundy, Bishop, Murphy and Campbell. They will certainly add to the entire argument I put.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks, Peter.
—I am sorry?
—You said Senator Campbell is going to add to the argument.

—Yes, he is. Senator George Campbell is a fine acquisition to the Labor Party on this side of the parliament and has a very deep knowledge of industry policy as a practitioner from the coalface. He is someone who worked with Australia's major corporations trying to develop a bipartisan approach to industry policy and job creation in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing that should be defined when confronting this issue is the role of government. The role of government is to give long, strong and dependable signals to the private sector in Australia as to what the framework for economic growth for this country is. In other words, the government has to have a vision. It has to know where it is going. It has to be able to then put in place a series of steps that are credible and that command community support in order to get to its destination.

What is the single, strongest criticism that comes from the private sector in Australia about this government? The single, strongest criticism that comes from the private sector is that the government lacks vision. It makes day-to-day, short-term decisions. It does not have an overview of the direction of the development of the Australian economy, and some of its decisions are contradictory. In other words, the private sector of Australia—the sector that the government acknowledges in many of its press releases is the engine of economic growth for this country—is confused, does not understand what is happening and is at odds often with the government about the direction of economic growth for this country and what it believes and depends on as being the directions the government should take.

Why is that so important? If industry lacks the confidence to make investments because it is uncertain of the climate into which they have been plunged by the government, they will act cautiously and not make those investments. Jobs that could be created will not be created. Opportunities that could be taken will be taken on cautiously and not to their full potential. That means, in short, that many more Australians will be out of work and many more opportunities for Australian industry to grow will be stunted and will not be able to develop.

Why is there this confusion? Let us go back to the 1996-97 budget. Whatever is said about that budget and the rationale for it, let us look at the immediate effect of it. The government made across-the-board cuts to government expenditure in that budget. It did not differentiate between the types of cuts it made. Therefore, it cut government expenditure that aided and fuelled economic growth, as well as government expenditure on the outlay side that did not directly contribute to economic growth.

In other words, the government cut out or reduced the amount of funding that went to industry in order for it to grow. It took a narrow, accountant's view of the budget—that is, cut outlays and get a balance on your bottom line. It did not take a creative view of the budget. It did not say, `What expenditure returns growth to the economy, takes people off the unemployment queue, puts them in jobs, causes them not to be beneficiaries of unemployment benefits but contributors to the budget through the paying of tax and fuels other job developments?' The government did not take that approach to the budget. It took a narrow, accountancy approach.

As a consequence of that, two major things have happened. The Australian economy has been flat and the budget predictions for growth last year have been undershot. The prediction for growth was 3¾ per cent. The growth that was actually obtained was 2.4 per cent. This year, the target for growth is 3¾ per cent. The growth that will be obtained will be around three per cent. That is not my view. That is the view of any sample of forecasting economists in both the private and the public sector.

So what we have is a government that has stunned the economy and made it somnolent. Despite any number of interest rate cuts we might have, the economy has failed to respond. Why is the Australian private sector up in arms against this government? Because the economy is so flat, aggregate demand—that is, the market which buys the goods and services produced by the private sector—is flat and people are not consuming. Therefore, production runs have to be slowed down and stopped or stockpiled because there is no-one out there with confidence in the future to buy the goods and services produced. Without that market, no profits are able to be made, no report to shareholders is able to be given about a return on investment and there is a general lack of confidence and leadership. That is exactly the situation in the Australian economy at the first level, the macro level.

At the micro level, what has happened is that $4 billion dollars worth of industry support has been removed from Australian industry and, at a time when they needed that boost of confidence in order to win markets, they have lost support from the very government they believed would support them. So we find that massive cuts have been made, for example, in research and development.

Australia is one of the most creative countries in the world. We create new knowledge in science and technology well ahead of our population or our GDP. The trick for Australia is to convert that new knowledge into new products and new services. By cutting down incentives for research and development, we remove an essential building block to creating products or services which the market of the future will consume. That means that Australian manufacturers and exporters are unable to produce products which can hold their place in the market and we then decline as an economic power in the region. You cut research and development and creativity and the ability to be competitive with new ideas and new products in the marketplace are affected.

Did the Australian government take any view about research and development, about how we build on our science excellence to create products for the new age in the next millennium? Yes, they did; they took a negative view and cut the funding. We now see that rather than $800 million‐odd being spent on R&D—and it would have been spent had our government policies remained in place—it is now reduced to over $250 million, a reduction of $550 million in research and development, which means a withdrawal of investment in Australia's future.

So when I say on the micro‐economic front, `What has the government done?', what it has done is choke off creativity in the Australian industry sector and put us behind in the race with other powers to capture the markets of this world with our products and processes. It has sat waving goodbye as Australian brands have gone overseas. That is what the Howard government has done.

We have this absolute need for direction and vision for Australian industry. After the wreckage of these cuts was beginning to make itself felt in the economy, there was a wake‐up call. `We have to have an industry policy,' became the rallying slogan in government ranks. So they commissioned the Mortimer report and the Goldsworthy report. They did that out of recognition that they did not have an industry policy and did not understand the needs of industry. While keeping some remnants of our policy, they decided to create one of their one.

While this is happening, industry awaits direction. Opportunities that could have existed are forgone and there is an interruption in industry strategic planning for growth while they wait to find out what the government wants to do to lead the economy. The trouble is, these reports, which took time and are impressive, have been delivered and we have been waiting four months for a response from the government. Not just members of this parliament but Australian industry leaders want to know what the government response is to these reports so that they can plan their growth targets for next year, how they can take advantage of any government programs to create new investment and what will be their strategy for getting into international markets.

When they do that, they will know how many jobs they can take on next year. But the government cannot make up its mind what to do. We have continual leaking from the public service in Canberra about one government department fighting a turf battle with another government department over who shall take over what type of program and whether or not one department will win that battle—arm wrestling between bureaucrats—while industry growth in Australia stagnates and jobs are put on the backburner. That is exactly the scenario we face right now. That is why bodies like the Business Council, like the government's favourite business mates, the ACCI, and others are very critical of this government.

This is not a presentation of an opposition view; this is the opposition putting a view which is representative of Australian industry which now feels disenchanted and unled by the direction of this government, industry that was so moved by the concern that it commissioned, at considerable expense to itself, the MTIA report, the Make or break report, a report in which Australian metal manufacturers ask the question, `How will this economy be made or how will this economy be broken?' They have put down a series of recommendations which they too expect the Australian government to respond to. What has been the response? A deafening silence has been the response because the government cannot make up its mind.

We cannot have a situation where the economy drifts, where jobs are not created and where the circumstances that face Aus tralian industry, unable to plan for its future, remain. That is why this motion ought to be carried in the Senate today.

The other thing I want to say about the 1996‐97 budget and, indeed, the budget brought down this year—the 1997‐98 budget—is that both budgets have a common thread: massive cuts to public expenditure across‐the‐board. When one looks at the reasonings behind these cuts, one comes to this conclusion—and it is said in black print in the budget documents—that that may mean a temporary slow‐down in domestic economic growth because of a reduction in demand in the Australian economy. But the international economy is still strong and, because Australia is a trading nation, international economic growth will pull us through and the impact will not be as great.

That is not a perfect quote, but is a fair summary of what those documents say. Because we have knocked flat the Australian economy we will, nonetheless, hitch our wagon to the stronger international economies and be pulled along by them, and that is where the growth will come from.

Let us look at the international scene for a moment, because the budget strategy that underpins what has occurred here has now been knocked into a cocked hat. The American economy is the strongest in the world at the moment. It is a healthy economy, and it is the locomotive of world economic growth. It is going well and it is an important trading partner for Australia. But bear in mind that the Americans are beating up on Japan and China because the trade deficits between the US and Japan, and the US and China are too great.

The trade deficit between Australia and the United States is greater in percentage of GDP terms than the trade deficit between the US and the other two countries. Do we hear the Australian government taking the initiative to Washington in order to open up the markets in the United States for Australian products in the way that Washington is to Tokyo and Beijing for US products? Where is the Minister for Trade, Tim Fischer? He is in the Vatican getting his hat blessed; he is down in Madrid talking to the King of Spain. What is he doing in Washington to open up these markets? He has not been there recently, and he is not doing anything.

The European economy is the other major economy in the world that is not going all that well. Again, we have a trade deficit with Europe: they buy less from us than we buy from them. The European economies are jogging along at about 2½ per cent growth and they have high levels of unemployment. They themselves are searching for an answer in the present circumstances.

Then we turn to Asia. The first thing one must say about Asia is that, currently, South‐East Asia has been plunged into a currency crisis. The bubble in property in Thailand has burst. The Thai baht is in free fall against the US dollar, and there is a massive devaluation, in excess of 30 per cent, going on in Thailand. That contagion has been caught in Indonesia which, like Thailand, has now put itself in the hands of the International Monetary Fund. That is to say, if you were a private company, you have put yourself in the hands of the receivers. That is what Thailand and Indonesia have done. They have put themselves in the hands of the IMF.

The same contagion affects Malaysia and, to a lesser extent, the Philippines. We have seen devaluations in their currencies of over 30 per cent. What does that mean to Australia? Our currency is sound and I have great confidence in it. But what does that mean to Australia? It means that the products manufactured in those countries are cheaper than they were yesterday, they can come into Australia at cheaper prices, thereby undercutting Australian products in our markets. That is the first effect.

The second effect is that imports cost more money in the domestic economies of the countries affected by massive currency devaluation. In ASEAN countries, where you have tariff barriers of around 30 per cent, with a currency devaluation of 30 per cent, you now effectively have a tariff barrier of 60 per cent. Australian products trying to be sold into those markets have a higher barrier to leap over. The higher price of imports into those countries means high inflation for them as well as a depression of living standards. They are facing very difficult times. Because these are key markets for Australia, and they will buy less goods from Australia, the reliance on international economic strengths to overcome the cuts to the Australian domestic economy is not there to the extent that Treasury thought it was when it wrote the budgets in 1996 and 1997.

Let me demonstrate the proposition that domestic economic demand is down, but international economic demand will pull Australia through. That was a theory. Domestic economic demand remains down but world economic demand, while strong in the United States, is slack in Europe and down in Asia. So we are not being pulled through, and the expectations for stronger growth in the latter part of this year and early next year have to be seen against the impact of the currency crisis in Asia. At the same time as we are pushing along at a very slow level, imports from that region of the world will be cheaper in our markets thereby displacing jobs in Australia.

Ask yourself: what is the government's reaction to that? Again, there is a silence. Is there a comprehensive plan on behalf of the government to deal with that? No, there is not. Where is Tim Fischer? What is he doing about opening up those economies, working with the International Monetary Fund that is helping to rescue those economies, lowering the level of tariff barriers so that they can overcome the problem of the lack of confidence in their currencies and creating a more level playing field in this region with lower tariffs, and opening up those economies to the world, in the way in which the IMF wants to take them? What are we doing about arguing that? Have we been out there? No, we have not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, what a load of rubbish!
—We have not been out there, Senator Campbell. You just do not know. That is where we should be and we are not there.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government, I rise to oppose the motion by Senator Cook. I will be ably supported by Senators Lightfoot, McGauran and Coonan. Senator Cook, how wrong can you be? Let me start with a quote from Graham Richardson which appeared in the Bulletin this year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest failure of successive Labor governments from 1983 to 1996 was the failure to develop a coherent industry policy.

Senator Cook, you have criticised the government for its budget measures of last year. But what have the industry reports been saying? He was critical of the government for not responding urgently to those reports, but the government is doing so. Let me start with the summary of the recommendations from the MTIA report entitled Make or break . It says:
1. Continue to deliver good macro‐economic results.
2. Fundamental tax reform.

What was this government's first priority when it came to power? It was getting the macro‐economic settings right. As the report says, it is the highest priority. The Mortimer report says the same thing, that we should get the fundamentals right. That is what we have done; that is what we have delivered. Those reports were demanding that we should have a stable economic environment for business investment, for encouraging jobs. That means low inflation, and that has led to low interest rates. Why did we do it? We did it because of the mess left behind by the Labor government. They were the big spenders. They are the big taxers. Pity the poor taxpayers.

Let me again quote some figures, and remind the Senate and the community of the last four years of the Labor government when tax revenue was up 30 per cent. Which business had a 30 per cent increase in revenue over that four‐year period? The then Commonwealth government. It sold off the silver—$9 billion worth of assets: Qantas and half the Commonwealth Bank—and then it went out and borrowed another $70 billion, and spent the lot.

At the same time the then government had the hide to tell the community that the government was running in surplus. The then government confused the community. Basically, it would not come clean as to the exact state of the accounts. When we came into power we found out that, instead of being in surplus, as they claimed, we were actually $10 billion in deficit. What did that mean? It meant that the then Labor government had spent $10 billion more than it got in. That is what was going on.

Every household knows that you cannot go on spending more than you get in. You just cannot do that. You cannot rely on selling the house or selling the furniture to pay for the groceries. It does not work. So we in the new government had to cut programs across the board to meet the $10 billion deficit. The cuts virtually had to be across most programs to reduce the cost of the administration of government. Of course, some of the industry programs were cut. Everyone had to take some pain in order to get the macro‐economic variables right. As Make or break says, we have got to get the macro settings right. That is the first priority. We have done that.

What constraints were there on economic growth in Australia in the past? The constraints were inflation and the current account deficit. Those constraints were stopping Australia's future growth. Inflation is now well and truly under control, and the current account deficit is coming under control. The very low inflation is a great encouragement for investment. A stable, low inflation environment really does encourage wise investment. It certainly discourages speculative investment, which happens in periods of high inflation.

Interest rates, as a consequence, have come down from the very high rates that we had in the Labor era to the lowest in about 30 years. Since we have been in government, which is only 18 months, official interest rates have come down 2½ per cent. Housing rates have come down four per cent. Ten‐year bonds are currently at the extraordinarily low level of 6.3 per cent. The risk premium on 10‐year bonds—US 10‐year bonds versus Australian 10‐year bonds—is now close to zero. It was 2.2 per cent higher when Mr Keating was in power. In other words, the world now judges us to be a safe place to invest money, relative to the USA.

The Labor Party was dishonest and said we were in surplus. It turned out that we were actually running at a loss. What has this government done? We have made commitments to change the financial reporting system so that that can never happen again. The community will never be misled. We have made a commitment. We are in the process of adopting accrual accounting, whole of government reporting; in other words, a balance sheet for government. The charter of budget honesty, which sets the scene, will produce openness and transparency for all in the long‐term future. As I said before, the macro‐economic settings are the government's first priority. We have fixed inflation and we have fixed interest rates. That is what this government demanded, and that is what this government has delivered.

What else has this government done for the business community in the short time of 18 months? It has delivered reform in industrial relations. We needed a change in industrial relations in order to get away from the `us' and `them' attitude of the past; to encourage managers and workers to come to agreement within the workplace and work cooperatively together. That is what we have to achieve. We have changed the legislation to encourage that situation, but perhaps not as far as we would have liked to go. It is absolutely criminal that the Labor Party and the Democrats have stopped the government's unfair dismissal legislation going through the Senate, because it offered further incentives to free up the labour market for small business.

Another positive thing that we have done is signal a change to the Corporations Law. We also recently signalled that we will change the fundraising regime—particularly as it applies to the small end of business—for raising equity.

Tax is the next big business issue. Major reports have emphasised that we have got to fix the tax regime. What is Labor's policy on tax? They are running away from it. They do not want to have anything to do with tax reform. We have already made a substantial change in tax for the small business arena. We have given capital gains tax relief to small business. We are allowing rollovers for small business of up to $5 million from one business into another. As an incentive we will allow people selling their business to use up to half a million dollars from the sale, free of capital gains tax, for retirement purposes.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced two months ago that tax is the next major business issue that this government will address. We are looking forward, not backwards like the Labor Party. The tax system in Australia is in a mess—there is no doubt about that. It discourages investment, it discourages jobs, it discourages exports and it is basically unfair. The government has signalled that we want to change that system and we will do so. The system is basically unfair.

I might add that the wholesale sales tax that we currently have is basically a tax on manufacturers because services are not touched at all. It is manufacturers who are hardest hit by the wholesale sales tax. We basically need a broad based indirect tax, and that is being addressed by the government. The government is committed to tax reform, which is the No. 2 issue for business, to encourage investment, growth and jobs for our children and our grandchildren. The government is also committed to no increase in the overall tax burden.

Today, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) again emphasised the Consultative Task Force on Taxation, of which I am proud to be the chair. I propose to seek leave to table a copy of the press release by the Treasurer, which sets out that we are seeking submissions from the community on, firstly, what is wrong with the tax system and, secondly, any proposals for change. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Turning to the various industry reports to government—Mortimer, Goldsworthy and Cutler, of which I have copies—the government has said that it is considering same. They are substantive issues and the government is giving them due consideration. Again, I emphasise that these reports place first priority on getting the macro‐economic setting correct. That has been the government's first priority and we have done that. What else is needed? The short answer is: not much.
—Not much?

—That is right, not much. Senator Bishop, you were present yesterday when Alan Oxley gave a speech in the library. As he said, the manufacturing industry is doing well in Australia. Let me quote the statistics. Manufacturing exports are currently greater than agricultural exports. Elaborately transformed manufacturing exports have been growing at 15 per cent a year for the last 10 years, and they continue to grow. If things are growing, why does it need to be changed? All exports are growing at half that rate—eight per cent—and, as Mr Oxley said yesterday, about half of the elaborately transformed exports have zero help from the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Many particular industries are claiming that they want government help, but who is going to pay? Who are you going to suggest pays the bill for additional support? Who are you going to tax? Are the battlers going to pay more to pay a particular industry? We are suggesting that the emphasis has to be on education and services.

The fact is, as the Cutler report points out, that the thing that we are really competitive in in a world sense is the excellence of our people, particularly in the technical arena, in information technology and engineering. We are world class and very economical by world standards. They are the things we have to be encouraging, and that is where we need encouragement, and I am sure the government will do something about encouraging that.

A few people from both sides were in Ireland recently. There has been huge investment in Ireland. Whilst the world believes that this has been largely tax driven, I do not believe that that is so. The government's IDA reported that it believed that a lot of the investment is because a lot of the investors, especially from North America, regard Ireland as an easy entry into Europe.

The people in Ireland are well educated. There is emphasis on the three R's in education and, what is more, they even teach grammar in schools in Ireland. The tax breaks that are available in Ireland were seen as a bonus beyond that, but they were not the fundamentals driving the investment. They are the messages for Australia. We cannot match those tax breaks because the Labor Party has committed us and we do not have any spare taxes, unless you can suggest who we should tax. We cannot do that.

With regard to the information technology industry, the government has accepted the recommendations and has appointed a minister for the information economy. The National Office of Information Economy is in the process of being set up. With regard to R&D, Senator Cook claims that the government has slashed industrial R&D from $820 million in 1995‐96 to $286 million this current year.

This reduced figure is only a reflection of the estimated cost to revenue of the tax concession for R&D which reflects the government's decision to abolish the Labor Party's syndication scheme, which was basically being rorted. It is not an accurate reflection of expenditure on R&D because it completely ignores the government's new R&D start program and the innovation investment fund, both of which will provide about $520 million over the next four years.

In summary, the government has stuck to the fundamentals. It has fixed the macro‐economic settings for business. It is about to tackle taxation, which is the highest priority for business, to encourage investment, to get investment going, and to provide jobs for our children and our grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The last 18 months have been a low point for industry policy and particularly for businesses involved in manufacturing industry. The Democrats have stood shoulder to shoulder with industry groups to oppose very damaging short‐sighted cuts to vital industry policy programs such as the R&D tax concessions, bounties, the export market development grant scheme, the DIFF scheme and the imposition of a three per cent duty on imported business inputs that previously entered duty free.

SPEECH.PARA: I have described these sorts of policies as not about avoiding picking winners but rather as picking on winners. The coalition government's view, certainly in the first 18 months, has been that if a program worked it would cut it back because expenditure was no longer needed. That is a singularly short‐ sighted policy which has affected jobs, investment and growth.

This view, which is known as the Treasury view, that the best thing government can do for industry is absolutely nothing, in line with an extreme view of how the market works, is simply out of step with international best industry policy practice. It is out of step with the policies and experiences of those countries with successful industry policy and impressive economic and jobs growth.

The Democrats and the Senate have had some successes in minimising the damage the coalition has sought to inflict. For example, the Senate—and I draw your attention to particularly me, Senator Cook and Senator Harradine—did succeed in extending the shipbuilding bounty and preventing the abolition of book, machine tools and robotics bounties ahead of schedule. We did succeed in retaining eligibility of trusts and airfares under the EMDG scheme. We are currently pressuring the government to tighten and improve Australia's anti-dumping legislation, and I expect we will be successful in that area. Anti-dumping is an area in which hopefully the government is moving in the right direction.

We have welcomed the outcomes focused approach adopted by Mortimer and the MTIA reports and their endorsement of the view that governments can and should be involved in pro‐business, investment enhancing, jobs friendly policies. We look forward to the moist or the damp group of the coalition actually triumphing over the hard and dry people who predominated in the first 18 months.

I hope for the sake of the 800,000 unemployed, the long-term unemployed and the 500,000 underemployed Australians that the government does listen to Mortimer and other hands‐on campaigners and reverses its hands‐off policy directions of the last 18 months, especially in the areas of innovation, investment and job creation.

In the short time available I will do a quick stocktake of some of the key developments that we think are important. One of the most deplorable actions undertaken by the coalition has been the savage cuts to business R&D assistance. Time and time again I, Senator Cook and other senators have asked: have you done a cost‐benefit analysis? What does the ledger tell you will be the effects on jobs, investment and growth of these actions? Regrettably, the coalition persisted with the view that business R&D assistance should be cut.

Given that less than two per cent of Australian based firms invest in R&D, given that our regional neighbours are achieving substantially higher annual average growth rates in business R&D expenditure, given that Australian business investment in R&D has peaked at only 0.7 cent of GDP, which is far less than developed countries such as Japan, the USA and Switzerland, to name three, each of which invests around two per cent—nearly three times that of Australia—of GDP per year in business research and development, the short-sighted nature of the government's R&D decisions cannot be overestimated—short-term budget revenue gains for long-term jobs, investment and growth damage.

Investing in R&D is crucial to ensuring sustainable growth, improving our export performance, improving our intellectual capital and reversing the brain drain of some of our best and brightest in the academic, scientific and business world. Few disagree now but the decision to wind back R&D assistance was one of the coalition's worst decisions. Even the Industry Commission, which we all know the Democrats believe is a dry and hardline economic rationalist think tank, did support the 150 per cent tax concession for R&D.

Labor rightly sought to prevent the cuts to the 150 per cent tax concession scheme, but it wrongly sought to defend the R&D syndication scheme. The R&D syndication scheme did boost R&D investment levels but there were serious doubts about its cost-effectiveness. There were also clear suggestions that the scheme was being manipulated by some of the major financial institutions. Allegations of creative accounting were widespread.

The Labor Party needed to acknowledge that a scheme that it had developed and implemented was not cost-effective and was possibly being manipulated. Labor was and remains still too close to its spell in government to admit this. Labor often remains unable to accept that the new government, the coalition government, not only has a right but has a duty to constantly review industry assistance programs and to improve, replace and even abolish programs which are not effective or not sufficiently effective. That is not our problem. The problem is that the government cut; it did not create.

The government did not simply abolish the syndication scheme. At least this time the government cut something and did replace it. It replaced it with the Start program, and for this we supported the government, as did Labor, I seem to recall. However, I am not convinced that the Start program is adequate, and I believe our whole package of R&D assistance schemes needs to be reviewed, overhauled and boosted. The Democrats do not want a mere return to the programs that Labor had in place.

Not all those programs still need to be alive today, although some, such as the EMDG scheme, were outstanding and need to be given the approbation they deserve. If Labor at times appears guilty of blindly supporting its old programs, even if they are suspect, it must recognise that it can bring disrepute to the argument that industry assistance programs and active interventionist methods are necessary. That can be seen to be support for a partisan view, not for a policy measure which has integrity in its own right.

There are many instances when government intervention is warranted, when market forces left to themselves will not deliver outcomes most beneficial to the community. I mean `community' in the broader sense—the business, social and national community. But if parties such as Labor—a party which is the alternative government—can actually publicly defend inefficient and potentially manipulated programs, then the public and the key opinion makers will lack confidence in government intervention.

Another appalling decision was the government's move to abolish tariff concessions on business imports. The tariff concession system allowed products to be imported duty free if there was no equivalent Australian manufac tured product. The rationale was that tariffs existed to protect Australian industries and should not apply to goods where there was no local industry to protect. The decision to abolish it caused understandable fury within industry. To his credit, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, John Moore, recognised how stupid this decision was and described it as `dreadful policy'.

Where did the idea come from? Regrettably, it came from the Labor Party. The motion before us today says that the government has failed to come up with any initiatives on industry policy apart from those it took from the ALP. Well that is one you should not have given them. After intense lobbying from industry, which was supported by the Democrats in their lobbying, the government eventually adopted the inept compromise of effectively imposing a three per cent tariff on previously exempt business imports.

The industry minister described this as the best outcome under difficult circumstances. What he did not mention was the difficult circumstances were the dry as dust hard boys in the cabinet. It was a pathetic outcome and the difficult circumstances refer to the complete ineptitude of a cabinet full of lawyers and of the Labor opposition's inability to accept that that recommendation had been wrong. Labor then completely ignored the impact on business. They wanted to impose a five per cent tariff. When the three per cent tariff came in, the Labor industry spokesperson, Simon Crean, then launched a campaign against the impact that these changes would have for consumer goods, but there was not a mention about the impact on business imports that I can find or recall.

Business warned that the changes were likely to render the scheme ineffective because claiming back the two per cent value on goods would not be worthwhile. No-one but the Democrats in the Senate took this seriously. Regrettably, it has since been revealed that applications for tariff concessions have fallen by more than two-thirds from 3,273 in 1995-96 to 1,029 in 1996‐97. This has borne out the fact that a good proportion of industry complaints were not just rhetoric but justified.

BREAK.PARA: Let us now turn to the issue of tariffs. Both Labor and the coalition are running around as the Latter‐day Saints of tariff reductions. Regrettably, they get more media exposure than we do so we are not getting the contrary view across. All of a sudden, both appeared to have discovered that unilateral tariff reductions means job losses. Yet, for a decade and a half of Labor governments who were fully supported in this by the coalition, it was the Democrats alone who strongly opposed the unilateral—and I emphasise unilateral—cuts in tariffs, quotas and bounties pursued and implemented by Labor. The coalition simply cheered them on. In other words, Labor and the coalition stood together as the conservative group supporting unilateral cuts in tariffs, quotas and bounties.

The media have been vigorous in promoting the view that the government and Labor have had an about‐face on tariffs. That they ignored the Industry Commission reports into both the car and textile, clothing and footwear industries was commendable, but this was not an about‐face; it was simply a slowing down. The economic cheer squad—those favouring tariff reductions—have been scathingly critical of the government for slowing tariff cuts while other media commentators catering for Howard's battlers came out cheering that John Howard froze tariffs and saved jobs.

But did the government and Labor really ignore the Industry Commission? Have they really done an about‐face on tariffs? We do not think so. With the aid of the media, the government has been able to perpetrate a major hoax on the Australian public because tariffs have not been frozen. It has not given up the goal of unilateral tariff reductions. Tariffs in the car industry are currently falling at a rate of 2½ per cent a year and at a rate of three per cent a year for the TCF industries, and they will continue to do so. By the year 2000, they will have fallen to a maximum rate of 15 per cent for the car industry and 25 per cent for the TCF industries.

These reductions are set to take place irrespective of what our trading partners do and irrespective of their impact on employment and investment in Australia, and that is our complaint. To adopt the Democrats' policy you would have to adopt the policy of reciprocity, and you have not. You have maintained the policy of unilateral reductions. We think it is dangerous policy considering the car industry directly employs 22,000 people and TCF industries directly employ up to 100,000 people and a further equivalent number, it is understood, of outworkers. Hundreds of thousands of employees and families are indirectly affected.

Unfortunately, the Liberal, Labor and National parties are still fundamentally opposed to reviewing these decisions. The recent decisions in both the car and TCF industries only deal with tariffs after the year 2000. So what we have in the tariff decisions is a change in timing, not a change in direction. Do they stop tariff reductions? No. On the contrary, the government has decided to unilaterally—and, once again, I emphasise the word `unilaterally'—reduce both car tariffs and TCF tariffs by the year 2005. We say it should be a reciprocal view we take relative to our competitors.

By 2005, the maximum tariff rate within TCF industries will be 17½ per cent, and this will apply to clothing and finished textiles. Other TCF products will have a maximum rate between five per cent and 10 per cent, regardless of what our competitors have or do. Isn't that the most astonishing thing—regardless of what our competitors have or do?

In the car industry tariffs will fall to 10 per cent in 2005—again, regardless of what our competitors have or do. Whether this occurs in one step as the government proposes or as a series of steps as the Industry Commission proposes is largely irrelevant. The end result is much the same.
