The end result is that tariffs are eroded unilaterally. The end result is that our tariffs will continue falling unilaterally while no regard is given to what our trading partners do.

Unilateral tariff reductions are to continue through to the year 2000 and on to the year 2005. They will occur in one step rather than in yearly steps as recommended by the commission. If anything, the supporters of unilateral tariff reduction should be elated. They are getting their tariff reductions but at the same time the battlers are cheering. The battlers have been deceived into believing that there has been a reversal on tariff policy. But still, every month, every year, the industries and the factories close down and the jobs are lost. For example, 275,000 full-time jobs have been lost every year for the last decade.

When are you going to accept that economic rationalism does not deliver the goods? You have the evidence before you. All that has occurred is that the tariff reductions have been packaged slightly differently, a temporary pause slotted in and that is all. Do not get me wrong—we at least welcome that, but it is not far enough.

Labor are claiming victory. They are saying that the government have adopted their policy. The coalition are claiming victory. They are saying, `Look at what we have done for jobs.' But there is no difference really between the Labor Party and the coalition on this because they both accept the same dry economic dogma. Both the government and Labor have remained committed to the Industry Commission view. Both Labor and the coalition have been like minded on tariffs for the past two decades. The Democrats have stood apart. Only the Democrats have consistently remained opposed to unilateral disarmament.

The coalition have faltered badly. They have failed to respond to growing job insecurity, especially for those workers in manufacturing. They have failed on their election promise to create 200,000 new manufacturing jobs. They have failed to adopt both economic and job growth targets. They have failed to adopt an industry policy which is comprehensible. What they have adopted is an intention to pursue macro and micro policy and macro and micro reform. That has a place. Without doubt, some of it will be good. Some of it will be bad, from our point of view. But we need an industry vision and direction.

The Democrats—along with the Labor Party when they have voted with us—have been able to minimise some of the damage that the coalition has sought to inflict. I assure the Senate that the Democrats will continue pressuring the government to deliver an activist, interventionist, strategic industry policy. We will continue to pressure the Labor Party to start to move away from the economic rationalist dogma they have so wrongly pursued over the last decade. I advise the Labor Party that we will support their motion if they omit subparagraph (a)(ii). If they do not, we will be unable to support their motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —The significance of this motion should not be underestimated as it represents, I believe, the false base upon which this government sold itself to the Australian people. Its alleged commitment to small business as the jobs growth engine of our economy was a phrase plastered right across its election campaign and, surprisingly, it has had the audacity to continue with it 18 months into government.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is significant because it steps out at each point the damage that this government has done to industry and business. The significance of this, in turn, goes to the very heart of what should be the priority of this government—that is, jobs, employment, job creation and what a government can do to improve the opportunity of Australians in seeking and finding secure employment.

It is interesting that the response from the government to date on this issue does not really get past the macro‐economic issues. They continue to hold up, as their one credential for industry policy, macro‐economic policy mechanisms, low inflation—

TALK.START.PARA: —The highest priority.

—Senator Gibson points out that it is the highest priority of the government. You would think that managing the economy would end up on the high priority list for any government. What I think is significant is how this government have managed to position the economy, macro‐economic policy and monetary policy at the forefront of their solution to industry development in this country. It is a pretty long bow to draw but not an unreasonable one. Unfortunately for this government, they have nothing beyond that point to demonstrate that they are providing anything in terms of support, direction or focus for the growth of business in Australia.
—What about the $1 billion investment base?

—Let me draw on a point that I would like to make specifically. This goes to the contribution of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to the MTIA conference earlier this week. Post the articulation of macro‐economic policy as being the be‐all and end‐all of industry development for this government, we get onto tax reform. So there is another layer of what this government are doing for industry policy.
—Of course there is.

—They are looking at tax reform. Congratulations to Senator Gibson and others who have taken the time to spend their whole contribution on this critical debate about industry policy and cuts to all of the elements that support industry in this country to talk about macro‐economic policy and tax reform.

BREAK.PARA: If you look at this motion, we go far beyond those two points and start looking at the substance of what is going wrong. What is the malaise in the Australian economy? The malaise lies in the heart of this government's inability to provide direction, focus, support and strategically applied incentives in a consistent manner to allow business to have confidence to grow.

We find ourselves in a situation where we have five reports on industry policy. Why do we have five reports that have come down all at once? You do not need to look too far beyond those reports to see why. Just about every one of them articulates the lack of leadership in this country as a prime reason why industry policy is floundering.

The issue of leadership, of vision, is something that was largely avoided in the election campaign. Whilst we had all the rhetoric about business being the jobs growth engine of our economy, there was no substance, and we have 18 months of government to prove that there is no substance and a proliferation of reports to try to put the substance where leadership is lacking.

The government's inability to acknowledge the important and successful structures and schemes that were put in place under Labor is an indication of the way that it is prepared to play petty politics with this critical issue. So many times we have seen areas of government support—be it in regional economic development, research and development incentives or anything else—cut back or ditched altogether and then re‐emerge in a repackaged, liberalised version of a support mechanism.

We are starting to see hints of that now. We are starting to see backdowns. We are starting to see Goldsworthy, in his report entitled The global information economy: the way ahead, talk about reinstating a R&D incentive for business in a slightly different way. We are going through a process of repackaging.

Is this responsible government? Is it responsible to take away what had been developed over a long period and had evolved to support industries—whether it be partnerships for development or the EMDG programs—and reshape and repackage them? What you have done is squander 18 months of growth. You have denied our economy who knows how many percentage points of growth through your cutbacks in this area. Ostensibly you have done all of this for the purpose of the macro‐economic measures to which Senator Gibson alluded but more covertly you have done all this to repackage it in a way which is based on pure political opportunism. You have denied this country 18 months of what should have been a pathway of expansion—a pathway of growth of R&D investment as a proportion of GDP.

I have spoken in this chamber before about the relationship between R&D investment in business and economic growth and jobs. We know that there are a number of scenarios. We know that there is a path on which Australia was travelling under Labor. It was a path of growth and improvement. We know that there was an enhanced scenario which meant that if the government put more focus on that area of policy it would result in even greater growth. But what we saw this government do is ignore all of that information—it is all there on the public record—and cut those very programs, knowingly denying that growth and restricting the opportunities for Australian businesses and hence jobs.

I would now like to turn to a specific area which I have great interest in. It goes to the heart of two significant industry reports that have been presented in the area of information technology and services. Both the Goldsworthy's report entitled The global information economy: the way ahead and the IPAC report entitled A national policy framework for structural adjustment within the new Commonwealth of information really start to articulate what was a glaring deficiency in the make‐up of the government's frontbench.

I would like to look at the development of the recognition of information technology as a policy issue of substance by this government. It has taken quite some time for them to realise that the fastest growing global industry is of some importance to Australia. It has taken them quite some time to realise that what we have, or what we had, is a critical opportunity to position Australia to ensure that we have claim to at least a proportion of what is currently the second largest industry on the globe.

The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, was probably the first one to pick it up. It took about six or eight months for him to learn the language and the IT lingo and to start building it into responses to dorothy dixers in the chamber. He has since had a couple of briefings which have upgraded at least the perception of his knowledge of this sector. He has also had some pretty comprehensive advice to back that up.

I would like to focus on the Prime Minister, Mr Howard. It was not until Mr Howard got a second dose of what was going on in the US and President Clinton's next generation Internet and other IT initiatives that it finally dawned on Mr Howard that maybe there is some substance to this issue and maybe he had better pay lip‐service to it back home.

When President Clinton visited Australia last year and addressed both houses of parliament in the other place the issue of IT was specifically raised as being critical for Western developed nations in terms of how they approach industry policy. It did not register. He missed it completely. The Prime Minister went over to the US and when he came back he said, `IT is important.' Ding. It took a long time and we suffered as a consequence.

I do not think the Treasurer, Mr Costello, is anywhere near realising the importance of this particular policy issue. In his articulation of these macro-economic issues Mr Costello is devoid of any substance and any critical achievement in putting in place an industry policy to back what should be a competitive and growing business environment. He is not going to click to the issues. While he holds sway in cabinet this government is going to be unable to develop industry policy in any successful and meaningful way. Even if he were overridden in cabinet, I do not believe there is the vision, talent or skill amongst the frontbench of this government to actually progress sensible, practical industry policy and to do what is required to be done in this country to resolve some of these issues. So we had this rude awakening to the importance of IT.

Research and development is a backdrop to the information technologies, the information services sector. Why? Because it is high-tech. It is the top end. It is a new technology and it requires a significant research and development base to develop at an innovative level. We know Australia will never be at the forefront of hardware manufacturing. We know that, because of the lack of action of this government with respect to software development, opportunities are slipping by.

Do we see any positive action by this government to promote the remaining opportunities in this area? Do we see increased investment in research and development? Do we see support of cooperative research centres?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—No, we do not. We see $10 million worth of cuts. Do we see the recommendations from these reports into the development of our IT sector being implemented? No, we do not, because this government has not clicked yet. How long is it going to take? Meanwhile, these opportunities are flying by.

BREAK.PARA: The other issue I would like to mention about IT is the role of government procure ment. In Australia it is reasonable to say that government procurement has a far greater level of importance in terms of a Western economy because of the nature of our industry. We do not have a critical mass of large industry in Australia. We are predominantly small to medium enterprises in terms of our profile.

So how do our companies export? How do they grow and innovate and look outwards globally? One of the key mechanisms for these companies to build an export base is to build up some credential, and the biggest contracts available are in the government sector. When we talk about outsourcing Commonwealth information technologies, we are talking about giving away the ability for these companies to create credentials for themselves so that they can enter into the global market.

The whole way that this IT outsourcing process has been managed—and I have spoken about this issue many times in this chamber—is doing great damage to local SMEs. The government are ignoring that clamouring, and the small movement that they have tried to implement—there was a particular industry development section inserted into the cluster 3 request for tender—shows that, even when the industry knocks on their door and tells them what the problems are, the government cannot get it right. They have a singular focus on outsourcing, and it is to save money. Forget the impact on local business, forget the impact on innovation, forget the impact of taking away the platform or the opportunities upon which Australian companies base their credentials for exports; that is, how they sell themselves.

Have a look at what this government is doing in this area and you start to see a comprehensive package of undermining the innovative end, the interesting end, the end that could position Australia in a very significant and useful way with leading edge technologies. This issue is not over yet; it is still going.

I just want to take the time to make reference to what the member for Mackellar, Mrs Bishop, said in the other place today in response to a question from the member for Lindsay (Miss Kelly). It is worth raising in this context because, on the issue of IT outsourcing, we have heard some very specific comments from the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) about what they are trying to achieve. They are trying to save money; they are trying to position multinationals in Australia and grow our industry off that.

So let us have a look at what Mrs Bishop said in the other place about IT outsourcing. We should remember, too, that the contracts which she is referring to relate to Defence, which happened because of their decision to provide for an in‐house option bid in their IT outsourcing. Surprise, surprise! The in‐house bid was the successful one. So, here we go. Mrs Bishop states:

The recently announced tender is that relating to CRISP, which is part of the Russell redevelopment program. It is concerning the overall computing infrastructure desktop hardware and standard office operating products for Russell.

The importance of this contract is that, firstly, it is a $27 million contract of which $8.8 million—or about 30 per cent of the contract for systems integration—will go directly to Australian small and medium enterprises.
Well, well, well. She goes on to say:

Secondly, there is another $6 million which will go to IPEX, which will provide desktop devices from its Melbourne manufacturing facility, and its associated printer production of Lexmark will be manufactured in Sydney.
Mrs Bishop goes on to say:

This contract is also of importance in that it is in accordance with that important principle this government supports that I brought in which says that we require large foreign firms doing business here in Australia not to exclude SMEs by using vertically integrated companies in their tenders but to nurture and look after small and medium enterprises which are Australian, so that Australian individuals get the opportunity to work in these important areas.

Well, well, well. I wonder if Mrs Bishop has been speaking to Mr Fahey lately. I suspect not because this flies directly in the face of everything we have heard from the minister for finance on this issue from day one, when that submission was first put forward to cabinet and supported for the 1997-98 budget. We will continue to observe the mismatched ad hoc policy‐on‐the‐run approach to industry development in this critical sector by this government. My only hope is that they are limited in the extent to which they can inflict damage by virtue of our democratic processes.

Let us have a look. We have a government scratching around for leadership. We have a proliferation of reports, articulating that very point and providing some solutions, being ignored. We are seeing R&D cuts. We are seeing cuts to education that undermine industry potential in every way. The links are there—we know they are there—and the studies have been done. Consistently, this government is undermining the infrastructure that will build those foundations of a sound, solid industry that has strong growth potential.

If the best the government have to offer is focusing on the macro-economic policy settings—and I am not even convinced that they have a grip on that—then they are closing their ears to small business. They are closing their ears to what they have described as the jobs growth engine of the future. Are their doors open to only those who are well resourced enough to be able to bend the ear of the relevant ministers? It is a sad day for Australian industry to see that, even with this information around on providing advice and even with the scope and possibilities that are available to them, they are squandering opportunities every day that they are in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity this afternoon to respond to Senator Cook, Senator Murray and Senator Lundy, who just spoke, and to support my colleague on this side of the House Senator Gibson. I continue to be amazed during my short time here that, all of a sudden, after 13 years of rule by the Labor Party, they now have all the solutions. They say we should have had all the solutions and rectified the malpractices of the previous administrations in 18 months. They say that we should have cleaned up the mess in 18 months. I am afraid the mess was just too high and just too big for us—or for any administration coming in that is expected to rectify problems and fiscal problems of that magnitude—to do that.

BREAK.PARA: There were no notable reforms that the people opposite speak of during that period of 13 years. Now they have all the answers. Apart from pandering to the unions, to which members of that administration had to tug their forelocks regularly—at least in the run up to preselection time—they pandered to the people who ultimately brought them down. The eyes of ordinary decent Australians ultimately brought down the administrations of Hawke and Keating.

What the Labor Party did produce in Australia during its tenure on this hill were premiers like John Cain, Joan Kirner, Carmen Lawrence, Brian Burke, John Bannon and Peter Dowding, who in aggregate lost billions of dollars for the Australian people. How disgraceful it is to say today that we are not doing the right thing when we have to rectify those things, to try to bring back those sorts of losses and to recompense the people of Australia for the corruption at the state and federal levels and for the moral corruption at the state and federal levels. We have to do that in the short period of 18 months.

Did Labor, for instance, unjam the logs at the waterfront? No. Did they rectify the problems there with the bludgers and the crooks on the waterfront who hold Australia to ransom and make us a laughing stock in the international world of commerce?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a grub.

—If I can continue, Senator Forshaw. I worked on the wharves and I know what they are like. In fact, I was a member of the Waterside Workers Federation for some short time. What the previous administration did excel at was high interest rates. I remember those very well and so do a lot of other businessmen in Australia. They are not likely to forget that in the short term, if ever.

BREAK.PARA: Those businessmen will also remember the fact that you denied small business this week the opportunity not only of increasing their own security but of employing young people. By knocking back the workplace reforms that this government put up, you, in collusion with the Democrats—all of whom are left of you, I might say—knocked back those reforms that small business so desperately needed with unfair dismissal laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —They needed to desperately sack people. Is that your answer to unemployment? You are a twit.
—Senator Forshaw has not even learnt yet that the reform was to employ people, not to sack people. The reform was needed to employ.
—He was even against wide combs, this bloke.

—The only thing Senator Forshaw knows about combs relates to the one he runs through his hair on odd occasions. I do not think he knows too much about combs in a shearing shed. That is true, Senator Forshaw; isn't it? You have never bent your back in a shearing shed like I have, Senator Forshaw. I can tell you I have.

BREAK.PARA: They were experts with high interest rates. We had the highest interest rates that this nation has ever seen. Under your administration we had one of the great recessions that this nation has ever seen, apart from the Great Depression of the 1930s. And you have the hide and the temerity to tell this government it should have got it all right and rectified your damage in 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—Yes, an absolute disgrace. We also had the unfettered deregulation of the banks. You went in with the plump boys at the top end of the streets in the shady suburbs of Perth, Sydney and Melbourne, to whom you attached yourselves with some alacrity, and deregulated the banks. You caused that industry, which once enjoyed respect, to be reviled by average Australians because of what it is doing with its charges.

BREAK.PARA: I understand that, when we came into office, Australia had about 0.9 per cent annual growth—not even one per cent annual growth. Of course, the growth is now expected to be at the end of this fiscal year about 3.7 per cent. Senator Forshaw, I appreciate the fact that you have stayed in here. You obviously did not have much else better to do. Senator Forshaw, those figures alone will tell you that, whatever this government may have in terms of faults, at least it is working. We do not pander to the plump boys in the leafy suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne.

You left it to us to look after Mr and Mrs Average Australia. That is what you did and that is what we are doing. That is why we are going to get back in next time. You are going to sit over that side for a couple more terms yet because you have not learnt your lesson. You have not learnt your lesson. Do not criticise us because we are fixing the mess—the stinking pile of economic filth—you left behind. While it is going to take longer than 18 months, we are going to rectify it.

TALKER.NAME: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for the consideration of general business notices of motion has now expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 October, on motion by Senator Carr:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on document No. 5, the Commonwealth Ombudsman's report. I start by complimenting the Ombudsman and her office for the hard work that has been undertaken this year in what have to be increasingly trying circumstances. I quote from chapter 10 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Adequate resources are essential if the Ombudsman's Office is to be effective and fulfil its statutory role.

1996‐97 has been the busiest year ever for the Ombudsman's Office with over 50,000 approaches to the office—complaints have increased by 19 per cent over 1995‐96, and by 61 per cent over the last three years. As the Government implements further changes in administrative practices, it is likely that there will be further increases in the number of complaints to the Ombudsman's Office placing additional pressure on limited resources.
She continues:

The Ombudsman's Office has always operated on a shoestring. By international standards the Australian Ombudsman is probably the busiest and most cost effective. The situation is reaching a breaking point, with a dramatic increase in both the demand for the Ombudsman's assistance, and the office's throughput of cases.
There have been serious consequences, in particular:
. the office is being forced to turn away an increasing number of people;
. important functions have been diminished; and
. there are signs that confidence in the office is being eroded.

This is all because of cuts that this government has made to the Ombudsman's Office. This government obviously does not care to see that there is any scrutiny or any independent body or organisation for individual people with complaints and problems caused by government programs and changes, and for people to seek redress for poor treatment they are getting.

The efficacy and the ability of the Ombudsman to do work on this issue are being eroded. For that the government must stand condemned. As much as we might like to say that the public servants do a wonderful job—and they do on the whole—there are the difficult cases, the cases that slip through, the cases that are put in the too‐hard basket, and people are given a hard time. Whilst we as members of parliament are often able to assist people to resolve their problems, referral to the Ombudsman still occurs for an independent, non‐judgmental assessment of the case, for a judgment to be made and some force to be applied to the errant department.

It was also interesting to note within the report the significant increase in the number of complaints and problems being experienced by the Department of Social Security. One wonders, with these cuts to personnel, just how they are going to cope with that.

We also note that the Deputy Ombudsman Defence position was vacated in 1996 and has not been re‐filled. The Ombudsman Act provides for up to three deputy ombudsman positions. However, to reduce overheads these positions have been reduced to one, which has eroded specialisation. Of course, with the erosion of specialisation, one then begins to see maybe a diminution in the standard of the decisions being made and the advice being given. It also reduces the strength and the amount of time the Ombudsman's Office has to assist people to rectify problems.

BREAK.PARA: I also turn to the Defence Force Ombudsman report, because this is an area that I have a great deal of interest in over a number of years. This is often the place of last review, particularly for women who have had sexual harassment cases. The Department of Defence is saying that it has done a lot of things to overcome these problems but, from media reports recently, it would appear that that is not the case. The Ombudsman's report on page 239 also raises some serious issues regarding the handling of incidents, which included:
a tendency to investigate complaints (and particularly complaints regarding harassment and discrimination) whether or not an investigation was the most appropriate response;
It also talks about:
. the alternative dispute resolution strategies needed to be better integrated into the processes of deciding how to deal with these sorts of complaints;
. the widespread use of "informal inquiries" with little guidance on the conduct of such inquiries, and few accountability mechanisms in place to protect the parties involved.
When you go through this report, you have to find that it is an issue of grave concern. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pertinent that I follow Senator West on this issue of the Ombudsman. I am addressing the issue of the Defence Force Ombudsman, because I think the points that Senator West has raised are very important. Whilst Senator West obviously did not have sufficient time to canvass that section of the report, there are some significant issues in the defence area because of the current turmoil that is there, I would imagine, as a result of the Defence Efficiency Review. I am sure the role of the Ombudsman will come into play more often.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator West referred to a number of factors that had been identified as issues relating to the Australian Defence Force's handling of serious incidents. While she mentioned some, she did not move to the fact that there were no procedures for monitoring and quality control of investigations, leading to some going off the rails. That is quite unsatisfactory. Whilst I will refer later on in addressing this to the matter of how it seems to have been remedied, it is cause of grave concern that that crops up in a report at all.
When referring to alternative ways of resolving issues, the report said:
One problem we identified was a tendency to invoke an investigation under the Defence (Inquiry) Regulations, whether or not this was the most appropriate course for dealing with a complaint.
That is what Senator West said earlier. The report continued:
This is an intensive and expensive option—
One would have thought an organisation such as the Defence Force would have been very meticulous in the way it handled these cases. The report goes on to say:

In some cases, an investigation will either not solve the problem or will not be the best solution. Although there has been an increased emphasis in recent years on alternative resolution strategies for harassment complaints, the employment of such strategies is still a relatively new concept—
In view of that comment in the report, one would hope we see a changed manner within the defence forces, particularly in respect of the handling of harassment cases.
Further in the report on page 245, there is a very concerning comment about procedural fairness. The report states:
One of the matters of most concern to our office was the lack of adherence by some Defence investigators to the principles of procedural fairness.

One would think that, if we are going to have a fair and just system, we must have procedural fairness. Whilst this comment should not be tagged to all investigators within the defence forces, the report did refer to some investigators failing to follow the principles of procedural fairness. The report says:
. . . there is a need to ensure that the principles of procedural fairness are spelt out in the relevant Defence instructions and adhered to—

One would hope beyond all hope that that is the case. People who are subjected to investigation—whether they be in the Defence Force or citizens outside of the Defence Force—are entitled to fair play. Fairness is one of the hallmarks of our society, and people are entitled to fairness and justice evenhandedly distributed, not with some cooked‐up investi gation techniques used by some Rambo in the Defence Force.
The report finishes the Defence Force Ombudsman section by addressing the fact that:

Despite the difficulties the Australian Defence Force has faced with investigations in the past, the Chief of the Defence Force is to be commended for recognising those deficiencies and for taking steps to remedy the Australian Defence Force's policy and procedures.

Because this is mentioned in this report, one would certainly hope to see it reflected in what we see in reality. If we do not see it in reality, one would wonder why these reports are printed and used in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address the Commonwealth Ombudsman's report, which has been signed by the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Philippa Smith. She has done mighty work—and I use that adjective advisedly—in the area of human rights and in trying to establish a situation where people treat each other in a decent fashion. Under the heading `Ombudsman's role', the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: This year represents the 20th anniversary of the Commonwealth Ombudsman's Office.

Back when the Office was created, the Prime Minister of the day, Malcolm Fraser said, ". . . the establishment of the office is directed towards ensuring that departments and authorities are responsive, adaptive and sensitive to the needs of citizens."

The creation of the position of the Commonwealth Ombudsman was just one mechanism to enable people who live in the community to move about as well‐respected citizens—respected not only by their fellow citizens but respected by the government departments that gave them service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Respected by the people who exercise the law.

—Yes, respected by the people who exercise the law, if I can take that interjection from Senator O'Chee. One of the great difficulties, as Senator O'Chee will understand, is that the theory is all very good but, when you come to apply it, that is when the difficulty arises.

BREAK.PARA: If you object to or put in a notice of disallowance of a regulation, departments are not likely to take that kindly. They understand the general proposition that power ought to be exercised responsibly and that arbitrary power ought to be restrained. They understand that general proposition and no doubt accept it, but it is the actual example that brings forward all sorts of concerns. The person who is faced with resistance to the power that he or she exercises tends to say, `I'm doing this in a very reasonable fashion. I shouldn't be criticised.' It is the person who stands up for that citizen and pursues that topic in a proper and right way who suffers.

I would like to pay tribute to Philippa Smith, who has acted fairly over the time but, nevertheless, has come up with the resistance that anybody who stands up for the rights of others will come across. I think that is a matter of reality. People who undertake that task are at times unpopular, but that is the way it is played. Even though we recognise that, I think it is proper to say that we should pay people like Philippa Smith due deference when they do what is proper and right.

It is interesting to look at the index of this report and the sorts of matters she dealt with: Australia Post, the Australian Defence Force—and that issue has already been addressed by Senator Hogg and Senator West—the Australian Federal Police, Austudy, the Child Support Agency and so on. They are all bodies that no doubt try to do the best they can to carry out their duties, but at times they perhaps act in a way that could be labelled as an arbitrary exercise of power. It is proper that we have somebody like Philippa Smith to restrain them, to bring them back to reality so they can get back to properly serving us as citizens and can do what they no doubt intend to do.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 October, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take note of the reports of the Nuclear Safety Bureau covering the period 1 January to 31 March 1997 and the next period of 1 April to 30 June 1997. As I think honourable senators know, I live in the electorate of Hughes which contains Australia's only nuclear reactor, namely the Lucas Heights establishment. It is not widely known that two reactors are located there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Moata reactor has been decommissioned but is still on the site in its decommissioning phase, and issues continue with respect to safety and the decommissioning process. The major reactor is the Hifar reactor which is scheduled for shutdown and decommissioning in 2003. As a consequence of that, this government announced recently that it proposes to locate a new replacement reactor for the Hifar reactor at Lucas Heights. We will come to deal with that issue next year when the Senate committee looks at that decision, because there is strong community opposition to that government proposal, and that opposition relates to the question of nuclear safety.

I have never been one to come down on the side of total opposition to the mining of uranium in this country. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the union which I used to work for, the Australian Workers Union, covers most of the workers at the uranium mine in Roxby Downs or Olympic Dam in South Australia, your home state. Also, living in the area I recognise that the reactor was there at Lucas Heights long before I built a home not far away, as many other residents of that area have done.

What is of major concern is, firstly, the fact that we are going to get another reactor to replace it and, more importantly, the attitude that is adopted, particularly by ANSTO, which is reflected in this report; that is, the question of safety. There is genuine concern in the community about safety issues at Lucas Heights. It ranges from those who are moderately concerned to those who are passionately concerned.

Very recently there was an incident at Lucas Heights where it has been acknowledged that water was found to have entered the containers containing some of the fuel rods stored there. The report came out from ANSTO, and you really have to dig deep to find it—I will come to the way these reports are produced in a minute—saying that rain water had seeped into the containers containing the fuel rods. It defies one's imagination, to the normal person in the community, how rainwater could have got in, given that these containers are encased in quite thick concrete. I want to quote from page 2 of the first report because what really concerns people is that these reports are couched in such scientific language that the average person really cannot understand them. They have a right to understand these reports. The report says:

Twelve Abnormal Occurrences were reported to the NSB for the period 1 January to 31 March 1997. The Abnormal Occurrences were reviewed by the NSB and it was concluded that none had adverse safety implications. Ten Abnormal Occurrences were due to equipment fault, one was human factors related and one was not classified as to cause. Two of the occurrences involved unavoidable non‐compliance with Operational Limits and Conditions, and the NSB agreed to temporary exemptions in these cases. The NSB continued to assign levels on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES)2 to HIFAR Abnormal Occurrences on a trial basis.
How can the public possibly understand what that gobbledegook is supposed to mean? I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 October, on motion by Senator MacGibbon:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst this report is not wildly exciting, the reason for raising it is that it mentions a study going on under the auspices of the Judge Advocate General. That report was due out in June 1997. To date, I have not seen the report—I would be interested in reading it.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the report, the office of the Judge Advocate General was created to police and enforce the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982. The functions under that act include:

. . . making procedural rules for Service tribunals, providing final legal review of proceedings within the Australian Defence Force . . . and reporting upon the operation of laws relating to the discipline of the ADF.
Point 5 of the preamble to the report says:

The JAG's duty is also perceived as including the promotion of the jurisprudential welfare and education of the ADF together with the exercise of a beneficial influence upon the legal structures within it.

That is terribly important. It is one thing to say that we can have discipline—and it gets back to the issue that I raised before: it is the fact that it has to be applied fairly and equitably; otherwise the application of any discipline is seen to be harsh and oppressive. At point 6 it says:
The JAG should not,—
in the opinion of this report—
act as a general legal adviser to the ADF as that would be inconsistent with judicial office.

In reading the report, it was also interesting to find out that legal training and military legal education are now being given to civilian lawyers who act for the Judge Advocate General. Obviously, this can only be a plus for the defence forces. In particular, they are grounded in matters peculiar to military service, including military discipline law, international law and operations law.

This led to a study being commissioned. The Chief of the Defence Force tasked the Deputy Judge Advocate to conduct a study into the arrangements for the conduct of military trials, with a view to determining whether these arrangements satisfy current tests of judicial independence and impartiality. This is a very laudable and praiseworthy thing that we are seeing take place; that we can be assured that the legal processes within the military stand up to any test against what happens out in the real civilian world. The Deputy Judge Advocate was also to recommend any changes if necessary.

The study was also to look at the military justice systems in the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada and to compare those systems with that of Australia. As I said earlier, the report was expected in June this year. To date, to my knowledge, no such report has been forthcoming. When this report appears, it will be interesting to see the impact it has on the legal system as it applies within our military forces.

Another interesting point is that the report concluded that `the state of discipline within the Australian Defence Force continues to be good'. One would hope that there will be no rebellions in the near future. One must say, though, that one would have to be concerned at the impact the Defence Efficiency Review is having on morale. Let us hope that does not impact on the whole state of discipline within the Australian Defence Force.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator West:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Review Board is a very important organisation. This is one of the organisations that the government has been planning to merge, along with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal, into a single tribunal called the Administrative Review Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: This is something that the opposition has grave concerns about, and we have expressed them on previous occasions. We see a need for the independence of these tribunals, that they be kept away from departments, so that they can review, as they are supposed to do, in an objective, non‐judgmental and arms‐length manner.

When we read the overview of this report, we find that the government—as with so many other things—has not been able to make up its mind about appointments. It would appear that the Veterans' Review Board is no different, because we have had a change of Principal Member. The appointment of Mr John Gallagher, who had been the Principal Member, ended on 5 February 1997 and, by that stage, the process for a Principal Member had not been concluded.

This is a bit unusual, because it has not been the practice to have a significant number of principal members. In fact, there have only been two since 1985. It would have been fairly apparent to the government when they came to power nearly 12 months earlier that this appointment was going to be up for review. However, that did not seem to bother the government. Again, they had to put in place interim measures, and Mr Bill Cook from New South Wales acted until 7 April, when Brigadier Rolfe, retired, was appointed on 8 April for two years. I am sure that those gentlemen will do a very good job.

It needs to be brought home to this government that they are continually late in making significant appointments to boards—to lots of things—and for that they have to be criticised. This is not the way to promote harmony and efficacy in the administration and working of boards. We saw the same thing happen when the terms of appointment for the other members of the board were due to expire on 31 December 1996. In the case of senior members and members, the appointments had to be extended for six months, and for 12 months for service members. This is just sloppy work on the part of the government.

The advertisements for the senior members and members went out in March 1997. Their term was due to expire in December 1996. It is taking the government a couple of months here and a couple of months there to get their act into gear. I think it is an indication of some sloppy administration. Certainly, the advertisements were well received, and there were a lot of applications. The outcome of the selection process will be a subject of the report at the end of 1997‐98. It is not good enough for the government to have this sloppy administration attitude, where they cannot get their things ready and up to date; and it is of grave concern.

The plan to merge the appeal bodies appears to have led the Veterans Review Board into undertaking an internal review of systems and methods of operation in order to ensure that it is armed with current information when eventually it is called upon to assess or apply particular proposals. One has to wonder how much time, effort and energy that is taking up. An IDC has been set up to devise an implementation strategy and it will report to the government by late 1997. One has to presume that the government, with its usual sloppiness, will not be ready to take any action on the material when it receives the report at the end of 1997.

We also looked at the workload they have undertaken. I congratulate them on the fact that they heard a greater number of applications than last year, and that there has been a reduction in waiting time for hearings from 9.5 weeks to 7 weeks. That is something on which the board is to be congratulated. Also, a total of 7,937 applications were lodged, compared with approximately 10,000 the previous year. But it needs to be noted that we are not comparing apples with apples here, because these figures, as the department says, are misleading. Under the department's newly introduced section 31 review procedures, applications for review by the board are not counted as lodged with the VRB until the section 31 review is complete. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 October, on motion by Senator Bob Collins:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —The Civil Aviation Safety Authority of Australia, as I think all senators are aware, was established in 1995 following a restructuring of the authorities that are involved in the regulation of air safety in Australia. Prior to that time, air safety had been exclusively in the control of the Civil Aviation Authority. There was also, of course, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, whose charter was specifically to investigate air safety incidents.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will recall the tragedy of the Seaview disaster and also the Monarch inquiry. Notwithstanding the fact that, over all the years of aviation in this country, we have had a marvellous record in air safety, it was clearly recognised that there were issues that needed to be addressed and that those unfortunate circumstances that I have referred to should not have occurred and may have been avoided.

As a consequence, the previous government's minister, the member for Kingsford‐ Smith (Mr Brereton), quickly ensured that the regulatory authorities were restructured, and the old CAA had its responsibilities rearranged. Two bodies were established. Airservices Australia was established to look at airport management and such issues as flight path management, and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority of Australia was given the specific task of ensuring a continuation of the high standard of air safety.
In the corporate plan, which was released in August 1997 under the hand of the then chairman, Justice Fisher, CASA stated its vision as being:
With the aviation community, create an air safety environment which engenders public trust and confidence.

That is important. In its operations CASA, until recent times—up until the time that the recently departed minister, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) took over—was re‐establishing that enviable reputation of the highest standards of air safety in this country. On page 2 of the corporate plan, the previous—and only recently resigned—director of CASA, Mr Leroy Keith said:

The core business of CASA is to regulate the safety of civil aviation for the benefit of the Australian public. This represents a fundamental shift from the concept of `the aviation industry' as our `customer', to a primary emphasis on public safety.
Again, I emphasise the words `public safety'.

It is well known that in recent months this government, under the then minister, Mr Sharp, prior to his forced removal for other reasons, had turned air safety regulation in this country on its head. In his blind manic pursuit to get a CASA board that would do his and the government's bidding rather than focus upon the issue of public safety, he essentially set out to destroy that board. He sought to have the chairman, Justice Fisher, who quite rightly stood up to him, resign. He then set about trying to stack the board by appointing Dick Smith, the friend of the Liberal Party. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator West:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I would love to talk about the grants, but I do not think I will because I will start to feel old if I look at how the grants have gone to the people that I knew as residents and registrars at Royal Prince Alfred Hospital 25 or so years ago, people who are now associate professors and professors. This is where I get out of that one real fast—but I wish them well in their research!

SPEECH.PARA: The topic I want to deal with tonight—and I started to deal with it the other day, and warned that I would do so again—is immunisation. I feel extremely strongly about the essential need for children and people in this community to be immunised. I am old enough to remember the poliomyelitis outbreak of 1954‐55. I am old enough to have lined up as a schoolchild and put out my arm to get the Salk vaccine, which was effective against two of the three strains of polio.

I am old enough to have also been lined up as a schoolchild to be given the Sabin vaccine, which immunised against the third strain of polio. I am concerned because, reading through the report, I read a profile by Associate Professor Margaret Burgess, who talked about recalling seeing 5,000 people lined up in a street in Melbourne years ago just to get their vaccine. She says that not long ago, in the Soviet Union, there were more than 40,000 cases of diphtheria and nearly 2,000 deaths.

I have nursed children who have died from diphtheria, and there was absolutely no need for it. I have nursed a tiny baby that had whooping cough, and there was absolutely no need for it. The child was too young to be fully immunised—it was old enough to have had only one injection but not the full course—but, because other people had not had their children immunised, this child developed whooping cough. Fortunately, it suffered no side effects. The mother knew very quickly that there was something wrong with her child and took it to hospital, but it spent many days there.

That brings me to the decision last week by the government to not allow the use of Infanrix—which is the DTPA vaccine for the diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough viruses—in the primary immunisation schedule for babies at two, four and six months of age. It is approved for use in booster doses at 18 months and four and five years of age. It is approved for those doses because triple antigen—the old one that we all know—was not able to be given to children at that age because they had reactions.

It is quite widely known that children have a number of reactions to triple antigen. These can mostly be settled quite simply with some liquid or paediatric panadol. However, it is of concern to parents. They do not like to see their children with sore arms and upset. It is imperative that the government do everything it can to make available to every baby and every child in this country an injection for these three diseases in a form which is going to cause less discomfort. If you have less discomfort, you have a less unsettled child and you will get greater compliance on the part of parents. But it does not seem to work like that.

Obviously, a number of the states thought that Infanrix—or whatever they want to call it—was the superior form of immunisation and a superior vaccine. Places like Western Australia had already gone ahead with the distribution of it and they have now had to let their doctors know that it is no longer available, except where there have been severe side effects and for the older child. If parents wish to immunise their child with Infanrix, they can certainly do so, but the cost will vary between $38 and $65 per dose, to be obtained by prescription. That is three times $38 to $65, because they have to have three of these immunisations.

From the information given by the Western Australian department of health, it is apparent that the adverse events within two days of immunisation between the two drugs are different. For Infanrix, for local swelling it was only about 8.9 per cent, while for triple antigen it was 25 per cent. For local tender ness, it was 4.5 per cent for Infanrix and 29 per cent for triple antigen. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator West:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a number of observations on horticultural research and development in this country. As honourable senators know, if we are to be one of the world's finest food exporting nations, we have to be at the cutting edge of research into the products which we produce.

SPEECH.PARA: The sort of research I am talking about is not just research in terms of improved resistance to disease or pests, nor is it just things like improved research into markets. A whole range of things that we do are important to research: from improving genetic varieties, resistance to disease, management practices on farms, and the handling of goods after they leave the farm, to researching the market to ensure that what we are producing is what the market wants.

Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson, as a farmer, you will understand that. You cannot just send any product to market—or you can, but you are not going to get the best price. You get the best price by meeting the demand of the market for a particular type of product. That is what we have to be doing as a nation in terms of exporting, particularly when we talk about exporting high‐value agricultural products to some of the countries of South‐East Asia. I will give you an example of the sort of thing I am referring to.

About six or seven years ago, as some of my colleagues well know, we exported absolutely nothing by air from far North Queensland. Last season we exported 3,400 tonnes of mangoes by air from Cairns alone. Senator Hogg is doing some quick arithmetic. He will be aware that that means we exported over 170,000 trays of mangoes.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many aircraft?

—That is an interesting question, Senator West. We realised about six years ago in far North Queensland that there was an excess freight capacity in the tourist flights that were coming in. So we had frequency of flights as well as low cost of operation. One of the reasons why it is very difficult to succeed in exporting with charter planes is the cost. Let me explain, Senator West, because I know you have an interest in these matters. We are exporting out of North Queensland, out of Cairns, at a cost of 90c to $1 per kilo but generally about 90c in the peak season.
—And the back load?

—There is no back load—and this is the point—because it is a tourist plane. What happens is: if you use the hold of a 767, it will carry 11 tonnes of freight. The people who come into North Queensland come for about five days, so instead of bringing two suitcases they bring one. There leaves about five tonnes in the hold. If you were to do it by charter flight—and I know there are people who say, `We want to bring charter planes into wherever'—you have to understand that the cost will vary between $2 and $3 because there is no cost on the other side. But we succeeded in finding a way to get into the market and we also found a way of ensuring that the product we were producing was the best possible product so that we picked up the premium. We also made sure we were producing at the right time of the year.

SPEECH.PARA: The work of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation is very significant, and I want to say with a great degree of pride that this government has been instrumental in improving the level of funding. For example, the revenue from government this year is $11.867 million. That is up from $10.292 million last year. That is more than a 14 per cent increase in government grants to the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. As a result of that, the total grants they have given out has increased from $18.801 million to $21.364 million.

I was rather hoping that Senator Hogg, my friend on the other side, might have been kind enough to speak for about five more minutes because I was adding up the total of the grant money which flowed to our good state of Queensland. Senator Hogg, you will agree, as I do, that Queensland is the finest state in Australia and because of our frequency of air flights we have much better opportunities to export our product by air to neighbouring countries of South East Asia than people in some of the other states. I got as far as getting up to the new and value added horticultural products—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want another government grant? This is a pitch for another grant.

—Senator Carr, if you understand anything about exporting, these exports have to stand up on their own or they do not stand up at all. Senator Hogg, I had added up to $2.454 million of grants to Queensland but I noted that there were some 12 more pages of grants, so I am sure the figure is substantially higher. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner report for 1996-97 on the operation and the effect of the Native Title Act is a report under the hand of Michael Dodson, who is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. This is the final report that Mr Dodson will put to this parliament under section 209 of the Native Title Act 1993. I think it is appropriate that the Senate take note of this report and, hopefully, take the opportunity to debate its contents.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an extremely well‐presented, well‐researched and well‐argued report. This report highlights some of the grave concerns that are being expressed across this country in regard to the government's response to the High Court's Wik decision. This report highlights the view that nothing is more important to the shaping of our national character than the way in which our elected representatives respond to the High Court's decision in the Wik case. The report states:
Our Parliament's response to this Bill will provide a measure of the values by which we live and work together as a nation.
These are very strong sentiments. This report reflects the very deep concerns and sentiments that are being expressed across the country.

This report highlights, as Mr Noel Pearson has indicated, that the Wik peoples put a simple argument to the High Court in June this year—that is, the rights of pastoralists to their pastoral leases were in no way under challenge and the native title rights of traditional owners could coexist with the pastoralists' rights. They did not challenge the rights of the pastoralists; indeed they urged the court to confirm pastoral rights. The Aboriginal people said that all they were seeking was recognition of coexisting rights.

That is essentially the way in which the pastoral industry in this country has developed throughout its history. What this report does, and I think it is unusual in a government report, is provide a very good historical essay on the way in which the pastoral industry has existed and was founded upon the premise of coexistence. An article by Ms Ann McGrath is included in this report. It draws upon the work of prominent Australian historians and demonstrates conclusively that fundamental premise, that the basis of our pastoral industry in this country has rested upon the foundation stone of coexistence between black and white Australians. That has been the case throughout much of our history.

Of course, there have been other instances of responses to white settlement, particularly in the north and west of Australia. That is also the situation in my own state. But the fundamental premise has been that, despite the massacres, despite the wars, despite the appalling treatment, the pastoral industry has coexisted with the rights of Aboriginal people.

This report highlights that the High Court's decision was a confirmation of the rights of pastoralists. There is great irony in the way in which this matter has been debated in the public arena, the way in which this government has sought to stir up racial intolerance, and the way in which this government has sought not to educate but to inflame and to highlight racial tension in this country. As highlighted in this report:
Wik was a "conservative" judgment, "carefully securing the Crown guarantee's status quo."
The report also highlights:
There is nothing to suggest:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . that this regime of co‐existence is somehow a striking innovation in property law. Every law student knows that more than one person may have an interest in the same land. There is nothing revolutionary in the High Court's finding that the rights of the Aboriginal people can co‐exist with rights of pastoral lease holders.

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to the issue of coexistence, the fact remains that there are far greater levels of uncertainty for Aboriginal people than there are for pastoralists. I think that this is a point that is often overlooked.

What we are seeing across this country is that the Aboriginal people's response to this judgment has been, as characterised in the words of the report, `rational, responsible, constructive and firm'. There has been a constant theme in the responses of the willingness of indigenous people to accommodate the legitimate rights and needs of the pastoral industry, government and miners. There has been no rush to lodge claims over pastoral lands. In fact, on the contrary, there have been suggestions by prominent Aboriginal spokespeople in this country that there ought to be a moratorium to allow for a negotiated and reasonable settlement based on real certainty. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let Senator Carr's comments go without remark. If you listen to Senator Carr, he would have you believe that, and I think he just concluded by saying, there has been no rush to make native title claims in this country. I do not know what the situation is in Victoria, but let me say very clearly that the situation in Queensland is that there has been a massive rush of native title claims. Let me make my position very clear on those native title claims. If an area is genuinely vacant crown land and has not been set aside for a particular purpose, then it is perfectly reasonable to say that, if the Aboriginal people succeed, they should in fact be given title to it. But, better than native title, I believe they should be given freehold title to that land.

SPEECH.PARA: My point of view from a Queensland perspective is very simple. Queensland has been a state since 1859. If the government of Queensland in almost 140 years has done nothing with a bit of vacant crown land—has not even set it aside for a purpose—it is a bit churlish to say that, if Aboriginal or islander people can prove that they have native title to it, they should not be given unfettered access to utilise that land. In fact, that is the point I made to the Central Queensland Land Council earlier this year. They said, `Nobody has ever suggested to us that we should have freehold title to the land. Would you support our having freehold title where we can prove a claim?' I said, `Absolutely. I would support your having freehold title, because I think it is the only way to achieve real economic impoundment of Aboriginal people.'

One of the great problems we have is that, in many places, Aborigines are allowed to live on land, particularly in reserves, but they are never allowed to own it. The great tragedy is if you do not have a sense of ownership, you do not have a sense that there is something you can pass on to your children. I believe it is tragic that Aboriginal people may be allowed to occupy land on Aboriginal reserves but in many cases can never own it.

What we really have in many of these Aboriginal communities is just a perpetuation of medieval feudalism. These Aboriginal people are in no better a position than feudal serfs in the Middle Ages. That is a tragedy. What is also a tragedy is that, under the existing Native Title Act, it is impossible for a private individual to acquire native title rights. For all the noise that we have heard from the other side of the chamber, the one thing which is undeniable is this: in Mabo and Others and the state of Queensland, the High Court created private property rights in favour of those islander people.

It recognised the fact that they had had, prior to white settlement, a system of private property rights over land. When the Native Title Act was introduced, a provision was inserted into that act when it was a bill that said that native title cannot be owned by a private individual; it must be owned by a corporation. What the previous government did in its Native Title Act was to destroy the opportunity for Aboriginal and islander people who in fact achieve native title to own it in their own right. It has to be owned by a corporation. It is yet again a perpetuation of this sort of feudal serfdom that holds back the economic aspirations of Aboriginal and islander people.

I well recall the debate in this chamber on that particular night when I argued long and loud that this provision of the bill should be taken out and that Aboriginal and islander people should be allowed to own land themselves if they get native title to it, and they should be allowed to own it as freehold title. That is not possible and the land is effectively alienated. It cannot be transferred. I believe that the Labor government in the Native Title Act did a gross disservice to people who are crown leaseholders in this country and also did a gross disservice to Aboriginal and islander people. That, I believe, is one the great tragedies—that all of this carry‐on does not actually advance the interests of either group of people as it sits at the moment.

It is my longstanding view that we should end the paternalism as it applies to Aboriginal people and give them a chance to own the land. But Senator Carr cannot deny the fact that we have seen in the state of Queensland wholesale native title claims over large chunks of Queensland, and that is reprehensible.
Debate (on motion by Senator West) adjourned.

Debate resumed from 2 October 1997, on motion by Senator Hogg:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a few moments on this particular report. Whilst I had an opportunity to comment on the response that the government had tendered, the irony was that I did not have a chance to speak to the report that was put forward by the committee itself—and a very fine report it was too.
—It had a very good chair.

—Yes. It clearly focused on the difficulties that were being experienced by people who were outworkers in our society. These people are almost outcasts and lepers in terms of any industrial rights and industrial justice.

SPEECH.PARA: The highlight of the report, as far as I am concerned, is a case study which I will come to in a few moments. It is interesting to note that the report identified that most of the outworkers were migrant women and were aged between 25 and 35. The report identified that very few had English language skills and very few were able to find work elsewhere. This really goes to highlight how low on the food chain in respect of dignity these people are.

The inquiry itself was seeking to address the problems that are being confronted by these people. The problems listed in the report include low piece rates, which translate to low hourly rates; impossible deadlines for the completion of work; late payment, underpayment or non‐payment for completed work; rejection of work; unreimbursed expenses; physical and verbal harassment from intermediaries; blackmail, threats, coercion and bribes; substandard working environments; and worries associated with combining work with family responsibilities.

One would hardly think that this was going on in this day and age, but these are the findings of this committee and, from my experience of what goes on out there in the real world, I have no doubt that their findings are, in effect, very much correct. The recommendations that the committee brought down were seeking to redress those problems that are being confronted by those people out there—people who invariably are isolated and have no‐one to turn to for assistance. So the report, indeed, was welcome.

There are a number of case studies in the report. One sees the case of the Nguyen family, and it describes the conditions under which the Nguyen family had been outworkers. They had been outworkers for seven years. The report states:
Over the last five years they have never received rates equivalent to the award have had to rely on their daughters to assist them with work over the last five years.
They say in the report that the average working day was 12 to 14 hours a day seven days a week. This is the problem being confronted by people who have little or no knowledge of the system.

What the government has set about doing with its industrial relations reform has been to dismantle the system which may in some way protect these people. It is almost incredible to say that this is going on in Australia. It is not going on in some Third World nation. It is not going on overseas somewhere which we have never heard of; it is happening here in Australia. To that extent, it is of real concern. It goes on to say:

The Nguyens have four children aged between 18 and three years old. The children work at the machines sowing from the age of 13. Before this age, they help with ancillary tasks—turning garments out, folding, sorting, bundling and cutting threads. The children assist for an average of three hours at night and up to 10 hours a day on the weekend. On average, the children work 35 hours per week.

This is supposed to be an enlightened society. This report should be made compulsory reading for many people to see the exploitation that went on out there in the marketplace, and still does go on. It is a real indictment on the morality that exists in our society that we let this thing persist, and the response that was offered by the government was feeble to say the least. The only response to the problem of the likes of the Nguyen family came from the agreement that was worked out between a number of retailers and people working in the industry and the ACTU. That particular agreement was there to assist these people who were otherwise badly treated.

That, to me, is what this place is really about—exposing these people, exposing the problems that they are confronted with, exposing those who would exploit them and seeing that those problems are addressed. This place is not about just relying on some mystical power that will take these people out of their problem, out of their difficulties; it is about helping them in a positive and sensible way. It goes on to say:

It is not uncommon for the Nguyens to be given work to be completed within five days but the following day they receive calls from the intermediary to finish the work earlier. They have often been pressured to finish the order in 3‐4 days and have had to go without sleep for at least one day to complete the order.

If we can stamp out this sort of practice then it is a positive for our society. When you read the ages of the children in the Nguyen family it makes it all the more shameful that we are still resorting to the exploitation of child labour in this nation to provide cheap goods to the retailer, who then puts on an exorbitant mark‐up. We as unsuspecting consumers go out and pay for these goods, having no idea of the pain, suffering and inconvenience which has been put into those goods by the people who make them.

The case of the Nguyen family highlights just how sick our society is if we still treat people in this way in this day and age. Whilst I spoke to the government response to this report before actually speaking to the report, I thought that the government response was feeble at best and failed to take up the cudgel to protect the people who are least able to protect themselves. That is what we should be about in this nation. We should not worry about the high‐fliers and those who are making exorbitant profits and living in the lap of luxury.

I would commend this report to anyone as it gives a view of what we should not have in our society. I would recommend to people that they be wary of the exploitation of people in our society for the sake of the exorbitant profits which are made by those usuries out there who seek nothing other than to feather their own nests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs and Trade Committee: Joint

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 October, on motion by Senator Calvert:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled ANZUS after 45 years: Seminar proceedings, 11‐12 August 1997 . This was an important seminar because it looked at the ANZUS alliance which is 45 years old. ANZUS is a security treaty and alliance that was signed by Australia, New Zealand and the US on 1 September 1951 and ratified on 29 April 1952. It came out of the relationship that Australia had with the United States in World War II and with New Zealand a long time before.

SPEECH.PARA: This treaty has been a central pillar of our national security policy for 45 years. Our bilateral relationship with the United States has progressed remarkably well because of it. I think that fundamentally Australia's view of the world has been seen substantially through the close relationship that we have had with the United States. I think that is true of governments of all political persuasions during the last 45 years. It is an expectation of the Australian population that we have a strong relationship with the United States even though we may have differences of opinion with them and may seek to open up some of the joint facilities for accountability and management reasons. Certainly our relationship with the United States has been substantially based on that strong ANZUS relationship.

It is as important now as ever—and as the tiger economies in south and east Asia develop and the strategic balance in our region changes and has changed—that the ANZUS alliance and treaty continues. The biggest structural change to ANZUS was New Zealand's prohibition of nuclear powered ships visiting New Zealand which happened in the mid‐1980s. The joint standing committee believes that for Australia and the region there remain important advantages in maintaining ANZUS in good repair.

Although the trilateral activities no longer take place because of New Zealand's exclusion by the US—they view New Zealand's membership as merely suspended—the US fully understands and welcomes Australia's continuing relationship with our very near and dear neighbour. That is occurring all the time. New Zealand have agreed to buy two Anzac class vessels from Australia and have indicated that they would buy another one. I hope they reconsider a recent decision not to add to the two Anzac class vessels they have agreed to buy. It is important at this time to take stock of the relationship that has served Australia well, has served the region well and will hopefully continue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
