TALKER.NAME: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Consideration of committee reports and government responses has now concluded, and I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

BREAK.EMPHASIS: In the Shadow of the Cross

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 October, in the adjournment debate in this chamber, I made reference to a book that was about to be launched on the following Monday, 6 October. The book was called Orphans of the Empire , and it was to be launched by David Hill. Unfortunately, I was not able to be present at the launch, even though I had been invited and, indeed, get a couple of mentions within the book.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing I did forget to make mention of was the author of the book. I seek now to correct that mistake. Now that I have had the opportunity to read parts of the book—I have not completed it all—I want to make some remarks on the content of the book itself. Alan Gill is the author of the book Orphans of the Empire. He is a journalist of some 35 years standing, and he was a religious writer for the Sydney Morning Herald for 17 years. In 1985, he was awarded the Walkley award. In 1995, he was made a member of the Order of Australia for services to the media.

The book is not for those who wear their emotions on their shirt sleeves. It is a stark reminder of the treatment this country delivered to many young children who were brought here—some without their parents' consent. Some parents were not even told they had been brought out here. It is a book that can leave somebody with low control over their emotions close to tears, because it is very graphically written. The reason it is so graphically written is that Alan Gill spoke to many of the individuals themselves. The book is not light reading. It is not a book that you would want to take to bed with you and read before you go to sleep. It is very disturbing, recounting what those children went through. In an excerpt on the back of the book, Geraldine Doogue says:

Orphans of the Empire is unusually affecting, hard to put down but very painful to read too, at times. For the extra light it casts upon the Australian‐Irish Catholic culture that helped form me, with its warts and its well‐meaning, I am especially grateful.

Geraldine Doogue is obviously well known to everybody in this chamber. I commend Alan Gill for putting down this part of Australian history. I certainly look forward to reading the rest of it. Perhaps at some later time I might come in and recount some of the stories that are in the book.

Another book dealing with much the same subject has arrived on my desk in the last week or so. This one is called In the Shadow of the Cross: The Story of VOICES: How the Christian Brothers' Victims Fought for Justice, and the author is Bruce Blyth. On the back cover, Bruce talks about this book being a crusade for truth and justice. To a certain extent, In the Shadow of the Cross is a record of at least a part achievement in that crusade for truth and justice.

I was reminded in glancing through the book—again, I have not had the opportunity to read each and every part of it because of pressures of parliament and of the committees of parliament—of some comments that I made in the Senate some four years ago, in 1993, when I said that the possibility of a cover‐up on allegations of child abuse within the four institutions in Western Australia was reflecting on the Catholic Church as a whole. That was not something I had wished to happen. My former colleague and former senator John Panizza joined with me in the hope that that was not going to happen to the church, but it does appear that perhaps the events in Western Australia and in other places in Australia have reflected poorly on the Catholic Church in Australia.
An article that appeared on page 5 of the Australian on 26 September 1997 is headlined `Public bash, abuse Catholic priests'. Part of the article states:
Catholic priests had been bashed, publicly abused and their homes subject to graffiti attacks in unprecedented displays of hostility, a senior Bishop said yesterday.
Bishop of Sydney Geoffrey Robinson said the incidents could be linked to public anger directed at priests over child abuse allegations.
Bishop Robinson is the co‐chairman of the church's national committee for professional standards which is drafting a code of conduct to counter sex abuse scandals.

It is very regrettable that articles such as that appear in our media. Now that a number of things have happened in our community, I hope we will not be seeing reports of priests or anybody else being bashed or abused in public or, indeed, even in private.

There have been a number of developments occur in this record of history—it is not a particularly proud record of Australian history—and this book by Bruce Blyth records some of them. Justice is close for some people, but it is not there for each and every one of the victims and probably never will be. But at least now there is public recognition by the church authorities, at least in Western Australia, that some things were not all that they should be. In doing that, they have accepted some of the blame, indeed, are moving towards reconciliation and also paying some small measures of compensation.

Bruce Blyth and the membership of VOICES have to be commended and congratulated for their efforts. Their struggle over the years was not easy. It was very difficult, particularly in the early stages, to get acceptance that the allegations that the individuals were making were indeed true. I came into the issue only because certain individuals—some of whom speak with an accent similar to mine—approached my office seeking my assistance for them to get their identity back, to get their name back and to get themselves a passport or an identity document in order for them to travel to where they had been brought from—in some cases it was Northern Ireland and in some it was the northern parts of the Republic of Ireland. We were able to assist some of them in getting those documents, but we could not in every case heal the hurt that was deep in their hearts.

I think that justice is getting close for the victims. I commend Bruce Blyth and the membership of VOICES. I also commend the Catholic Church and those in authority within the church for the achievements they have made to date. I do not think the war—if that descriptive term can be put to it—is over, but certainly it has gone a long way towards addressing the wrongs that occurred in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Cook moved general business motion No. 826 relating to the government's industry policy. I was, in fact, on the speakers' list and did not get reached before the time for the debate had expired. I was so astounded by some of the claims made during the debate that I wish to take up some of those matters in the adjournment debate tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The very terms in which that motion was couched indicate Labor's fundamental confusion as to what actually underpins good industry policy. There has never been any shortage of advice given to governments of either persuasion about what will assist industry. Currently, the government is contemplating the Mortimer report, the Goldsworthy report, the Cutler report and the Metal Trades Industry Association report on the need for proactive investment. Whilst shortly the government will be announcing its response to this plethora of recommendations and encouraging investment and growth in Australian business, there cannot be any reasonable doubt that the most effective industry policy for Australia is, and will remain, fixing the economic fundamentals so that growth can be directed through the market.

To be able to do this we need to get a fairer and more efficient tax system that allows us to compete internationally; to get a well-designed tax system that delivers a lower rate of taxation for all businesses, not just those privileged enough to get a government handout; and to effectively deregulate industrial relations if Labor and the minor parties in this chamber will permit it. Of course a couple of nights ago we saw the extraordinary resolution of this chamber against the exemption of small businesses from unfair dismissal laws—a job destroying decision if ever there were one. We also need to fix the waterfront, to continue competition policy development, and to identify and remove distortions that protect some sectors at the expense of others.

The government's scorecard on macro-economic reform so far is impressive. I will come back to that if time permits. But the government does recognise that there is a role to play in providing incentives to industry for growth and development. Arguments about incentive schemes tend to downplay the fundamental fact that, under Labor, all too often such incentives were little more than business welfare involving a transfer from Australian taxpayers—and, in effect, from other efficient businesses—to those industries that succeeded in a bit of special pleading to government to justify handouts. Not only does this result in sectoral distortions but it is based on dubious and untested assumptions that the trickle‐down effect actually results in net economic gains for Australia.

While there can be no doubt that Australia needs to encourage export competitiveness and exploit our position in the region, the recent destabilisation in the South-East Asian economy must lead us to question the assumption that what works in Asian economies automatically works in Australia—it does not. Unfortunately, Labor had 13 years to develop a good industry policy and to get the fundamentals right. It failed pretty dismally. Under Labor, the manufacturing sector was forced to shed over 200,000 jobs and showed no net growth in employment for 12 years. So it was more than a little ironic that Senator Cook's motion actually sought to reinstate a job target of 200,000 in the manufacturing sector.

Business investment declined to its lowest level on record. Australia's average productivity improvement was just 0.9 per cent, half the world's average for this century; foreign debt increased by 800 per cent; real household incomes decreased by nine per cent; a million people were left unemployed; and—here is the clincher—Australia slipped from 18th to 24th in terms of business expenditure on research and development among OECD nations. Despite the promises of the Labor government to make Australia the clever country, in 1995 we imported $20 billion worth of technology developed by other countries.

What is more alarming for business investment however is that Senator Cook seems unrepentant. He is still intent on picking winners rather than improving the conditions for all businesses to flourish. He was reported in the Australian Financial Review on 17 October this year as misty eyed about the virtues of the now discredited development import finance facility, the DIFF scheme. The headline was: `Another DIFF needed, says Cook.'

Senator Cook is advocating that the company Transfield should again be given a mixed credit taxpayer funded loan to help it win a contract for $178 million to build four patrol boats for the Philippines. It prompted Janet Hunt, the Executive Director of the Australia Council for Overseas Aid, to write to the Financial Review on 22 October. Her letter begins:
Senator Peter Cook's call for a "son of DIFF" to assist Transfield export patrol boats is a worrying sign.

Indeed it is. In case it has escaped Senator Cook's attention, the Simons review of the DIFF scheme recommended against any tied mixed credit scheme and warned against the use of aid to promote trade agendas.

Another example of Labor's backward looking attitude to industry policy was Labor's call for intervention in the recent BHP rationalisation of its steel division in Newcastle. The call for intervention would have simply deferred the hard decisions, long overdue, that BHP needed to take to modernise to make itself internationally competitive.

I doubt that there would be anyone in this chamber who fails to recognise the importance of incentives for a national research development effort and that innovation and investment are major factors driving growth and likely to produce new job opportunities. But proposals for R&D incentives posed in the Mortimer report require careful and considered evaluation before they are adopted.

Unlike Labor, this government had the courage to get rid of the inefficiencies of syndication. Even Senator Cook has said the previous syndication system was `an escalating and unsustainable cost to the taxpayer'. So what can he possibly have meant when he called today for a reverse to cuts in industry programs? Does the opposition know whether it is coming or going on industry policy?

The R&D start program, which replaces syndication, provides $520 million over four years for genuine R&D. It is better targeted towards larger grants in areas of high‐risk research and development. R&D funding under the previous government—where I think Senator Cook held the portfolio, although memories fade quickly—encouraged a focus on financial returns for wealthy promoters and investors, rather than generating an interest in genuine R&D.

The government's R&D start program announced the establishment of the Innovation Investment Fund, which will provide $130 million in government funding on a two‐for‐one basis giving access to venture capital for small technology based enterprises. It will make available a total of about $200 million for commercialisation of R&D and fills a longstanding gap in the marketplace.

The need for access to early stage venture capital was simply ignored by the Labor government. The Innovation Investment Fund is based on successful venture capital models established in the United States and Israel, and will help to ensure a much greater return on R&D expenditure. Australia needs such investment in R&D in order to be competitive and to meet the challenges of the next century.

Senator Cook's motion then called for a recommitment to a manufacturing jobs target of $200,000. As I said a little earlier, it is a bit rich, as it was the manufacturing sector that was forced to shed over 200,000 jobs and now Labor wants this government to put these jobs back. Of course, now manufacturing is globally cost competitive and is growing at twice the rate of all exports, mostly without government assistance.

Whatever response the government does make to the various industry recommendations before it, such initiatives will simply be ineffective unless the artificial impediments to business success are removed. Reform of the tax system, restrictions on industrial relations and removal of those, will have a far greater impact on the success of our economy than any amount of business handouts. This government has got its priorities right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to start by acknowledging some visiting members of my family in the gallery: my uncle, Ed Walker, and cousin, David. How are you?

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad Senator Coonan is here and I hope she has got time to stay for a moment, because I am speaking on an issue that Senator Coonan raised in the parliament on 24 September.

Another recent controversial use of parliamentary privilege has involved Senator Conroy reading into Hansard a transcript of interviews said to be by National Crime Authority investigators with Mr John Elliott and others—evidence that had been ruled inadmissible in the Supreme Court of Victoria.
She goes on to say:

. . . aspects of the matter concerning whether the protection of parliamentary privilege extends to matters covered by the secrecy provisions of the NCA have been referred to the Senate Committee of Privileges . . .
And further on:

It raises the spectre of individuals being persecuted or being accused in a public forum with little or no effective redress. If the legal system has failed to achieve a fair balance between the interests of the person or persons accused of criminal or civil wrongdoing and the public interest in having that person brought to justice, it is, in my view, for the legal system to address.

I inform the Senate that a number of legal opinions have been sought recently. I have one from Professor Davis, Professor of Law at ANU, who regularly works for a number of the parliamentary committees. We have the benefit of his view on what transpired before the NCA committee and the conduct of Messrs Richter and Walker. Professor Davis said:

At the Committee hearing on 12 June 1997, Mr Richter submitted that at least those transcripts were confidential. He said, to quote from the proof Hansard Report of that meeting, at p 882: `Senator Conroy is purporting to read from a transcript of evidence which was given in confidence. That confidentiality was never lifted. His Honour Mr Justice Vincent ruled that it was illegally obtained and excluded the evidence.'
Professor Davis went on to say:

The first thing to be said about this submission is that it appears to confuse, on the one hand, the propriety of the way in which the evidence was obtained and its admissibility in criminal proceedings with, on the other hand, the status of the documents as confidential. Those two issues must be kept completely separate. Whether a document has been obtained legally or illegally has no bearing on whether it should be regarded as confidential.
Furthermore, the mere fact that evidence is ruled inadmissible in a criminal trial is irrelevant to the question of whether the evidence is confidential.

The law relating to confidentiality is still in a state of development, but one thing which would appear to be relatively clear is that a claim that a particular document is confidential must be based on some legal principle. Merely to assert confidentiality, without some legal backing for that claim, is not enough. Such a claim may be based, say, on a contract between two parties, or on principles of equity or as an aspect of the property rights which a person has in information, or in a document.

The only provision of the Act which appears to be even remotely relevant is section 51, dealing with secrecy. But that section merely prohibits a member of the Authority, or a member of its staff, from revealing information obtained by the Authority, otherwise than in connection with the performance of his or her duties under the Act.

This will come as no surprise to anybody in this chamber, but I am not actually an employee of the National Crime Authority. Therefore, I am not bound by the secrecy provisions of the NCA Act. It is quite clear that that is the case. Further:

In particular, subsection 51(3) permits, but does not require, a member of the Authority to provide, in Court, information which has been obtained in the course of an inquiry, where the divulging of that information is "necessary . . . for the purposes of a prosecution instituted as a result of an investigation carried out by the Authority in the performance of its functions" (see paragraph 51(3)(b)).

That is absolutely clear. If you collect information, it is allowed to be tendered in court. That is perfectly clear. If NCA staff give material to the courts as part of legal proceedings against individuals, that material is part of the public documents. They are not private, not secret or not illegally obtained, but public documents. Professor Davis went on to say:

Although some of the documentary evidence tendered by the NCA was found to be inadmissible for a variety of reasons, much of it was accepted without objection by the defence. As the transcript of the committal hearing shows (at p 199), the contents of all of the documentary evidence which Mr Richter now claims is confidential was made available to the press, subject only to the members of the press checking with counsel that any part which they proposed to use was not inadmissible for one reason or another, or was not hearsay.

At the trial before Justice Vincent, the evidence which the NCA proposed to lead was initially embargoed and not permitted to be released to the media. The reason for that was that anyone who was to be a member of the jury should not be allowed to discover the nature of the evidence to be led, otherwise than in court. But when his Honour ruled that most of the evidence was inadmissible, and the prosecution declined to lead any evidence against the accused, the embargo on release of the material held by the NCA was lifted.
Lifted—no embargo, no secrecy provisions. It was lifted; they were public documents. Professor Davis went on to state:
There was hence no judicial ruling that the material be kept confidential, or not released to the public.

All you have to do to get these transcripts is go down to Justice Vincent's court and request them. It is that simple. Or, if you happen to know somebody who was given a copy during the trial, you can ask them for a copy. That is not illegally obtained. What has been said is an absolute furphy. Further:

However, as a result of further discussion before the Committee, especially by Mr Walker QC, the Prosecution Case Statement was described by that counsel as "a purely confidential, private document" . . . and therefore one which ought not to be tabled before the Committee.
Professor Davis said:

BREAK.PARA: With all respect to counsel, I find it
very hard to support this contention.
That is about as close as lawyers get to saying, `What a crock. What an absolute furphy.'

What you had here was a deliberate attempt by counsel representing Elliott and Scanlon to impugn me for my actions in my duties as a senator. They suggested that I was doing illegal things and that I had in my possession illegally obtained documents. It was purely a stunt because they did not want to answer any questions about the evidence that their own people gave before the NCA. That is all that happened at that committee.

Then, when I read into Hansard the documents that are publicly available on request, I am accused of being similar to Franca Arena for abusing parliamentary privilege. It is a sad day when qualified legal people mislead the parliament. Senator Coonan—an eminent lawyer in New South Wales, I am told—runs this furphy out that I am tainted in the same way as Franca Arena in New South Wales.

I am sorry that Senator Coonan has left the chamber. I advised her beforehand, as protocol, that I would be speaking about what she had to say. For her to suggest on the basis of my actions—which she has not investigated and has not sought to clarify with the NCA committee—that the Senate's parliamentary privilege needs to be changed is an absolute misleading—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: Senator Conroy has been given a lot of latitude here tonight, but it is not parliamentary for him to suggest that Senator Coonan was somehow attempting to mislead the Senate. That is quite contrary to standing order 193. I suggest, Madam Deputy President, that you instruct Senator Conroy to confine his remarks to those which are parliamentary.
—What Senator Conroy said was not unparliamentary. There was no accusation of deliberate misleading. I will listen to what Senator Conroy says very carefully.

—In conclusion, I repeat that Elliott's lawyers and Scanlon's lawyers have been running around this country trying to suggest that I have been acting illegally. They have made that statement many times. It is not true. They have misled the committee, they have misled this parliament, and they were trashed by the full bench on appeal in Victoria where even Judge Brooking suggested, in the harshest possible legal terms, that Richter QC was not telling the truth in evidence before Justice Brooking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to rise, but I must make a number of observations having heard Senator Conroy.
—You were listed.

—I was not going to make a speech tonight because I had intended to speak about another matter which has not transpired. I want to make a number of observations following Senator Conroy's contribution to the adjournment debate. The first of those is this. With the greatest respect to my friend Professor Davis, in every legal case there are two sets of lawyers; and one set wins and one set loses. What Senator Conroy must understand about legal opinions is that half of the time they tend to be wrong. I am not casting aspersions upon Professor Davis—he is a very fine man and a very fine academic—but, just because Senator Conroy can find one lawyer who will write an opinion which supports Senator Conroy's action, it does not mean that Senator Conroy's conduct was legal, nor does it mean that Senator Conroy's conduct was the sort of conduct which should be welcomed in this Senate or in the committees of this parliament. I want to make that comment very clear.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a place and I understand that there is a role for parliamentarians to use parliamentary privilege to raise matters of significance. I understand that, but there is also a limit. The limit is decency and respect for the freedoms of individuals. What Senator Conroy has done has been to utilise the proceedings of this parliament to conduct a witch‐hunt, a vendetta, for purely political motives because he sees that as advancing the cause of the Labor Party in Victoria. It is his right to form that view, but I ask honourable senators: is that the best purpose to which this parliament can be put? I would say no.

There are many things that this parliament can be used for. There are many things which are appropriate for debate in this place, but I would have thought that if Senator Conroy wanted to use his undoubted talents he could have used them in a much more constructive and creative fashion. Moreover, I am disappointed that Senator Conroy persists in using this to justify his unjustifiable conduct in that Senate committee.

Quite frankly, I would not conduct myself in that way. I know that most senators would not conduct themselves in that way because they see that conduct as unbefitting a senator. It is for Senator Conroy and his conscience to wrestle with whether he considers this satisfactory, but I will have Senator Conroy know that there are many people in this chamber who were disappointed, not in a political sense, but disappointed in a sense of propriety, with the way in which Senator Conroy conducted himself at that hearing for the simple reason that everybody knew that Senator Conroy was willing to recklessly impugn people, be they guilty or innocent, to obtain a political motive.

I can understand why Senator Coonan would compare Senator Conroy's actions with those of Mrs Arena in the New South Wales parliament. If I were forced to make a decision, I would have to say, leaving my party hat off, that I would be forced to align myself with Senator Coonan's comments rather than with Senator Conroy's comments because I can see very little difference between Mrs Arena going out and accusing people of being paedophiles—she may have seven boxes of documents, she may have four, she may have four folders, she may have absolutely nothing—and Senator Conroy accusing people in this country of being somehow involved in criminal conspiracies just because it suits him and his political ambitions.

In this Senate, we begin every day with an invocation that this parliament should serve and prosper the good of the nation. I do not think that Senator Conroy is doing that and that is why I urge Senator Conroy, in the weekend that he has available to him, to give some serious consideration to the moral consequences and the moral guidance of his actions because I believe it is unfortunately lacking.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 August 1997:

BREAK.PARA: Were the rates per business kilometre for motor vehicle claims in income tax returns for the 1996‐97 financial year lower than the rates which applied for the 1995‐96 financial year, if so: (a) how are these rates determined; and (b) what were the rates in:(i) the 1995/96 financial year, and (ii) the 1996/97 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The rates per business kilometre for motor vehicle expenses for travel of less than 5,000 business kilometres for the 1996‐97 financial year were lower than the rates which applied for the 1995‐96 financial year.

However in March 1996 when announcing the rates applicable for 1995‐96, the Assistant Treasurer outlined the 1995 Department of Industrial Relations (DIR) rates and foreshadowed that they would apply in 1996‐97 unless the rates subsequently rose.

The DIR rates for 1996‐97 subsequently fell with the exception of the rate applicable to vehicles with non‐rotary engines exceeding 2600 cubic centimetres. The foreshadowing of the rate applicable in the following financial year was designed to ensure taxpayers would not face any unexpected income tax liabilities which could occur if they received allowances based on the 1995‐96 rates.

(a) Rates per business kilometre for motor vehicle claims are specified in the Income Tax Regulations. Since the 1986‐87 income year, the rates have followed the private motor vehicle rates for the Commonwealth Public Service set by the DIR. The DIR rates are set by a subcommittee in accordance with a Joint Council methodology that is prescribed in the Continuous Improvement in the APS Enterprise Agreement: 1995—1996. The methodology requires a triennial review of the rates, with an annual adjustment based on the Private Motoring Component of the Consumer Price Index (CPI) in the intervening years.

The subcommittee comprises representatives from the Department of Work Place Relations and Small Business (formerly known as the Department of Industrial Relations), Telstra and the Community Public Sector Union (CPSU).

The triennial review is carried out to ensure rates continue to reflect the approximate cost of running a private vehicle. The review takes into account the following vehicle running costs; depreciation, interest, comprehensive insurance, third party insurance, registration, drivers licence costs, motoring organisation fees, tyres, petrol, repair and maintenance intervals.
A triennial review was held in 1996 and resulted in rates being reduced compared to those rates which applied for the 1995‐96 financial year, due to:
. significant reductions in interest rates available from financial institutions;
. improved fuel economy of current vehicles; and
. reduced maintenance costs due to longer service intervals.

The triennial review further observed that motor vehicle sales and production had moved away from vehicles in the small medium range and decided that the previous four categories (small, small medium, upper medium and large) should be reduced to three (small, medium and large). The findings of the triennial review were endorsed by_the sub committee.

Following the triennial review for 1996‐97, the Assistant Treasure's Office announced on 3 April 1997, new rates which would apply for the 1996‐97 financial year and foreshadowed rates which may apply for the 1997‐98 financial year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Taxation Office: Lamesa Holdings BV

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what grounds did the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) fail in its Federal Court action to tax Lamesa Holdings BV for the sale of shares in Australian Resources Ltd.
(2) How much tax did the ATO fail to get.
(3) On what grounds did the ATO initiate action in order to tax Lamesa Holdings BV.
(4) Was the ATO's failure due to deficiencies in (a) the current legislation; or (b) the current double tax treaty between Australia and the Netherlands.
(5) In light of the ATO loss, does the Government plan to review either the treaty or the legislation with a view to making any changes.
(6) Is the manner in which Lamesa Holdings BV structured its sale of shares in Australian Resources Ltd a cause for concern for the ATO.
(7) What is the threat to revenue from similar structured transactions.
(8) What has been the cost to date regarding ATO's action for both its legal representation and any costs awarded against the ATO.
(9) Will the ATO be seeking to appeal the Federal Court decision to the High Court; if so, how confident is the ATO of succeeding in any High Court action.
(10) Did Lamesa Holdings BV enter into any discussions with the ATO at any time from the launch of the ATO litigation with a view to settling the dispute.
(11) If any offer to settle the action was made, what was the ATO's response.
(12) If an offer to settle was made, what were the terms and any amount offered by Lamesa Holdings BV to settle the litigation.
(13) If a High Court action is proceeded with, what would the approximate cost of such an action be.

(14) Did the ATO take any outside legal advice on the merits of proceeding with the litigation in the Federal Court; if so: (a) from whom was this advice taken; (b) how much did it cost; (c) what was the nature of the advice; and (d) can a copy of that advice be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation's primary argument in the Lamesa case was that the "assets" of Australian Resources Ltd (ARL) should be held to be the assets held by Arimco Mining Pty Ltd. The latter company held interests in three mines and was controlled by ARL through a 100% shareholding in Australian Resources Mining Pty Ltd which in turn held 100% of the shares in Australian Resources and Mining Company NL with that company holding 100% of the shares in Arimco Mining Pty Ltd. A flow chart setting out the company structure is attached.

Article 13 of the Australia/Netherlands Double Tax Agreement (DTA) provides for income from the alienation of real property to be taxed in the State in which the real property is situated. Real property is defined by the Article to be:
(i) a lease of land or any other direct interest in or over land;
(ii) rights to exploit, or to explore for, natural resources; and

(iii) shares or comparable interests in a company, the assets of which consist wholly or principally of direct interests in or over land in one of the States or of rights to exploit, or to explore for, natural resources in one of the States.

The Commissioner's argument was that the income arising from the sale by Lamesa of its shares in ARL fell into category (iii) and should, accordingly, be taxable in Australia where the rights to exploit or to explore were situated. The argument was based on the Court taking a "substance over form" approach which would have recognised that as the DTA provides in sub‐subparagraph (iii) for real property to be held indirectly through a company that Australia's rights to tax should not be defeated merely because the rights were held indirectly through a chain of wholly owned group companies.

The Commissioner's argument was based on the principle that international treaties are to be construed more liberally than domestic law provisions given that they allocate taxing rights between the parties to them rather than impose tax as is the case with the domestic law i.e. the right to tax exists under Australian domestic taxation law and the treaty merely determines whether that taxing right can be exercised by Australia in relation to Netherlands residents deriving income in Australia.
The Commissioner was unsuccessful in this argument before the Full Federal Court.

(2) The profits on which Lamesa was assessed resulted in a primary tax liability of $74,199,875 this consisted of tax on profits derived in the year ended 30 June 1994 of $28,111,646 and in the year ended 30 June 1996 of $46,088,229.

(3) The Commissioner initiated action to assess Lamesa under the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (ITAA) dealing with capital gains (section 160ZO). These assessments were subsequently amended to assess Lamesa on the profits from the sale of the ARL shares under section 25(1)(b) of the ITAA (i.e. as ordinary income amounts rather than on the capital gain).
(4) The Commissioner was not successful because of deficiencies in the current DTA between Australia and the Netherlands..
(5) The Government is currently considering the options open to it in relation to the decision.

(6) Yes. However, it should be noted that in the Lamesa case the real property was held indirectly by Australian Resources and Mining Company NL (at that time Arimco NL) prior to the purchase of that company by ARL and its subsidiary Australian Resources Mining Pty Ltd (ARM). Accordingly, based on the Courts finding that Article 13(2)(a)(iii) only applies to real property held by one company tier, interposition of ARL and ARM could not be said to have occurred purely to derive a tax benefit under the Australia/Netherlands DTA as Article 13(2)(a)(iii) would not have applied even if Lamesa had purchased the shares of Arimco NL directly.

The Commissioner will, however, be scrutinising similar structures to that used in the Lamesa case very closely and will not hesitate to use Part IVA of the ITAA in circumstances where the interposition of companies between the real property and a non‐resident that has control over that real property results from a scheme to defeat the operation of Article 13(2)(a)(iii).

(7) It is not possible to gauge how many similarly structured transactions may be in existence or the potential revenue loss that might be involved. The effectiveness of similarly structured transactions is subject to the comment on the potential application of Part IVA of the ITAA as referred to in the previous question.

(8) Barristers costs for the ATO are in the vicinity of $140,000, the costs of the Australian Government Solicitor will be approximately $60,000 while costs awarded against the ATO have been advised by the taxpayer's representatives to be around $1.2 million

(9) The Commissioner has decided not to seek special leave to appeal to the High Court. The Commissioner's decision is based on the fact that the decision of the Full Federal Court is one open to it on the wording of the DTA albeit the Commissioner would contend not within the spirit of what was intended to be the situation under the DTA.
(10) Three settlement offers were received by the Commissioner through the Commissioner's legal advisers.
(11) As the profit was either assessable or not, the Commissioner did not see any basis for settlement of the case..
(12) The secrecy provisions of the tax law preclude the Commissioner of Taxation from providing this information.
(13) Question is no longer relevant.

(14) The Commissioner took verbal legal advice from Mr David Bloom QC and Mr Tony Pagone prior to the hearing in the Federal Court. Written opinions in relation to appeal applications to the Full Federal Court and also the High Court were obtained from Mr David Bloom QC, Mr Tony Pagone and Mr Tony Payne. The advice was provided on a confidential basis and is covered by legal professional privilege.
